loans.name: Mercedes Namay

texts.es:
Mercedes leads the Communal Bank "Mujeres Trabajando II," she lives in the San Martín region of San Martín province, Tarapoto district. Her business is located in her home at Jr. Federico Sánchez Nº 539 where she sells groceries, fruit and vegetables.

Thanks to the support of Manuela Ramos she and her son have been able to grow their business. The loan from Manuela Ramos is used to buy large quantities of groceries and supply them according to her customer's needs.

With the loan for 800.00 soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy rice, sugar (in sacks), milk, eggs, and other products such as candy, costume jewelry and accessories (hair clips, earrings, hoops, etc.) that sell well in her business.

Mercedes is 45 years old, she lives with one of her 6 children whom she makes study and wishes to be successful so with the support of Manuela Ramos she has the capital to grow her business and offer more products. She feels satisfied to be able to help more women with this kind of opportunity that Manuela Ramos provides to be able to develop oneself economically and ensure the family's success.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Mercedes lidera al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Trabajando II”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia D. San Martín, distrito D. Tarapoto. Su negocio está ubicado en su domicilio en el Jr. Federico Sánchez Nº 539 y se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes, frutas y verduras al por menor.

Es una mujer que gracias al apoyo D. Manuela Ramos y D. su hijo ha logrado incrementar su negocio. El préstamo D. Manuela Ramos lo utiliza para comprar los abarrotes en mayor cantidad y surtirlos D. acuerdo a la necesidad D. los clientes.

Con el préstamo D. S/. 800.00, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará arroz, azúcar (en sacos), leche, huevos y otros productos como golosinas, pasamanería (ganchitos, aretes, aros, etc) que tienen buen movimiento en el negocio.

La señora Mercedes tiene 45 años, vive con uno D. sus 6 hijos a quien hace estudiar y desea sacarle adelante con lo cual agradece el apoyo D. Manuela Ramos porque le permite tener un capital para mover en su negocio y ofertar más productos, asimismo se siente satisfecha con poder difundir a más mujeres este tipo D. oportunidad que Manuela Ramos da para poder desarrollarse económicamente y llevar adelante a su familia.

loans.use: Purchase groceries (milk, sugar, rice, eggs, etc.)

loans.name: Nanci

texts.es:
Nancy belongs to the Communal Bank El Gran Pajaten, she lives in San Martín region, Mariscal Cáceres province, Juanjui district, and her business is located at Jr. Leticia donde funciona el mercado Nº 1 where she sells eggs.

Thanks to the support of her husband and children she has been able to grow her business. Previously she was a street vendor, and seeing the great demand in the selling of eggs, she decided to expand her business and sell them wholesale, and today she delivers her eggs to homes.

With the 2000.00 Soles loan, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy eggs in crates and by the hundred as well as packages of toilet paper.

Nancy is very active, she likes to work, she is 26 years old and has two children, she lives with her husband who helps her and gives her encouraging words to continue to be successful.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Nancy pertenece al banco comunal El Gran Pajaten, vive en la región San Martín, provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui y su negocio está ubicado en Jr. Leticia donde funciona el mercado Nº 1 y se dedica a la venta de huevos de granja.

Gracias al apoyo de su esposo y de sus hijos logró incrementar su negocio. Anteriormente la venta era ambulatoria y viendo la gran demanda en la venta de huevos decidió incrementar su negocio y venderlos al por mayor con lo cual hoy en día reparte sus huevos a domicilio.

Con el préstamo de S/.2,000.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará huevos en jabas y en cientos, así como papel higiénico en paquetes.

La señora Nancy es muy activa, le gusta el trabajo, tiene 26 años y dos hijos, vive con su esposo, el cual le ayuda y le da palabras alentadoras para seguir luchando.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise (eggs and toilet paper)

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris T. E. from Morales, in San Martin, owns a business raising and selling chickens. She started the business in July of 2004 to earn money to feed and educate her two children. After inheriting some land from her parents, she saw the opportunity to take charge of her life. She learned how to raise chickens from her brother who has a similar business. She currently has over one thousand chickens and believes there is plenty of room to grow.

At 34 years old and divorced, she works hard to keep her business running efficiently and take care of her children. Having her own business gives Doris the flexibility to do both. Before she started her business, times were hard. She is now very happy and couldn’t imagine doing anything else.

With a loan of $500, Doris would like to buy more chicken feed so she can raise more chickens next season. She is a member of the Community Bank Mujeres Rumbo Al Desarrollo who help support her business decisions. Doris is ambitious and proud of her accomplishments. In the future she would like to expand her business and raise pigs, too.

loans.use: To buy feed for chickens

loans.name: Jany

texts.en:
Jany R. G. from Morales in San Martin has a business cooking and selling barbequed meat from her home. Jany is 39 years old and has 3 children and a terminally ill husband. She started the restaurant in August of 2007 with an old grill, and it’s currently the family's only source of income. She has experienced steady growth and demand for her delicious meats, which she attributes to her location and product. She always buys the best meats to cook, and her home is located on the corner of the busy town plaza. With the disposable income she has earned, she has reinvested in the business and bought a new grill, plates, and utensils.

The barbeque business has come naturally to Jany as she has experience managing other businesses. Jany is happy to work from home where she gets to spend time with and take care of her family. She is a hard worker who wakes up early and goes to bed late to balance her many duties.

Jany, a member of the Community Bank Mujeres Rumbo Al Desarrollo, is seeking a $675 loan to improve the main dining room and the bathroom. She is confident that these improvements will attract new clients and further improve the family's economic situation. In addition to improving her restaurant, Jany dreams of owning telephone booths, another lucrative business.

loans.use: To improve her restaurant

loans.name: Rosio Isabel

texts.en:
Rocio Isabel Gerdini Ushinahua from Tarapoto in San Martin started her business in July of 2006. She sells prepackaged foods and toiletries to her neighbors from a small store she built into her home. She started the business with $350, a table, and a display case. She has slowly increased her inventory and number of products. Rocio’s store is located in an area where she has little competition and her neighbors don’t need to make the long trek to the market. Because of these features and her friendly service, she has many faithful clients.

Rocio Isabel is 45, married, has three young children, and is very motivated. She started the business so she could improve the family's economic situation and send her children to school. Learning to run her business came easily as she grew up managing a juice bar with her parents. She is a dedicated mother who loves her job because it enables her to spend more time with her children.

With a loan of $500 dollars, Rocio would like to restock and add new products that are frequently requested by clients. Rocio is a member of the Communiity Bank Mujeres Emprendedoras who support her business decisions. She is confident that she will have no problem repaying the loan and excited to have the opportunity to provide a better service to her community.

loans.use: To buy various products

loans.name: Antoine

texts.fr:
Mr. Antoine M. is 29 years old married and the father of 2 children. For the last 6 years, he has been the owner of a store that sells traditional colorful wrap around fabric in Adéta. He buys in bulk in Lomé and retails them in his store. For the last year his customer base has increased considerably because of the quality of his fabric (pagnes). To meet the demand, Mr. Antoine M. is requesting a loan to cope with his customers’ demand.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

Mr Antoine M. est agé de 29 ans marié et père de 2 enfants . Il est propriétaire d'une boutique de vente de tissu imprimé à Adéta depuis 6 ans. Il s'approvisionne à Lomé en gros et revend en détail dans sa boutique. Depuis plus d'un an sa clientèle a considérablement augmenté à cause de la qualité de ses pagnes.Pour satisfaire la demande Mr Antoine M. sollicite le présent emprunt pour faire face à la demande de sa clientèle.

loans.use: Purchase of 60 pieces of traditional fabric in Lomé to be sold retail in Adéta

loans.name: Dziodzom

texts.fr:
Mr. Dziodzome Nyassogbé is 30 and a married father of one child. For nearly two years, Dziodzome has been buying used clothing at the market in Lomé and then reselling it in all of the neighboring villages on market day. This business earns him enough income to pay his family’s expenses and to send his child to school.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Mr Dziodzome Nyassogbé est agé de 30ans marié et père d'un enfant. Depuis bientôt deux ans Dziodzome achète de la fripperie au marché de Lomé . De retour il vend ses fripperies dans tous les villages environnants les jours de marché. Cette activité lui procure des ressources pour financer les charges de sa fammille et scolariser son enfant

loans.use: Purchase of used clothing to resell in the village markets in Kpalimé

loans.name: Mazama

texts.fr:
Mr. Mazama T. is 35 and a married father of four children. For over seven years, Mr. T. has earned his living by purchasing ripe palm trees, cutting them down, extracting the juice and turning it into alcohol. He has built an alcohol production factory, where he works. He sells the liquor in neighboring towns and villages. With the income he earns from this business, he pays his family’s expenses. He has recently found a palm tree field with 200 palm trees that he would like to purchase with this loan.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Monsieur Mazama T. est agé de 35 ans marié et père de 4 enfants. Depuis plus de 7 ans l'activité génératrice de revenu de Mr Mazama T. est d'acheter les palmiers murs, les abattre , extraire le jus et le transformer en alcool Il a crée une usine de production de l'alcool dans laquelle il travail. Il revend la liqueur dans les villages et villes environnant. Avec le revenu de cette activité il finance les charges de famille. Actuellement il a trouvé un champ de palmerai de 200 palimier qu'il voudrait acheter avec le présent emprunt

loans.use: Purchase of 200 palm trees to extract alcohol

loans.name: Afefa

texts.fr:
Mrs. Aféfa T. is 32 and a married mother of three children. She buys boxes of candy wholesale at the market in Lomé and then sells them retail at the Assahoun market and at the markets in the neighboring villages on market day. The income she earns from this business allows her to help pay her family’s expenses. She would like to increase her supplies, especially in time for the holidays, so that she can satisfy her customers’ demand.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Mme Aféfa T. est agée de 32 ans ,mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle achète en gros les paquets de bonbons au marché de Lomé et les revend en détail au marché d'Assahoun et dans les marchés des villages d'Assahoun le jour des marchés. Cette activité lui procure des revenus et elle contribue aux charges de fonctionnement de la famille. Elle désire augmenter son étallage surtout en cette période de fête afin de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle

loans.use: Purchase of 25 boxes of candy in Lomé to resell them in Assahoun

loans.name: Patricia

texts.es:
Patricia lives in the region of San Martín in the province and district of Lamas. Her business is located at 209 Jr. 2 de mayo. She sells dresses, shoes, perfume, and toys. With the aim of improving the economic situation of her family, and thanks to the support of her mother and sister and her own effort, she has managed to grow her business considerably. When she started it, she sold her products at a small table that her mother lent her, and now she sells varied merchandise of excellent quality that she displays in cases and on counters.

With this loan of 2,500 nuevos soles, which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy varied merchandise of excellent quality like dresses, shoes, toys, and cosmetics at wholesale prices, which she will offer to her clients in Lamas. Patricia is 32-years-old, and she lives with her mother and her young daughter, who is the motor of her life. She wishes to give her everything that she couldn't have in her childhood. Thanks to her perseverance and dedication, she has managed to secure many loyal clients. She would like to someday have a boutique with a lot of variety.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Patricia vive en la región de San Martín, provincia de Lamas, distrito de Lamas. Su negocio está ubicado en Jr. 2 de mayo Nº 209 y se dedica a la venta de vestidos, calzados, perfumería y juguetería. Con la finalidad de mejorar la situación económica de la familia y gracias al apoyo de su madre, hermana y al esfuerzo propio ha logrado que el negocio crezca considerablemente, ya que cuando se inició comenzó vendiendo sobre una pequeña mesa que le prestó su mamá y actualmente vende mercadería variada y de excelente calidad la cual la exhibe en sus vitrinas y andamios.

Con el préstamo de S/.2,500.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará mercadería variada y de excelente calidad como vestidos, calzados, juguetes y cosméticos al por mayor para ofrecer a sus clientes de la localidad de Lamas. La señora Patricia tiene 32 años, vive con su mamá y su menor hija, quien es el motor de su vida y desea brindarle todo lo que ella no pudo tener en su infancia. Gracias a su perseverancia y dedicación, logró fidelizar a mucha clientela. Le gustaría llegar a tener una boutique con mucha variedad.

loans.use: Purchase of varied merchandise (dresses, shoes, toys, cosmetics, etc.)

loans.name: Petronila Segunda

texts.es:
Petronila Segunda it’s a member of El Gran Pajaten a local community bank. She lives in the San Martin Region, in the Province Mariscal Caceres, Juanji District. Her business is located en Jr. Bolivar #277 and she owns a convenience store.

Thanks to the support of her husband and children she managed to grow her business. Before she only had a small convenience store, now she has more products than before and also rents videos, she has a solid client base.

With the loan of 1,000 Soles ($350 USD), which she will repay in 4 months, she will purchase canned fish, boxes of crackers, dozens of soap boxes, oil and DVD’s, among other products to increment her line of products.

Petronila it’s always dedicate to get better, she is 51 years old but she never gives up, she keeps fighting for a better life

Translated from Spanish by Christian Jimenez, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Petronila Segunda pertenece al banco comunal El Gran Pajaten, vive en la región San Martín, provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui, su negocio está ubicado en Jr. Bolívar Nº 277 y se dedica a la venta de productos de primera necesidad.

Gracias al apoyo de su esposo y de sus hijos logró incrementar un negocio. Anteriormente tenía un negocio pequeño y hoy en día cuenta con mayor número de productos, también alquila videos y tiene gran clientela.

Con el préstamo de S/.1,000.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará conservas de pescado, galletas en cajas, detergentes en docenas, aceites en litros, y DVD, entre otros para incrementar los productos ya existentes.

La señora Petronila siempre está con ganas de seguir a delante, tiene 51 años y a pesar de la edad que tiene nunca se da por vencida, sigue luchando para que tenga una vejez feliz.

loans.use: Purchase Inventory for Store

loans.name: Ama

texts.fr:
Mrs. Ama S. (“she who cares for the child”) is 37 and a married mother of five children. She has been managing a supply of charcoal at the town market for six years. She buys the charcoal in Badou, a town 70 km from Kpalimé, and then resells it in Kpalimé. This business earns her enough income to pay for most of her family’s expenses, especially since her husband earns a meager and irregular income.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Mme Ama S. (celle qui tient l'enfant) est agée de 37 ans, mariée et mère 5 enfants. Elle gère un stock de charbon au marché de la ville depuis 6 ans. Elle achète le charbon à Badou , localité située à 70 Klm de Kpalimé et revend ce charbon en ville à Kpalimé. Cette activité lui procure des revenus qu'elle utilise pour le financement de la plus part des charges familiales surtout que son mari a des revenus dérisoires et irréguliers

loans.use: Purchase of 50 bags of charcoal in Badou to resell them in Kpalimé

loans.name: Béatrice

texts.fr:
Mrs. Béatrice Toudeno is 42 and a mother of six children. Her husband has been unemployed since 2004. Mrs. Toudeno owns a sewing supplies store in the main market in Kpalimé. She buys the supplies wholesale in Lomé and then sells them retail in her store. This business earns her enough income to completely pay for her family’s expenses and her children’s education. With this loan, she would like to build up her inventory so she can satisfy her constantly growing, loyal customer base.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Mme Béatrice Toudeno est agée de 42 ans, mère de 6 enfants. Son mari est au chômage depuis 2004. Mme Béatrice T. est propriétaire d'une boutique de vente de fourniture de coututre sise au grand marché de kpalimé. Elle s'approvisionne à Lomé en gros et revend en détail dans sa boutique . Cette activité lui procure le revenu qui finance à 100% les charges de famille et de l'éducation de ses enfants. Par le présent emprunt elle désire augmenter le stock pour satisfaire sa clientèle qui lui est fidèle et en pleine croissance.

loans.use: Purchase of sewing supplies in Lomé for retail sale in Kpalimé

loans.name: Fesuiaina

texts.en: Fesuiaina was born and grew up in rural area but married a man from and moved to Alaoa Apia. She is 25 years old and has one son.  Trying to learn the ways of town living is hard but Fesuiaina has to do something to earn money for her child and her family. She is applying for her first loan to buy seeds and other stuff for her vegetable garden.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her vegetable farm

loans.name: Folole

texts.en: Folole is the mother of eight children and is 55 years old. Folole’s business is sewing, which she does at her own house at Tanugamanono. Most people come to her house and order whatever pattern and size they want. She is very good in sewing clothes especially Puletasi, aloha and kids wear.  She requests a loan to  buy a sewing machine, scissors and other sewing supplies.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine, scissors and other sewing supplies

loans.name: Israel

texts.es:
Mr. Israel F. lives in his own home in a residential area of Lourdes in the department (region) of La Libertad in El Salvador. He has 2 children; his life partner helps him in the business. He has worked with Apoyo Integral for 3 years now. His loans have all been well invested; with the investments his business has grown over the years. His progress to date has been outstanding. He'll use this loan to buy more of his best-selling products, along with the products his clients demand most in this season, such as beverages, basic grains, oils, and different styles of clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

El señor Israel F., vive en casa propia en una colonia de Lourdes departamento de la Libertad en El Salvador, tiene dos hijos y su compañera de vida que le ayuda en el negocio. Actualmente tiene tres años de trabajar con Integral y sus créditos todos han sido bien invertidos ya que su negocio a crecido con el paso de los años , hasta la fecha se ve su mejoría de manera notable, este financiamiento lo ocupara para poder comprar los productos que mas se venden y que en esta temporada solicitan sus clientes tales como bebida los granos básicos y aceites y ropa de diferentes estilos

loans.use: Buy some of his best-selling products: beverages, basic grains, oil, clothing and other items consumed daily by the people of his area

location.town: Col.Las Moritas segunda calle Poniente numero 14,L

loans.name: Julia Rainelda

texts.es:
Señora L.'s business is located in her home in Colonia las Moras. This business is the family's primary source of income.

She needs financing to be able to make improvements to her house. This will benefit 5 people, including her. She considers this investment a necessity since it the rain gets insiD. her house during the winter due to the poor condition of her roof. The loan will cover all of her necessities to repair the house, and will allow her to cook even in rainy conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Su negocio esta ubicado en su mismo lugar D. habitación, Colonia las Moras, este negocio es D. donD. obtiene la mayor fuente D. sus ingresos para su familia .

Su financiamiento lo necesita para poder mejorar su vivienda D. la cual se benefician 5 personas incluyendo a la solicitante, la señora considera que esta inversión es una necesidad ya que durante el invierno se llueve en ese sector debido a el mal estado D. las laminas actuales, el préstamo solicitado cubriría todas sus necesidades y mejoraría su vivienda , además D. permitirle el poder cocinar a pesar D. la lluvia.

loans.use: Buy construction materials: roofing, cement, sand and gravel. She needs to repair the hallway where she prepares her food products since it will rain in winter.

location.town: Calle Principal Pasaje Iraeta Las Moras, Lourdes,

payments.comment: This entrepreneur has prepaid the balance on her loan. She is very grateful for your loan and appreciates your support.

loans.name: Ermelinda

texts.es:
Mrs. T. has been making and selling tortillas for 10 years. Through her efforts, she has demonstrated that she can improve her financial situation. She started out with a small tortilla stand, and then, with her profits, she was able to set up a tortilla shop that she runs from home. Her hardwork has permitted her to raise her two children and proviD. for their schooling. With this loan, she will buy corn so that she can sell some while reserving the other portion for the fast-approaching winter. She also wants to take advantage the current market value of corn.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra T. tiene 10 años D. dedicarse a la venta D. las tortillas considera que con los esfuerzos se pueD. salir adelante y a si lo ha demostrado, ya que inicio con la venta D. tortillas y actualmente a puesto una tienda en su misma casa D. la ganancia que le a ido quedando D. ella. Su esfuerzo a contribuido para poder sacar adelante a dos D. sus hijos y seguir dándole el estudio a los demás con el financiamiento ella comprara Maíz para poder vender y tener D. reserva para el invierno que pronto se acerca, y aprovechar los precio actuales en el mercado.

loans.use: Purchase of corn for distribution and production of tortillas

location.town: Final Colonia Jerusalen Contiguo a Ferrocaril  cal

payments.comment: This entrepreneur prepaid the balance on her loan. She is very grateful for your loan and appreciates your support.

loans.name: Maria Marta

texts.es:
Maria Marta López V. belongs to the communal bank El Gran Pajaten, she lives in the San Martín region, Mariscal Cáceres province, Juanjui district. Her business is located at Jr. Cahuide Nº 386 where she sells basic necessities and groceries.

Thanks to the support of her husband and children she has been able to grow her business and today finds herself with a well-stocked business, and she also sells cacao and orange seeds which increases her income.

With the 600.00 Soles loan which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy crates of eggs, dozens of bottles of oil, sacks of rice and sugar, among other things, and with the rest she will use in the cacao and orange crops.

Maria is very talkative and happy, she is 57 years old, she lives with her husband and grandchildren, she works with enthusiasm and pride of the projects she has been able to complete and make reality.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Maria Marta López V. pertenece al banco comunal El Gran Pajaten, vive en la región San Martín, provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui. Su negocio está ubicado en el Jr. Cahuide Nº 386 y se dedica a la venta de productos de primera necesidad.

Gracias al apoyo de su esposo y de sus hijos logró incrementar su negocio, actualmente cuenta con un negocio bien surtido y también cuenta con sembríos de cacao y naranja que incrementan su ingreso económico.

Con el préstamo de S/.600.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará huevos en jabas, aceites en botellas por docenas, arroz y azúcar en sacos, entre otros y con lo que le resta lo utilizará en la cosecha de cacao y naranjas.

La señora Maria es muy comunicativa y alegre, tiene 57 años, vive con su esposo y sus nietos, trabaja con entusiasmo y esmero para lograr que sus proyectos se hagan realidad.

loans.use: Purchase groceries (eggs, oil, rice, sugar, etc.)

loans.name: Miri

texts.es:
Miri lives in the San Martín region of the Lamas province and district, she belongs to the Communal Bank Mujeres del 2000, her stall where she sells juice and bread is located in the Number 1 market in the city of Lamas.

She is a single mother, and from a young age, together with her mother, she made and sold bread. Inspired by a friend about the possibility of having her own business located in a strategic place in the market, she decided to start a business selling fresh fruit juices and extracts and snacks such as candy, cakes, tamales, etc., that she sells daily starting in the early morning hours.

With the 3000.00 Soles loan, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will buy a new blender, servicing pieces and glasses appropriate for the selling of juice, plus she will buy sacks of flour and sugar, kilos of butter, and other ingredients to make bread.

Miri is 37 years old, mother of two children for whom she works tirelessly and dreams of seeing them become professionals in their own right. Her short term goal is remodel her home to make it more comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Miri vive en la región de San Martín, provincia y distrito de Lamas, pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres del 2000, su puesto de venta de jugos y panes se ubica en los interiores del mercado N° 1 de la bella cuidad de Lamas.

Es madre soltera que desde muy pequeña, junto a su madre, se dedica a la elaboración y venta de panes. Motivada por un familiar ante la posibilidad de contar con un negocio propio ubicado en un lugar estratégico del mercado de abastos decide emprender el negocio de la venta de jugos y extracto de frutas y refrigerios como dulces, kekes, juanes, tamalitos, entre otros, que ha diario es ofrecido desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana.

Con el préstamo de S/. 3,000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará una nueva licuadora, vajillas como vasos apropiados para la venta de jugos, además comprará harina y azúcar en sacos, manteca en kilos y otros insumos para la elaboración de los panes.

Miri tiene 37 años, es madre de dos niños por quienes trabaja incansablemente y sueña con verlos profesionales. Su neta más cercana es remodelar su casa para tener mayor comodidad.

loans.use: Purchase a blender, serving pieces including glasses; baking supplies such as sugar, flour, etc.

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es:
Juan Carlos has owned his business for 10 years. Previously he was an employee but he decided to launch his own microbusiness. He started out with very little but with every passing day he went on developing his business. Currently he needs financing to be able to buy more vitamins and feed for his chickens and to expand the site where he raises his chickens. This business is his sole source of income; it sustains his family and pays for the education of his 3 small children.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Su negocio lo tiene desde hace diez años, comenta el señor M. que antes era empleado pero con el tiempo decidió poner su microempresa ; y inicio con poco pero con el paso de los días la a ido desarrollando actualmente necesita el financiamiento para poder comprar mas concentrado vitaminas y ampliar el local en el cual tiene la granja, ya que esto es su fuente de ingreso y es lo que le da el sustento a su familia y educación a sus hijos que son 3 pequeños en la actualidad.

loans.use: Juan Carlos needs the loan in order to be able to buy chickens to fatten, as well as vitamins and food concentrate for the chickens. This will allow him to increase his production and slaughter of chickens.

location.town: Col. Hermosa Provincia Calle Principal  Numero 1 L

loans.name: Ana Luz

texts.es:
Mrs. C. has had her business, which she runs from her home, for 8 years. This business allows her to obtain supplementary income, thus permitting her to help her husband and provide for her family. Her family is made up of four members—one is a dependent child.

This is the second loan she has requested. She used the first one for the business, and she is requesting this loan in order to buy the products that are most popular during this season. This investment will allow her to generate more income, and she would not lose the opportunity to offer better service.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora C. tiene siete años de tener su negocio, la ubicación de este es en su hogar, lo que le permite obtener otros ingresos para ayudar a su esposo y no descuidar a su familia. Su grupo familiar lo componen cuatro personas una depende directamente de la solicitante.

Este es el segundo crédito que maneja con integral el primero lo utilizo para negocio y esta solicitando este para surtir con algunos productos que se venden mas en esta temporada esta inversión le generaría mas ingresos y no perdería la oportunidad de prestar un mejor servicio.

loans.use: Purchase of soft drinks, grains, dairy products, meat, sausages, and apparel

location.town: Col.san Carlos 2 poligono 34 numero 3 Ciudad Arce

payments.comment: Ana Luz was able to pay ahead of schedule. She thanks you for your loan.

loans.name: Sagrado Corazón De Jesús Group

texts.es:
Mrs. Dionicia P., founder of the group, got in conctact with her neighboring colleagues, who quickly demonstrated interest in the “Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras” program. All members belong to the “Cabañas de Caacupé” company, and the name of their group is “Sacrado Corazón de Jesús” (Sacred Heart of Jesus). We can observe 14 of the 16 members in this photo (two are not shown because they were not able to attend the meeting due to their prior work commitments ).

The majority of the committee members work in the cultivation and sales of plants and flowers for a living; other members own mini markets that sell flour, milk, sugar, fruits, and vegetables, while still other members operate fast-food, candy, and soft drink stands.

All members of the group receive an average of $150.00 USD, which they each use in order to improve their aforementioned business affairs.

The committee has carried out several activities with the aim of helping their community, such as the renovation of sidewalks in their neighborhood, festivals that benefit the sick, and other charitable activities.

They are requesting a loan in order to purchase more merchandise for their different businesses, such as seeds, fertilizer, meat, rice, flour, canned goods, soft drinks, fruits, and vegetables, among other things.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

El grupo se conformo através de la señora Dionicia P., quien fue la que inicio los contactos con sus colegas vecinas quienes rápidamente demostraron interés por el programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras. Todas son de la compañía Cabañas de Caacupé y el nombre del grupo es Sagrado Corazón de Jesús; en la foto podemos apreciar a 14 de las 16 integrantes (dos no figuran en la foto ya que por motivos laborales no pudieron acudir a la reunión.)

La mayoría de las integrantes de este comité se dedican a la producción y ventas de plantas y flores; otras poseen despensas donde venden artículos de primera necesidad como harina, leche, azúcar, frutas, verduras y otras poseen kioscos donde venden golosinas, gaseosas, comidas rápidas, entre otros.

Todas las integrantes reciben un promedio de G. 660.000 ($ 150 aproximadamente) cada una y lo invierten para la mejora de sus actividades descriptas mas arriba.

El comité como grupo ya llevan realizando varias actividades con la finalidad de ayudar a su comunidad, como ser el mejoramiento de las veredas de su barrio, festivales a beneficios de personas enfermas, entre otras actividades benéficas.

Solicitan el crédito para invertirlos en la compra de mercaderías para los diferentes negocios, entre otras cosas podemos citar semillas, abono, carne, arroz, harina, productos enlatados, gaseosas, frutas, vegetales, etc.

loans.use: Purchase of seed, fertilizer, rice, flour, canned goods, soft drinks, fruits, vegetables, etc.

loans.name: Faala

texts.en: Faala is a 46 year old married mother of five kids presently residing in Malie. She is a new member of Malie Borrowing Centre and would like a loan to support her 3 acre taro plantation.  She rarely asks her family living overseas for a financial support because she takes 2-3 bags of taro to the market twice a week and she earns more than $200-$300 WST ($80-120 USD) a month.  She would like a loan to buy fertilizers, weed killers, spades and other supplies for her plantation

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, weed killers, spades and other supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Baldovina's Group

texts.es:
In the city of Quiindy, 20 km. away from the city of Carapeguá, a group of women of scarce resources heard of the Mujeres Emprendedoras (Entrepreneurial Women) committee program developed by Fundación Paraguaya and decided to form a group looking for support in developing their family income through microcredit.

These individuals grew thanks to this program and are currently in its fifth cycle, having now more than 14 months in the program and succeeding by being excellent clients since the beginning. Four clients are missing in the attached photograph because they could not attend the gathering where it was taken due to travel involving the sale of their products.

The majority of the members are artisans who create hanging hammocks, blankets and ao poi embroidery, one of the most traditional and recognized techniques in Paraguay. Others are fashion designers, peddlers and makers of pigskin footballs.

They are requesting this loan to buy the different kinds of materials that they each need to perform their activities, among them we can list: waxed, wool and cotton threads; needles; fabrics; buttons; zippers; leather; etc.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

En la ciudad de Quiindy, distante a 20 km. de la ciudad de Carapeguá, un grupo de señoras de escasos recursos se enteraron del programa de comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras que desarrolla la Fundación Paraguaya y decidieron formar su grupo buscando un apoyo para fomentar a través del crédito, sus ingresos familiares

Estas personas crecieron gracias a este programa y actualmente se encuentran dentro del quinto ciclo del mismo, teniendo ya 14 de meses dentro del programa y destacándose por ser clientes excelentes desde sus inicios. Faltan 4 clientes en la fotografía adjunta debido a que ellas por motivos de viajes laborales de venta de sus productos no pudieron asistir a la reunión en la que se tomó la fotografía.

La mayoría de las integrantes son artesanas que se dedican a la confección de hamacas colgantes, colchas, y bordados de ao poí que es una de las técnicas más reconocidas y típicas del Paraguay. Otras son modistas, vendedoras ambulantes y confeccionistas de pelotas de football.

Solicitan el crédito para comprar los distintos tipos de materiales que cada una necesita para desarrollar su actividad, entre ellos podemos citar: hilos encerados, hilos de lana y algodón, agujas, telas, botones, cierres, cuero, etc.

loans.use: Purchase waxed, wool and cotton threads; needles; fabrics; buttons; zippers; leather; etc.

loans.name: Matalena

texts.en: Matalena is 27 years old and joined SPBD Program when she heard stories from other women. She bought vegetable seeds from the Agriculture shop and started tending a garden. After three months, she started taking her vegetables to the market and she earned money to support her family.  She is requesting a loan to buy more supplies for her vegetable farm.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her vegetable farm

loans.name: Kolopa

texts.en: Kolopa is a 20 year old married mother from Malie J3 centre. She is one of a newest members applying for a loan.  She sells ice cakes (popsicles in a bag) from her own house.  She sells 100-150 ice cakes a day, which cost 50 sene (20 cents) each and she earns about $100-150 WST ($40-60 USD) a day. Her husband has a taro plantation but that does not stop her from trying to look for another business to support her new family.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her ice cake business

loans.name: Ilaisa

texts.en: Ilaisa is a 42 year old mother of 6 children.  She is a very strong woman who didn't give up when her husband left her and kids two years ago. She is now living with her mother and two brothers who do the farming for the whole family. She is now applying for her third loan to expand the taro plantation and to help out with her family remittances.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Faia

texts.en: Faia is a 55 year old married mother.  She happily  give supports to her husband by working their taro plantation  six days of the week. She hardly ever asks her family living overseas for a financial support because she takes 3-4 bags of taro to the market twice a week and earns more than $300 WST ($120 USD) a month. She requests a loan to keep taking her children to school and to extend her 4 acre taro plantation.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Señora Victoria lives in the Mariscal Caceres province, Juanjui district, San Martin department. She is dedicated to sell groceries, clothes, plastic articles, and ice creams. Her business is located within her home in a suitable place for her sales. She has been in this business for 4 years. During that time she became a member of the "El Tiempo es Oro" (Time is gold) Community Bank. She came up with the idea of having her own business because she had the need of supporting her household and be useful. At the present time, she has a varied business and is also working with her youngest daughter who helps her with the administration of it and together they are making the business grow day by day

With the 2,000 soles (Peruvian currency) loan, which she will pay back in 6 months, she will buy goods to supply her business like 2 sacks of rice, 2 sacks of sugar (each sack is 50 kg), 2 packets of oil, 2 boxes of soap, detergent packets, one sack of potatoes and one of onions, some clothing, and others. She will be able to supply her business and serve it with the same kindness, happiness, and sense of responsibility that characterizes her day by day relations with her loyal customers.

Señora Victoria is 69 years old. She has seven children which she is still in charge of two of them. She lives with her husband which is three years older and a grandson whcih she cares for everyday. She shows us that there are no age limits if you want to move forward only you have to work with dedication and perseverance.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Victoria vive en la provincia D. Mariscal Cáceres, distrito D. Juanjui, departamento D. San Martín. Se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes, ropa, artículos D. plástico y helados, su negocio está ubicado en su casa en un local adecuado para sus ventas. Se dedica al negocio desD. hace 04 años, tiempo en el que ingreso al Banco Comunal “El Tiempo es Oro”. La idea del negocio fue propia, sentía la necesidad D. apoyar en el hogar y ser útil. Actualmente cuenta con un negocio variado y está trabajando con su menor hija, quien la apoya en la administración del mismo y juntas están haciendo que el negocio crezca día a día. Con el préstamo D. S/.2,000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará artículos para abastecer el negocio como dos sacos D. arroz, dos sacos D. azúcar (cada saco D. 50kg), dos paquetes D. aceite, dos cajas D. jabón, paquetes D. detergente, un saco D. papa y cebolla, algunas prendas D. vestir y otros, para así poder abastecer y atender con la misma amabilidad, alegría y responsabilidad que la caracteriza a sus clientes que día a día le muestran su fidelidad. La señora Victoria tiene 69 años, siete hijos D. los cuales dos están aún a su cargo. Vive con su esposo tres años mayor que ella y un nieto por lo que tiene que velar día a día y nos demuestra que para salir adelante no hay límites D. edad sólo hay que trabajar con dedicación y perseverancia. .

loans.use: Buying groceries to sell (rice, sugar, oil, soap, etc)

loans.name: Veronika

texts.en: Veronika is a 52 year old mother with seven children. Her canteen is the most important thing in her daily work, she earns 100-200 WST ($40-80 USD) a week from selling pork cakes.  She uses that money to support her school children and help out with her family remittances.  She requests a loan to buy supplies and ingredients for her pork bun business.

loans.use: To buy supplies and ingredients for her pork bun business

loans.name: Mote

texts.en: Mote is a 48 year old mother of 2 and was selected as chief of the centre. She is one of the oldest members of the Samusu V centre. Her first loan was used to buy material for her 4 acres taro plantation, she in now applying for another loan to extend the floor of her house and to pay her kids' school fees.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
Señora Victoria lives in the region of San Martín in the province of Mariscal Cáceres in the district of Juanjui. She makes a living by selling fruit at a market in the region. Victoria was widowed when her children were still small, but she had to keep going, and this is why, at the advice of her oldest daughter, she decided to become a member of the Communal Bank "Sarita Colonia." Thanks to Manuela Ramos, she was able to start a business.

With this loan of 1,000 nuevos soles, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy more fruit, like a sack of oranges, 4 bunches of plantains, 100 lemons, 100 avocados, and 40 boxes of papaya. She will also buy a sack of potatoes and a sack of onions.

Victoria is 52-years-old and has 5 children, 4 of whom are independent, and 1 she still cares for. She works hard to give the latter a better future. Among her plans is to have a location where she can start a grocery business to combine with her business of selling fruit.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Victoria vive en la región San Martín, provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui. Se dedica a la venta de frutas en el mercado Nº 02 de la zona. La señora Victoria enviudó cuando sus hijos eran aún pequeños por lo que tenía que salir adelante, es así que por el consejo de su hija mayor decide ingresar al Banco Comunal “Sarita Colonia”, gracias a Manuela Ramos ha podido emprender un negocio.

Con el préstamo de S/.1000.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará más frutas como un saco de naranjas, cuatro racimos de plátano, un ciento de limón, un ciento de palta, cuarenta cajas de papaya y también comprará un saco de papa y un saco de cebolla.

La señora Victoria tiene 52 años y cinco hijos, cuatro ya son independientes y uno está a su cargo y es por quien trabaja y por quien se esmera en salir adelante y brindarle un futuro mejor. Dentro de sus planes está el contar con un local donde poner un negocio de venta de abarrotes y combinarlo con la venta de frutas.

loans.use: Purchase of fruits (oranges, plantains, papaya, etc.)

loans.name: Muava

texts.en: Muava is a mother of 3 from the big island of Savaii and is married to a business man from Matautu Falealili. She joined the program in 2005 when she needed help for her business. She is now applying for another loan to help buying more inventory for her shop and to pay her children school fees.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Serita

texts.en: Serita is a 44 year old mother.  She is the kind of woman who wakes up early but goes to bed late late.  Her business is making and selling pancakes in her own village.  She makes 150-200 WST ($60-80 USD) a day. Her first loan used to help out with her business and her family remittances.  She is applying for another loan to fix the floor of the house that she uses for the business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her pancakes business

loans.name: Juliana

texts.es:
Mrs. Juliana S. R. lives in the Juanji district of Mariscal Cáceres, San Martín. Mrs. Juliana’s business is located in the Pomarrosas market, and she dedicates herself to selling fruit. The idea for the business came from the need to get her family ahead and to support her husband, who was in poor health. She decided to join the communal bank “Sarita Colonia” where, through Manuela Ramos, they were given the opportunity to believe in her and help her to start up her business. She is very thankful for this opportunity.

With this loan for $275, which she will repay in four months, she will buy fruit, including two sacks of oranges, two bunches of plantains, two hundred avocados, one hundred lemons, two cases of papaya, and more. Additionally, she has a small business selling sodas out of her home. She also counts on field several hectares large where she grows fruit and corn; she has invested some of her money here to help with the harvest.

Mrs. Juliana is 63 years old, and had eight grown children. She lives with her husband, and together they share their lives in good times and in bad.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Juliana S. R. vive en el departamento de San Martín, provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui. La señora Juliana tiene ubicado su negocio en el mercado denominado “Pomarrosas” y se dedica a la venta de frutas. La idea del negocio ante la necesidad de sacar adelante a la familia y apoyar a su esposo que estaba delicado de salud decide ingresar al banco Comunal “Sarita Colonia” lugar donde a través de Manuela Ramos le dieron la oportunidad de creer en ella y permitirle poder emprender un negocio por el que está muy agradecida.

Con el préstamo de S/.800.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará más frutas como dos sacos de naranja, dos racimos de plátanos, dos cientos de paltas, un ciento de limón, dos cajas de papaya y otros, además tiene un pequeño negocio de ventas de bebidas gaseosas en su propia casa, también cuenta con una chacra de varias hectáreas en el que está sembrando frutas y maíz en el cual también ha invertido parte del dinero para la cosecha de los productos.

La señora Juliana tiene 63 años, ocho hijos, todos independientes, vive con su esposo quien es su compañía y juntos están trabajando y compartiendo sus vidas en las buenas y en las malas.

loans.use: Purchase of fruits - orange, plantain, papaya, etc

loans.name: Noriko

texts.en: Noriko is a 32-year-old mother of six. Her business is running a flea market stall of handicrafts at the Savalalo market. She also sells in front of her house. She makes $100.00-150.00 WST ($40-60 USD) a day from selling handicrafts and she uses her earnings to help support her family.

loans.use: To restock her flea market stall

loans.name: Fale

texts.en: Fale is 45 years of age and has 5 children. She is one of the members who started Malie J3 centre two years ago. Her first, second and third loan was used to buy chemicals for her three acre taro plantation quite far from her house. She goes to the market twice a week and she makes $200.00-300.00 WST ($80-120 USD). She is applying for another loan to expand her taro plantation and to help out with her family remittances.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Faalaniga

texts.en: Faalaniga is 58 years of age and a mother of six children. She always supports her husband by working their taro plantation six days a week. She hardly ask her family living overseas for any financial support because she  takes 3-4 bags of taro to the market twice a week and earns more than $300.00-$400.00 WST ($120-160.00 USD) a month. She is applying for another loan from SPBD Program in order to keep taking her children to school and to extend her 4 acre taro plantation.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: María Immacula

texts.en:
Immacula is a 33-year-old woman that recently seperated from her husband.  She is bravely raising her two daughters by herself.   The children both attend her school.

Immacula is the manager of a school she founded three years ago for the children of her community.  Currently, more than 200 children go to her school.  As a visionary manager, Immacula plans to computerize the school in a few years.  She wants to install electronic blackboards, a computer room for the teachers as well as one for the pupils.

In the meantime, Imacula needs to resolve the school's present issues.  She is requesting funds to buy new chairs for the pupils and to repair some desks.  Immacula says that with God’s help and a lot of effort she will achieve her goals.

loans.use: To purchase new chairs and repair desks at a new school.

loans.name: Malia

texts.en: Malia is a new member to SPBD. She is 45-years-old, and recently quit her job because she wanted to work from home where she can look after her five children. She makes more than $100 WST ($40 USD) a week from selling pancakes, and she uses the money to support her family and kids.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her pancake business

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
Mrs. Lucia lives in the Juanjui district of Mariscal Cáceres, San Martín. She devotes herself to selling food both out of her home and out of a small stand. She launched her business thanks to a friend who gave her the idea and invited her to the communal bank “El Tiempo Es Oro” (Time is Money). Thanks to a loan received through Manuela Ramos, she has been able to contribute to the household expenses, supporting her husband.

With this loan for $675, which will be repaid in six months, she will buy goods for the kitchen, including rice, sacks of sugar, boxes of oil, onions, dried potatoes, and other bulk goods so that she can serve her lodgers and guests that visit her day after day. Her husband, who dedicates himself to buying and selling wood in a business whose profits and responsibilities they share, will use the remainder of the loan. Currently, they own a small house that they were able to purchase thanks to the income generated by their businesses.

Mrs. Lucia is 36 years old, and has three children and a husband that she works with everyday to bring their children a solid education that will help them care for themselves later on. Among her plans are the improvement of her home and the expansion of her sales stand so she can bring her customers better service.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Lucia, vive en la región San Martín, provincia D. Mariscal Cáceres, distrito D. Juanjui. Se dedica la venta D. comida, el mismo que se encuentra ubicado en su casa en un pequeño local. Emprendió un negocio gracias a una amiga que le dio la idea y la invitó al Banco Comunal “el Tiempo es Oro” y gracias al préstamo recibido por Manuela Ramos ha podido contribuir y apoyar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar.

Con el préstamo D. S/.2,000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará artículos para la cocina como arroz, azúcar en sacos, aceite en cajas, cebolla, papa sacos y otros en cantidades grandes para atender a sus pensionistas y comensales que la visitan día a día, otra parte del préstamo lo trabajará su esposo quien se dedica a la compra y venta D. madera, negocio en la que juntos comparten las ganancias y responsabilidades. Actualmente ya tienen una casita el cual han podido comprar gracias a los ingresos que les generan los negocios D. ambos.

La señora Lucía tiene 36 años, tres hijos y un esposo con quien trabaja día a día para brindarle a sus hijos una educación sólida y que les permita defenderse más adelante. Dentro D. sus planes está el acondicionar mejor su casa y ampliar su local D. venta D. comida para así brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for cooking - rice, sugar, oil, onion, etc. Purchase of wood for second business.

loans.name: Maricela

texts.es:
Mrs. Maricela lives in the Juanjui district of Mariscal Cáceres, San Martín. She dedicates herself to selling kebabs and all other types of grilled meat products. Her business is based out of her home. She decided to enter into a business with the intention of supporting her husband with the household expenses, but she didn’t have enough money to get started. Thanks to an invitation she received, she joined the communal bank “San Martín de Porres,” in which Manuela Ramos loaned her the money she needed to get her business started. With this loan for $525, which she will pay in four months, she will buy stock for her everyday sales, including chicken, beef, pork, several kilos of giblets, and more.

Currently she is working with her husband, who devotes himself to selling plantains in bulk to guaranteed customers in various markets in the area. They take on this business in the morning, and in the afternoon they devote themselves to selling grilled meats.

Mrs. Maricela is 36 years old and lives with her husband, who is her rock, and together they fight to get their children ahead in life. Among her plans are the refurbishment of a location hear their home where they can expand and improve their meat sales, and so bring better services to the customers who always come see them.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Maricela vive en la región San Martín, provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui. Se dedica a la venta de anticuchos, juanes, tacacho y todo lo relacionado a la venta de parrillas. Su negocio está ubicado en su domicilio. Decidió incursionar en un negocio con la intención de apoyar a su esposo en los gastos del hogar, pero no contaba con el capital necesario para iniciarlo, es así que gracias a una invitación que recibió decidió ingresar al Banco Comunal “San Martín de Porres”, en el que Manuela Ramos le prestó el capital necesario para poner en marcha el negocio. Con el préstamo de S/.1,500.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará los insumos para su venta de todos los días como carne de pollo, res y cerdo, menudencias en kilos y otros. Actualmente está trabajando con su esposo quien se dedica a la venta de plátanos en grandes cantidades los que son vendidos en los mercados de la zona donde ya tienen clientes asegurados. Este negocio lo realizan por la mañana y por las tardes se dedica a la venta de sus asados en parrilla. La señora Maricela tiene 36 años y vive con su esposo, quien es su punto de apoyo y con quien lucha por sacar adelante a sus tres hijos. Dentro de sus planes está el acondicionar un local dentro de su casa para ampliar y ubicar mejor sus venta de parrillas y brindar así un mejor servicio a sus clientes quienes siempre la visitan.

loans.use: Purchase of sales stock - beef, chicken, pork.

loans.name: Kuña Katupyry Group

texts.es:
The “Kuña Katupyry” group was formed by several neighbors in the Las Garzas neighborhood of San Antonio. Ever since its start, trust and unity directed the group, and today, “Kuña Katupyry” is one of the most solid committees in the Fundación Paraguaya

The members of the committee are both workers and mothers. Many members are not present in the photograph taken here, as they are participating in an important assembly that was called by the neighborhood council that they are active in.

All the members have their own activities that they earn money from. Among these are: fashion designing, fast food sales, school cafeterias, mini-pharmacies, small grocery stores, crafts, bookstores, clothing sales, and lingerie sales.

The loan will be used to buy various goods, such as needles, thread, embroidery goods, and paints, in the case of the artisans, while the vendors will use their credit to buy articles for sale, including bread, milk, rice, caramels, pastries, clothing, medicine, and so on.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

El Comité “Kuña Katupyry” se formó a partir de la unión de varias vecinas del barrio Las Garzas de la ciudad de San Antonio; desde un principio, primó en el comité la confianza y la solidaridad y hasta hoy día, “kuña Katupyry”, es uno de los comités más sólidos de la Fundación Parguaya.

Las integrantes del comité son madres y trabajadoras, por lo que las une ambas cosas. En la fotografía tomada, no se encuentran gran parte de las integrantes, quienes en ese momento estaban participando de una asamblea muy importante, convocada por la comisión vecinal del barrio la cual ellas son participes aditivas.

Todas las integrantes tienen sus actividades propias con las que hacen trabajar su capital; las diversas actividades son: modista, venta de comidas rápidas, cantinas escolares, venta de medicamentos (mini farmacias), despensas, venta de artesanías, librerías, venta de ropas y lencerías.

El crédito será utilizado para la compra de diferentes artículos como hilos, telas, agujas para bordar, pinturas; en el caso de las artesanas, mientras que las comerciantes (despensa, vendedores ambulantes, farmacias, etc.) utilizaron su crédito para la compra de artículos para la venta, tales como leche, panes, arroz, caramelos, pastas, ropas, medicamentos, etc.

loans.use: Basic materials for making crafts / Stock for making and selling merchandise.

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es:
Gregoria lives in the region of San Martín in the province of Mariscal Cáceres in the district of Juanjui. She sells food at the port in the region as well as at her house. She also sells plantains and firewood. She has always liked to work and needed a loan to start a small business, thanks to the invitation to join the Communal Bank "El Tiempo es Oro" (Time is Gold). Thanks to the loan she received from Manuela Ramos, she has been able to contribute to her home and help her husband.

With this loan of 800 nuevos soles, which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy items for the kitchen such as rice, sugar, oil, red and white meat, potatoes, and noodles. She will also buy half a load of firewood, which she will sell in thirds, three bunches of plantains, and other items. Gregoria has three people in her home who are retired and who she takes care of after she comes home from selling her food at the port of Amberes.

Gregoria is 61-years-old, and she has five independent children. She lives with her husband who has shared her life for 40 years and who lives with her sorrows, joys, and pains. Both plan to save a little money so they can enjoy a peaceful old age.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Gregoria vive en la región San Martín, provincia D. Mariscal Cáceres, distrito D. Juanjui. La señora Gregoria se dedica a la venta D. comida en el puerto D. la zona y en su casa, además venD. plátanos y leña. Siempre le ha gustado trabajar y necesitaba un préstamo para emprender un pequeño negocio, gracias a la invitación para ingresar al Banco Comunal “El Tiempo es Oro” y al préstamo recibido por Manuela Ramos ha podido contribuir y apoyar a su esposo en el hogar.

Con el préstamo D. S/.800.00, el cual pagará en 06 meses, comprará artículos para la cocina como arroz, azúcar en kilos, aceite en botellas, carnes rojas y blancas, papas y fideos en kilos, también comprará media carga D. leña D. los cuales venderá en tercios, también comprará diez racimos D. plátanos y otros. La señora Gregoria cuenta con tres personas que reciben pensión en su casa a los que atienD. después D. regresar D. realizar su venta en el puerto Amberes.

La señora Gregoria tiene 61 años, cinco hijos independientes y vive con su esposo con quien comparte su vida desD. hace 40 años y con quien vive sus penas, alegrías y dolores, ambos piensan ahorrar un poco y poder pasar una vejez tranquila.

loans.use: Purchase of materials for her kitchen (rice, sugar, oil, red meat, etc.)

loans.name: María Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is a single mother of a two year old boy.  She sells silver-plated jewelery by catalog to the women of her community.   Every weekend she goes to Santo Domingo, the capital, to get the goods that her customers ordered during the week.  After two years she has a well established clientele.

Cristina expects in a few years to have her an own location where she can run her business.  With her loan she will buy more jewelery and some women’s blouses to add to her selection and increase her sales.  Cristina hopes she will increase her income so that she can better care for her unique son.

loans.use: Purchase jewelery and other goods to add to a small business.

loans.name: Tuaoloa

texts.en: The school field is the place where Tuaoloa spends most of her time from Monday to Friday. She is a 32 year old mother of  three children. Her canteen is the most important thing in her daily work. She earns $100.00-$200.00 WST ($40-80 USD) a week from selling popcorn and she uses that money to support her school children and her family remittances.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her popcorn business

loans.name: Amanda

texts.es:
Mrs. Amanda belongs to the interim group “Jerusalén,” and lives in the Tarapoto Region of San Martín region. She runs her business at a stand in the Progreso Market near her home, and her main activity is baking bread. Thanks to the support of Manuela Ramos, as well as her husband and children, Amanda has been able to expand her business.

The loan she receives through Manuela Ramos will be used by buy stock that she needs for making bread; this will allow her to cover the needs of her household and children. With this loan for $175, which she will repay in four months, she will buy flour, sacks of sugar and cans of butter. Mrs. Amanda is 54 years old and lives with her husband and their five children.

She is grateful for the opportunity that Manuala Ramos offers, and looks forward to it helping her improve the infrastructure of her business (both shop and oven) that will help her serve more customers.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Amanda pertenece al Grupo Mientras Tanto “Jerusalén”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia de San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto, su domicilio está ubicado en el Pasaje Jerusalén Nº 139 del PPJJ 9 de Abril y su negocio funciona en un puesto del Mercado Progreso a la altura de la Cdra. 10 del Jr. Progreso del pueblo joven 9 de Abril. Su actividad económica es la Producción de Pan. Es una mujer que gracias al apoyo de Manuela Ramos ha logrado incrementar su negocio con el apoyo de su esposo e hijos, el préstamo de Manuela Ramos lo utiliza para comprar los insumos que necesita para elaborar el pan, esto le permite cubrir tanto las necesidades de su hogar como la de sus hijos. Con el préstamo de S/. 500.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, compró harina y azúcar en sacos y manteca en latas. La señora Amanda tiene 54 años y vive con su esposo y sus cinco hijos, agradece la oportunidad que le otorga Manuela Ramos ya que más adelante le va a permitir incrementar la infraestructura de su negocio (local y horno) y por consiguiente podrá abastecer a más clientes.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for the bakery (flour, sugar, butter)

loans.name: Anamelba

texts.es:
Anamelba, who is a member of the communal bank "La Primavera" (The Spring), lives at Asentamiento Humano La Primavera MZ "A" Lt 01 in the province and district of Moyobamba in San Martín. She has a stand in the Ayamaman Market where she sells used clothing. Many times she mends garments to be able to sell them. She decided to start a business because she needed to generate her own income to be able to give her children a good education. She is a very happy, enterprising, and optimistic person, and this helps her have good clients.

This loan of 1,000 nuevos soles, which she will repay in 6 months, will be used to buy used clothing in bundles to make the most of the celebrations at the end of the year, so she can have a well-supplied business and satisfy her clients' tastes.

Anamelba is 43-years-old, and her husband helps her with her business. He stays at the stand in the mornings, while she is there in the afternoons. This is so she can do her housework and also mend garments. She is happy with her accomplishments: she has a loyal clientele, and her goal is to continue with this business to make it even better.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Anamelba, socia del banco comunal La Primavera, vive en el Asentamiento Humano La Primavera MZ “A” Lt 01 de la provincia y distrito de Moyobamba, departamento de San Martín. Anamelba tiene un puesto en el mercado Ayaymaman en donde vende ropa usada, ella es quien muchas veces los arregla para ponerlo a la venta. Decidió iniciar en un negocio porque tenía la necesidad de generar sus propios ingresos para poder darles una buena educación a sus hijos. Es una persona muy alegre, emprendedora y optimista y eso le ayuda para tener buenos clientes.

El préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará ropa usada en fardos para aprovechar las fiestas de fin de año para tener bien surtido su negocio y satisfacer los gustos de sus clientes.

Tiene 43 años y dos hijos, su esposo le apoya en el negocio, él se queda en el puesto en la mañana y ella por las tardes para que ella pueda atender las labores domésticas y también arreglar las prendas para poder venderlas. Está contenta por sus logros obtenidos, tiene su clientela segura y su meta es continuar con este negocio implementarlo mejor.

loans.use: Purchase of used clothing

loans.name: Sala

texts.en: Sala is a mother of 3 and is 41 years of age. She started the Levili Toefuataina centre. Her business is a flea market stall selling handicrafts and Samoan food just in front of her house. She earns more than $100.00- $200.00 WST ($40-80 USD) a week. Her husband works as one of the security guards in town but Sala never relies on his pay for her family remittances.

loans.use: To restock her flea market stall

loans.name: Sophie

texts.en: Sophie is 43 years of age and a mother of 4 children.  She always provides support to her husband by working on their taro plantation six days a week. She rarely asks her family living overseas for any financial support because she  takes 3-4 bags of taro to the market twice a week and earns more than $300.00-$400.00 WST (120-160.00USD) a month. She is applying for another loan from SPBD program to continue taking her children to school and to extend her 4 acre taro plantation.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Lotoi

texts.en: Lotoi is a widowed mother of 66 years of age. She is overage to get any loan from the program but she is fit and healthy plus she received help from her two sons. She is applying for a second loan just to extend and to help out with her family remittances.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Luaipou

texts.en: Luaipou is a 35 year old mother of  4 children from the Nuusiatia village. Her first loan was used to buy supplies for her taro plantation. She is now applying for another loan to fix the wall of her house and to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation and for home improvement

loans.name: Roxanna Patricia

texts.en:
Roxanna is in her late twenties, and she is a single mother of two children.   Her son and daughter both attend school.  Roxanna runs a very small store that she recently started. She sells an assortment of perfumes, shampoos and other beauty products.

The entrepreneur is working very hard to make her business known in the community and to increase her clientele.  She is requesting a loan to increase the inventory for her store.  She wishes to continue to satisfy her customers’ demands and increase her income.  Roxanna wants to provide a comfortable lifestyle for her two children.

loans.use: To replenish a small store in order to satisfy her customers´ needs.

loans.name: Lusia

texts.en: Lusia never stopped herself from looking for a business to support her family. She is fifty four years old and a  married mother of 8 children. Her business is a small shop just in front of her house. She earns $300.00-$400.00 WST ($120-160 USD) a day and that’s where she earned money for her family and her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Anita

texts.es:
Anita is a partner of the Banco Comunal “La Amistad”, located in the province and district of Moyobamba, department of San Martin. She sells different varieties of candy, the same that is offered in the principle schools in her area, as well as in the main plaza.

It was her sister-in-law who gave her the idea to start a business and who taught her how to manage it. She started it with a loan received from the community bank, which was a great help because it permitted her to supply and diversify the products that she sells, which are popular with children.

With a loan of S. 500.00, which she will repay in four months, she will buy a larger quantity of chocolate, cookie and waffle packets, gum, “chisito,” potato chips, caramels, “frugos” by the dozen and mineral water by the dozen.

Anita is 36 years old and is very happy. She likes what she does a lot, above all, the daily contact with her varied customers. Along with her husband, her six children always support her and her wish to develop as a woman and as a small entrepreneur. She wishes to have a small store in her own home.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Anita es socia del Banco Comunal “La Amistad”, ubicado en la provincia y distrito de Moyobamba, departamento de San Martín. Se dedica a la venta de golosinas en sus diferente variedades, los mismos que ofrece en las principales escuelas y colegios de la localidad, así como en la plaza principal. Fue su cuñada quien le dio la idea de poner un negocio y le enseñó su manejo, iniciándose con el préstamo recibido del banco comunal, el mismo que es de gran ayuda porque le permite surtir y variar los productos que vende y que son requeridos mayormente por los niños. Con el préstamo de S/. 500.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará mayor cantidad de chocolates, galletas y waffle en paquetes, chicles por cajas, chisitos, papitas fritas por tiras y caramelos en bolsas, frugos en docenas, asimismo agua mineral en docenas. Anita con sus 36 años se muestra muy contenta, le gusta mucho lo que hace sobre todo el contacto diario que tiene con su variada clientela, junto a su esposo y a sus seis hijos que siempre la apoyan desea desarrollarse cada día más como mujer y como pequeña empresaria con el deseo de tener una bodega de venta de abarrotes en su propia casa.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise (chocolates, cookies, waffles, etc.)

loans.name: Nafanua

texts.en: Nafanua is 55 years of age from Fagalii center and lives together with her husband and two kids. Her business is selling ice cakes (popsicles in a bag). She sells her ice cakes from her house. She earns about $100.00-150.00 WST ($40-60 USD) from ice cakes which is her only source of income for her family and her children.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her ice cakes business

loans.name: Otila

texts.en: Otila is a young married mother of twenty five years of age residing at Lotofaga village. She is a strong woman that happily provides support to her husband for their plantation. She was employed by one of the company's in town but she resigned because she earns more money from selling taro. She sells 3-4 bags of taro to the market and she makes $200.00-$300.00 WST ($80-120 USD) each trip.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: María Soledad

texts.en:
Soledad is a very young entrepreneur that struggles to make a living.  A couple of months ago, she started a beauty salon with a friend’s help.  She runs the salon in a small, rented location.
Soledad needs funds to buy some materials.  With her loan she will buy a hair dryer, a used chair hair dryer and some hair brushes. 
Given this loan, the entrepreneur will able to support her university education in the capital.

loans.use: To purchase some materials for a small beauty salon.

loans.name: Faauuga

texts.en: Faauuga is a married mother of two children, 21 years of age and presently resides in Malie village. Her business is a taro plantation that is quite far from the house. She is one of the members that had a very good project check throughout the year. She sells 3-4 bags of taro to the market twice a week and she earns $200.00-$300.00 WST ($80-120 USD).

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Mutia

texts.en: Mutia is a 55-year-old married mother of 5 kids. Two of her children have moved overseas but the rest are still in Samoa. Mutia used to regularly rely on remittances from her overseas children until she joined the Program last year. Since then, she has started a taro plantation and started making her own money from selling taro to the market and fellow villagers.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her Taro Plantation

loans.name: Celestina

texts.es:
Mrs. Celestine belongs to the communal bank “La Marginal II”, she resides in the San Martin Region, province of San Martin, district of La Banda de Shilcayo. Her home and business are located on the main road of Fernando Belaúnde Terry (Route South) Km 3.5 and she dedicates herself to the production of Almidón (yucca flour) for wholesale.

Her husband and children help with the business and she also employs three other people. With the Manuela Ramos loans she’s been able to increase production as there was high demand for her product but lack of capital.

With the loan for $525.00, which she’ll pay back in 4 months, she’ll buy yucca in quantities of 50 kilos from the farms of her suppliers; she’ll also rent lands to plant yucca in order to supply all her clients and containers to process the product.

Mrs. Celesting is 39 years old and has 6 children, 4 of which live with her. She feels satisfied with the work she does and by expanding her business, feels good about being able to offer other women like her employment. Her wish is to see them also become successful business women.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Celestina pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Marginal II”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia de San Martín, distrito de La Banda de Shilcayo. Su domicilio y negocio están ubicados en la Carretera Fernando Belaúnde Terry (Marginal Sur) Km. 3.5 y se dedica a la producción de Almidón (harina de yuca) al por mayor.

Tiene el apoyo de su esposo, los hijos y asimismo tiene la posibilidad de dar empleo a tres personas más. Con el apoyo de los préstamos de Manuela Ramos ha podido ampliar su mercado ya que tenía demanda pero por falta de capital no podía atenderlos.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,500.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará yuca en quintales (50 kilos) en las chacras de sus proveedores, asimismo alquiló terrenos para la siembra de la yuca para abastecer a toda su clientela y envases (bandejas) para el proceso de este producto.

La señora Celestina tiene 39 años de edad, seis hijos de los cuales cuatro viven con ella. En la actualidad se siente satisfecha con el trabajo que realiza y al incrementar su negocio le satisface poder dar trabajo a otras mujeres como ella y su deseo es que ellas también sean comerciantes exitosas.

loans.use: To buy yucca and rent lands for planting.  To purchase containers.

location.town: La Banda de Shilcayo - San Martín

loans.name: Miriama

texts.en: Leaving school at a young age did not stop Miriama from trying her best to start a business. She is a married woman with 3 kids from Vaiala Apia and married to a man from Tiavea. Her business is a Taro Plantation. She joined the Program early this year when she needed help for her business. She is able to get $60-80 USD from selling bags of taro to the people living in town, at the Fugalei market.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her Taro Plantation

loans.name: Leusitai

texts.en: Leusitai is a married mother of six children from the village of Vailoa Aleipata. Her business is a taro plantation that is worked on by her husband and two sons. Her last loan was used to buy supplies for her plantation. She is applying for this loan in order to do the same thing, as well as to keep her children in school, and to support her family.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her vegetable farm and for family expenses

loans.name: Faga

texts.en: Faga is a married mother of 7 from the village of Vaipuna. She operates a sewing business, and she has recently joined SPBD’s loan program in order to receive financial assistance for her business. She spends most of her time in her sewing room, and she hopes that she can make more money to support her family and to help with her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies

loans.name: Moega

texts.en: Moega is a 49-year-old mother from the Vavau village. She has two children and she is one of the old members of the centre. Her first loan she used to buy materials for her taro plantation. She is now applying for another loan to fix the wall of her house and to help out with her plantation.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her plantation and for home improvements

loans.name: Pele

texts.en: Pele joined SPBD to receive financial assistance to help her run her business, but it has also given her a chance to get together with other ladies of her community. Her husband died while her kids were very young, and she is raising 2 boys and 3 girls. She is sad for her loss, but her success has provided inspiration for women, to not to be too dependent on their husbands. Pele’s operates her sewing business 6 days a week, and she makes $40-60 USD She uses the money for her children’s school fees and to support her family.

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies

loans.name: Coni

texts.es:
