Coni belongs to the Mientras Tanto group “Mas que Vencedoras” (more than winners), lives in the San Martín region, provence of San Martín, in the Tarapoto district. Her home and business are located at Jr. Túpac Amaru Nº 533 in the Joven 9 de Abril village. She sells groceries retail.

Coni is a women that, with the support of Manuela Ramos, has increased the capital with which she started her business and so she uses all other loans that she receives from Manuela to continue to expand her business to match her customer’s demand.

With this loan that she will repay in 4 months, she will buy rice, sugar (in sacks), milk in boxes, eggs in cartons and other products such as candies that she sells daily in the store.

Coni is 24 years old, a single mother and lives with her only daughter for whom she works hard to be able to succeed and supply her daughter with what she needs and raise her well. She would like to thank Manuela Ramos for the opportunity that they are giving her, which helped her to make the decision to become independent of her parents and enter the world of business.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Coni pertenece al Grupo Mientras Tanto “Mas que Vencedoras”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia de San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto, su domicilio y su negocio están ubicados en el Jr. Túpac Amaru Nº 533 del pueblo joven 9 de Abril. Se dedica a la venta de abarrotes al por menor.

Es una mujer que con el apoyo de Manuela Ramos ha aumentado el capital con el que inició su negocio y de esa manera los demás préstamos que recibe de Manuela le sirven para ir incrementando el negocio de acuerdo a la demanda de sus clientes.

Con este préstamo que pagará en 4 meses, comprará arroz, azúcar (en sacos), leche en cajas, huevos en javas y otros productos como golosinas que diariamente tienen movimiento en el negocio.

La señora Coni tiene 24 años, es madre soltera, vive con su única hija por quien toma fuerzas para seguir adelante para suplir sus necesidades y darle buena educación. Agradece a Manuela Ramos por la oportunidad que le brinda y ello le ayudó a tomar la decisión de independizarse de los padres y entrar en el mundo de los negocios.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries (rice, sugar, milk, eggs, etc.)

loans.name: Taaloga

texts.en: Taaloga is a 35-year-old married woman. She is from Levili Village, and is currently a member of Levili Toefuataina centre. Her business is elei (a traditional Samoan fabric). The printing is done by her and her husband at her own house. She sells 10-15 lavalava at $8 USD each to the people of her village and delivered to the nearby shops in town.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her elei printing business

loans.name: Altagracia

texts.en:
Altagracia is 47 years old and she has four grown up daughters.  They go to the university, and one of them works in Santo Domingo, the capital.  Altagracia owns a small cafeteria which she started five years ago.  She prepares food within her house early in the morning and she has a stall near a bus stop where people can enjoy her delicious dishes.

Altagracia would like to have a location where people can easily get the food.  She thinks her own location would offer services in better hygienic conditions.  She wants to execute those plans in a few years.

With her loan, Altagracia will purchase more disposable plastic plates, spoons and folks to serve the food.  She’ll also get raw materials to continue doing her business.  With additional income, Altagracia will help better support her children’s studies.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for her food preparation business.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en: Elena is a 27-year-old married woman who is trying to support her family. She recently joined SPBD’s loan program to recieve financial assistance for her family’s banana plantation. She plans to buy supplies to improve her business, and make it sustainable.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Mesepa

texts.en: Mesepa is one of an old member of the Levili center. She is 29, and presently residing at Levili village. Her business is a flea market, selling vegetables and general goods just in front of her house. Her main customers are passing traffic and village people. She used to earn about $80-120 USD a week, and that is the only place she gets financial support for her family.

loans.use: To restock her flea market stall

loans.name: Faapisa

texts.en: Faapisa was born and grew up with her family in a rural area and married a man from Tuanai. She is 39, and has three sons. Trying to pick up the way of living in town is so hard, but Faapisa has to do something to get some money for her child and her family. She is applying for a second loan to buy seeds and other stuff for her vegetable garden.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Malae

texts.en: Malae is a mother of four. She is 45 years old from the village very far from town and married to a man from Ulumasinave. Her business is sewing and painting clothes and lavalava. Her last loan was used to buy a second-hand sewing machine. To improve her business was the reason she applied for another loan.

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies

loans.name: Alataua

texts.en: Alataua is a married mother of five children from the village of Ulutogia Aleipata. Her business is a vegetable garden. Her husband and two sons work on her garden too. Her last loan was used to buy supplies for her vegetable garden. She is applying for this loan in order to keep her children in school and to support her family.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her plantation and for family expenses

loans.name: Fipe

texts.en: Fipe is an older married mother of 6. She is now 62 years of age. Her business is a retail shop separate from her house, serving people of her village. She wakes up early each morning and goes to sleep late at night. She also has two children living overseas but hardly relies on them for a financial support. To enlarge her business was the reason she applied for another loan.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Yoselin

texts.en:
Yoselin is in her late twenties and she has three children, two of them girls.  They go to the public school in her community.  Yoselin runs a small beverage store that she opened one year ago.  People visit her store to get different kinds of beverages such as beer, whisky, wine, ron and energy drinks.  Currently she has a lot of loyal customers.  On the weekends, to give customers the incentive to purchase at her store, Yoselin offers specials from 10:00 pm to 2:00 am.

The entrepreneur is requesting a loan to purchase more beverages to supply her business.  During the holiday season people usually buy more drinks.  “ I have to get ready for this very moment”, she says.  Currently, the store is the principal source of income of Yoselin, and she wants to increase her income in order to improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: Increase inventory to face big demands from customers during the holidays.

loans.name: María Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena is a good example of an arduous woman, a loyal wife and a good mother.  Her husband and she have six children, four of them boys.  The children attend primary and secondary school in the small town.  Magdalena is the manager of the tailor´s shop that her husband runs in a small, rented location.  That activity is the principal source of income of the family.  They have been running the business for more than fifteen years and now the have a well established clientele.

Magdalena plans to hire a young boy to help her husband prepare the clothes.  Her husband wants to teach the sewing art to young people in the community.  They plan to start giving sewing classes next year at very low prices to these young people.  Magdalena thinks the teenagers need to develop those abilities to earn a living in nowadays.

Magdalena will invest her loan in the purchase of cloth, thread, oil for the sewing machines and other materials they need to  continue running the business.  They want to be able to maintain a comfortable lifestyle for the family.

loans.use: Purchase cloth, thread and other materials for a tailor´s shop.

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Lê Thị Yến is 47 years old, she is a TYM member since 1997. She started raising pigs with her loan. This helped improve her family living condition. In 2003, she and her husband decided to invest in a new business. So her husband took training classes in making aluminum window / door frames. Now they own a shop producing glass window & door in the town of Nỉ, it is well located near the highway # 3 axe. Their products are of high quality, the design is beautiful and the prices are competitive. For these reasons, they have attracted a lot of local customers as well as out of towners. They have 2 employees working in the shop, each earns 75 USD a month. Her family income is about 250 USD a month. Ms Yến is requesting a loan of 950 USD to buy aluminum  and food for her livestock.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Lê Thị Yến, 47 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 1997. Kinh tế gia đình chị phát triển nhờ vay vốn đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn gà. Năm 2003 chị bàn với chồng chuyển sang mô hình kinh tế mới, do vậy anh Thành, chồng chị, đã quyết định đi học nghề sản xuất khung nhôm cửa kính và đóng trần nhựa. Hiện gia đình chị đã có cửa hàng làm khung nhôm cửa kính tại phố Nỉ, trên trục đường giao thông quốc lộ 3. Sản phẩm khung nhôm, cửa kính của gia đình anh chị rất đa dạng, mẫu mã đẹp giá cả phải chăng nên đã thu hút rất đông khách hàng không những trong vùng và cả những khách hàng của các tỉnh bạn. Chị Yến đang thuê 2 công nhân làm việc tại cửa hàng và trả lương 75USD/người/tháng. Mức thu nhập hiện tại của gia đình: 250USD/tháng. Chị Yến đang làm đơn vay 950USD để mua nhôm, kính và thức ăn gia súc.

loans.use: Buy aluminum, glass and foodstuff for cattle

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Nguyễn Thị Lành is a TYM fund member since 1997. Her first loan was only 30 USD which was invested in pig & poultry raising. In later rounds she was able to obtain maximum loans. In 1999, she switched to retails, selling general goods. The business was good, her family financial condition had improved substantially. She was able to save a sizable amount of money. In 2007 Ms Lành was able to qualify for a special loan of 1200 USD. Combining this loan, her savings and loan from her family she and her husband decided to invest in a farming business. They now own a 5 acre farm: there are 2500 ducks, 55 chickens, 30 pigs, a fish pond (an area of 1 acre) and lots of fruit trees. They have 10 employees working on the farm, each one earns 45 usd/month. They also own a store selling cell phones and propane. The revenue from all their businesses is about 375 USD a month. Ms Lành is requesting a loan of 1200 USD which will be invested in her farm buying poultry feed and pig mash.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Lành tham gia quỹ năm 1997, chị vay vốn lần đầu 30USD đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn gà và làm hàng sáo. Các vòng tiếp theo chị đều vay mức cao. Năm 1999 chị chuyển sang làm hàng ăn và bán hàng tạp hoá, kinh tế của gia đình đã ngày càng phát triển hơn và chị đã tích luỹ được một số vốn. Năm 2007 chị Lành được vay vốn đặc biệt (1.200USD). Cùng với số vốn hiện có của gia đình và vay thêm của anh em họ hàng anh, chị Lành đã quyết định chuyển sang mô hình kinh tế trang trại với diện tích là 50sào. Hiện trang trại của anh chị có 2.500 con vịt, 500 con gà thịt, 30 con lợn, 12 sào ao thả cá và hàng trăm cây ăn quả. Trong trang trại luôn có 10 lao động làm thuê và anh chị trả lương cho họ là: 45USD/tháng/ người. Ngoài ra anh chị còn mở thêm cửa hàng bán điện thoại di động và bán ga để tạo thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Mức thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị Lành là 375USD/tháng. Chị đang làm đơn xin vay 1200USD để mua thức ăn cho đàn gia súc, gia cầm của mình.

loans.use: Buy foodstuff for cattle, mash for figs

loans.name: Choo

texts.en: Mrs. Choo C. T., 32, works on her rice paddy growing crops and vegetables and typically earns around $2/day in revenue. Her husband is a middleman buying and selling oxen, making around $3/day of profit. Mrs. Choo C. T. has three children. Two of them are students and another one is too young to attend school. She has humbly requested for a loan to purchase a hand tractor to help with the plowing of her farmland to grow more crops.

loans.use: To purchase a hand tractor to ease the plowing of her farmland

loans.name: Choy

texts.en: Mr. Choy S., 40, is married with four children. He works on his piece of land raising pigs, earning on average about $5.30/day in revenue. His wife is employed at a garment factory making around $2.3/day of income. Three of his children are enrolled in school and another one is employed in Phnom Penh city, giving  his family $50 per month. Additionally, Mr. Choy hopes to use this loan to purchase rice crops to stock in his inventory, waiting for the price to increase at which point he will sell them for a good profit.

loans.use: To purchase rice crops to stock in his inventory, waiting for the price to go up at which point he will sell them for a good profit.

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Mrs. Long S., 25, is a mother of one little kid and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is employed at a nearby garment factory, earning around $2/day, while her husband can typically earn about $2.50 per day from working as a laborer. Mrs. Long S. hopes to use this loan to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a motor-taxi, which enables him to generate much more than working as a laborer. ( Long S. and her husband are pictured with a motor-bike they plan to buy ).

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycel for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business.

payments.comment: Congratulation! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for interest helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Long Sotha and sustain their business. Your loan has made them different. We do hope that you will continue support the poor entrepreneurs in Cambodia through CREDIT MFI in the future. Best Regard, Vichet Ouch, Kiva Coordinator at CREDIT MFI, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en: Mrs. Chorn S., 45, is a mother of six children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband work together on their rice paddy growing rice crops, earning collectively around $3/day in revenue. Three of her children are currently employed at a garment factory and the rest of themare students. Mrs. Chorn S. hopes to use this loan to purchase more seeds and some farming tools for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more seeds and some farming tools for her business.

loans.name: Toaga

texts.en: Toaga is married to a farmer from the village of Saaga, very far from town. She has four children, three boys and one girl. Her husband has no job and that was the main reason she joined SPBD, to get a loan to support her 2-acre taro plantation, just 50 meters from her house. She sells 3-4 bags of taro twice a week and she gets $120-160 USD a week. She also does business with the Saaga Fou centre. She used to make a deposit of $40 USD every two weeks, just to support her business, family and for her childrens' school fees.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Taumaia

texts.en: Taumaia joined the SPBD Programme in 2004. She is the secretary of the centre. She says that  “Most of her family have all moved to New Zealand, except her, her husband, and four kids.”  Without relying on remittances from overseas she applied for her first loan, and used that money to buy chemicals, fertilizers, and other stuff for her taro plantation not far from her house. To enlarge the taro farming, she is now applying for another loan to support her plantation and to fix the floor of her house.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Pofa

texts.en: Pofa is a married mother with five children, one of them has a job in town, the rest are unemployed. Her business is a taro plantation. Before joining SPBD program in 2004, her family depended only on remittances from overseas (New Zealand and Australia), the reason she needed help from SPBD.  Her last loan was used to fixed the floor of her house and other stuff for her business. To maintain and to improve her business, she is now applying for another loan to buy more farming supplies and also to help out with her family remittances.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Lang

texts.en: Mrs. Lang T., 32, is a mother of two children and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works as a labourer making burnt brick, earning around $2/day, while her husband is now unemployed. One of her children is a student and another one is also unemployed. Mrs. Lang T. would like to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business, which would significantly help her and her family generate more income. She hopes the loan will assist in increasing her living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business.

loans.name: Mareta

texts.en: Mareta is a young married woman of Saaga Siumu, her business is a taro plantation not far from her backyard, owned by her husband. She joined the program in 2005 and she is now on her second loan. She used to sell 10-15 bags of taro at Fugalei Market and she gets $80-120 USD a week.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Mele

texts.en: Mele is a married woman with 4 kids, living in the village of Saaga Siumu. Her business is a Taro plantation run by her husband. She sells 2-3 bags of taro once a week at Fugalei market, and she gets $80-100 USD. Before joining the program, her family depends only on remittances from overseas. But when she joined SPBD in 2004, she experienced a big change. She can now pay her kids' school fees and a lot family purposes.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Lematea

texts.en: Leaving school at a young age does not stop Lematea from trying her best to start a business. She is a married woman with 3 kids from SaA., and married to a man from Salesatele. Her business is a Taro Plantation run by her husband. She just joined the Program in 2005 when she needed help for her business. She makes $60-80 USD from selling bags of taro to the people living in town, at the Fugalei market.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Faalataimoa

texts.en: Faalataimoa is affiliated with the Samusu V center. She is a married mother of 9 kids, andwas employed at one of the private pharmacys in Apia. She resigned because she had no one to look after her kids, and she can get more money from selling taro than the salary she got for one week. She takes 2-3 bags of taro once a week and she gets $100-120 USD, and she uses that money to support her family, especially taking her children to school.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Noela

texts.en: Noela is a married mother of 45. She has five children, two of them are girls and three are boys. She lives with the boys. The rest are living in New Zealand. She is a very helpful person, which is why her husband works hard. Her husband recognizes the support from his wife, not only for the good of her family but also for her childrens' school funds. She takes 2-3 bags of taro twice a week to the market and she gets $80-120 USD.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Folole

texts.en: Folole is 37 years old, from one of the villages in town, and married to a man from Samusu. She has 5 children. Her husband is a strong farmer, but she never stops thinking about a business for some extra money. She started her small shop just in front of her house last year, and she earns $120-160 USD a day.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Leua

texts.en: Leua is 55 years of age. She is married and has four children. She runs a taro plantation with her husband and one of her brothers. She sells three to four bags of taro in the new market at Fugalei and earns $200.00-300.00 WST ($80-120 USD) a week. She is now applying for her third loan to help out with her children's school fees and to fix the wall of her house.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Sua

texts.en: Sua is a widowed woman from Saaga Village. She is 64 years of age. She is one of the peole who started the Saaga centre of SPBD two years ago. She is also the chef for the centre. She and her two sons run a taro plantation. She used her first and second loans to buy supplies for her farm. She sells two to three bags of taro in the market twice a week. She earns $200.00-300.00 WST ($80-120 USD). Sua would like another loan to buy more supplies for her plantation.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Sua

texts.en: Sua is a widowed woman from Saaga village 64 years of age. She is the one who started Saaga centre two years ago, she is also the chief. Her business is taro plantation does by her two sons whom lived together with her. Her first, second loan were used to buy stuff for her business. She used to take 2-3 bags of taro to the twice a week and she gets $200.00-300.00 WST ($80-120 USD).

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Ofisa

texts.en: Ofisa is a young, married woman of 31 years. She is from Apia but she is married to a farmer from Poutasi. Her business is a four acre taro plantation not far from her home. Her first loan was used to buy supplies for plantation. She is now appyling for a second loan so she can pay some of her family's debts.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Amanda

texts.en:
Amanda was rarely a part of organizations or groups with many people, so joining the SPBD program was a big change for her. Even more of a change was when the Poutasi Centre chose her to be the secretary.

Amanda joined SPBD to help support her taro plantation. She is now applying for second loan to buy more supplies for her business and also to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Mekisa

texts.en: Mekisa is a married woman who is 32 years of age. She presently resides in Nofoalii village. She has four children, two boys and two girls. She and her husband run a fishing business. They sell their fish from the house and also deliver the fish to nearby villages. They earn about $200.00-300.00 WST ($80-120 USD) a week from selling fish. The business is the only source of income for the family. She would like a second loan to buy new fishing gear.

loans.use: To buy new fishing gear

loans.name: Tala

texts.en: Tala is a widowed woman of 67 years. She is a member of Papauta centre. She is one of the longest standing members at the Papauta centre. She runs a sewing business by herself from her own house. She sews three to four puletasi (traditional Samoan garments worn by women) a day. She earns about $200.00-250.00 WST ($80-100.00 USD) a week. She is applying for this loan so she can buy another sewing machine.

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies

loans.name: Gataiala

texts.en: Gataiala is a married woman from Lepale village. She is 54 years of age. She is one of the longest standing members of the SPBD centre. She and her two sons run a taro plantation. Her first and second loan were used to buy chemicals and tools for her plantation business. She sells two to three bags of taro twice a week and she gets $200.00-300.00 WST ($80-120 USD). She would like a third loan to buy farming supplies for her taro plantation.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Chung

texts.en: Mrs. Chung S., 37, is a labourer and lives with her husband who is now unemployed in a part of Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works as a labourer, earning only about $2.5/day. She has one child who is now at school. Mrs. Chung S. hopes to use this loan to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business to help her and her family generate more income.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Chung Srey has successfully paid back the Kiva loan early via CREDIT MFI. Thank you for helping to support Cambodian entrepreneurs. We hope that you will continue your support of CREDIT MFI.

Best regards,
Isadora Tang
Kiva Fellow
Cambodia

loans.name: Feagai

texts.en:
Though she left school at a young age, Feagai is tring to run a successful business. She is a married woman and has three children. They live in Vaiala Apia, though her husband is from Tufulel.

Feagai's husband runs a taro plantation. Feagai joined the SPBD in 2005 when she needed help with the plantation. They earn $150.00-$200.00 WST ($60-80 USD) from selling bags of taro at Fugalei market to the people living in town. She would like a second loan to buy more farming supplies for the taro plantation.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Vitolina

texts.en:
Vitolina is a married woman who is 47 years old. She is a member of the Saleaumua Center. She has seven children, three of whom are now living in New Zealand. The other four still live at home with her.

Vitolina and her husband have a taro plantation. They work six days of the week. She would like another loan to buy supplies for her plantation. She will use the money that she earns to support her family, especially her school age children.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Lotu

texts.en: “The more you work hard the more you get” is the saying that the single mother of three, Lotu F., adopts. She is 38 years of age and lives in Tuanai center with her parents and her children. Her business is selling ice cakes, which cost fifty cents each, and Samoan cocoa, which costs $5.00 WST ($2 USD) cooked and $3.00 WST ($1.20 USD) uncooked. She sells her goods from her house and also delivers them to the nearby villages. Lotu earns about $200.00-300.00 WST ($80-120 USD) from her business. This is the only source of income for her family. She would like a loan so she can purchase more supplies for her snacks business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her snacks business

loans.name: Sialai

texts.en: Sialai is a married mother who is 39 years of age. She resides in Leloto village. She is a strong woman who happily supports her husband's work at their plantation. She was employed at one of the supermarkets in town, but she resigned because she earns more money from selling the taro that she and her husband grow. They sell three to four bags of taro at the market and they earn about $200.00-$300.00 WST ($80-120 USD) twice a week.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Leilani

texts.en: Leaving school at young age is not good, especially for those who do not have jobs. Leilani left school when she was only 16 years of age. She is very talented. She makes prints and paints lava lava and puletasi (traditional Samoan garments). However, Leilani does not have enough mone to buy the fabrics and paints needs to run her business. She joined the SPBD program last week to get a loan to start her business of elei printing. She will use the money to help pay her family's needs.

loans.use: To buy paints and fabrics for her elei printing business

loans.name: Sua

texts.en: Sua is one of the longest standing members of the Faatoia C Center. She is 49 years of age and presently resides in Faatoia village. She has a flea market business; she sells vegetables and general goods just in front of her house. Her main customers are people passing by and the village people. She earns $200.00-$300.00 WST ($80-120) a week. The money she earns supports her entire family; they have no other income. Sua would like this loan to restock her flea market stall.

loans.use: To restock her flea market stall

loans.name: Temukisa

texts.en:
Temukisa is married and has eight children. The family currently lives in Levili Apia. She joined the program in 2005 when she needed help for her business. She sews four to five puletasi [Samoan garb worn by women] a day at a cost of $50.00 WST ($20 USD). She earns $300.00-$400.00 WST ($120-160 USD) a week.

Temukisa's first loan was used to buy a sewing machine. She would like a second loan so she can buy supplies to continue her business. She will use the money she earns to pay her children's school fees and to fix the floor in her house.

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies

loans.name: Natia

texts.en:
Natia is a married mother of four. She is 31 years of age and presently resides in Tufulele village. Her business is running a taro plantation, which is quite far from her house.

She is one of the members of the organization that had very good check-ins throughout the year. She sells three to four bags of taro in the market twice a week. She earns $200.00-$300.00 WST ($80-120 USD). She would like another loan to buy farming supplies for her plantation.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Tiloga

texts.en: Tiloga is a married mother of four children and is 29 years of age and currently a member of Faleasiu 6 centre. Her business is making chips and selling them from her own house and delivered to the nearby villages. She sells 100-200 chips which cost $1 WST (40 cents USD) each and she earns about $300.00-400 WST ($120-160) depending on the sales volume that day.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her chips business

loans.name: Talisami

texts.en: Forty five year old plantation owner Talisami, alongside with her husband, has struggled to keep their plantation alive.  To add to the stress, they have six children.  This current loan will go towards purchasing chemicals needed, as they are thinking of expanding their plantation.  It will also help purchase fencing wires and more taro tops to grow new produce. An honest living is what Talisami would like to achieve, as well as farming her land.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Shahana's Group

texts.en:
I am Shahana S., and Nasreen S. is my group member at a local microfinance institution, Asasah. I am married and a mother of five: two daughters and three sons. Three of my kids attend school, whereas the other two are small and are not of school-going age yet. I and my husband both are determined to educate our children so that they can find honorable jobs for themselves. 

I and my partner both work on a brick furnace and also raise goats and cows and sell their milk. Currently, I need to buy a few more goats for the business. Nasreen S. is my friend and neighbor; she also raises goats and requires a loan. I am really happy that I am able to help someone and get them a loan for their business. Both of us dream to be successful businesswomen and that our children will become professionals.

loans.use: Buy goats for the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Refurbish furniture for his bar and guest house

loans.name: Rubina's Group

texts.en:
I am Rubina J. and I was born in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. After my marriage, I had to move to a small town, Kot Radha Kishan, with my husband. I am a mother of four: three sons and one daughter. Currently, only two of my kids attend school. My husband raises cows and goats, and he sells goats when they grow to a suitable age and sells cow milk to our neighborhood clients. He needs to buy an additional cow for the business. 

I am a group leader of my group of four entrepreneurs. My group members have always displayed a high degree of cohesiveness among each other and have shown commitment toward group policies and procedures. I feel very happy to have a opportunity to help them. My group members are: Rubina K., who needs to buy goats for her business. Nermala R. needs a loan for her son’s mobile phone store. Koser H. also requires buying a few goats. Lastly, Naseem H. needs a loan to buy goats as well.

loans.use: Buy an additional cow for the business

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en: Nelly is married to a farmer from Malaela and she is 44 years of age and has seven children. Her business is a taro plantation and she sells her crops in front of her house and also takes them to the market twice a week. She earns about 250-300 Tala ($100-$120 US) which she uses to support her family and to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Tumema

texts.en: Tumema joined the SPBD Programme in 2004 and she is the chief of the centre mentioned above. Most of her family moved to New Zealand, except her, her husband and their four kids. Without relying on remittances from overseas she applied for a second loan to buy chemicals, fertilizers, and other items for her taro plantation not far from her house. To enlarge her taro farm, she is now applying for another loan to support her plantation and to fix the floor of her house.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increase his stock of bananas to open a new location

loans.name: Perise

texts.en: Perise is a married mother of five children, one of them has a job in town but the rest are all unemployed. Her business is taro plantation. Before joining the SPBD program in 2004, her family depended only on remittances from overseas (New Zealand and Australia). This was the reason she needed help from SPBD. Her last loan was used to fixed the floor of her house and other goods for her business. To maintain and to improve her business, she is now applying for another loan to buy more goods so she can serve and satisfy the needs of her customers everyday. Not only that, but she would also like to help out with her family remittances.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Perise

texts.en: Perise is a married mother of five children, one of them has a job in town but the rest are all unemployed. Her business is taro plantation. Before joining SPBD program in 2004, her family depend only remittances from overseas (New Zealand, Australia.), that was the reason she needed help from SPBD, her last loan was used to fixed the floor of her house and other stuff for her business. To maintain and to improve her business, she is now applying for another loan to buy more stuff for her business so she can serve and to satisfy needs of her customers everyday, not only that but also to help out with her family remittances.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her taro plantation

loans.name: Pene

texts.en: The school field is the place where Pene spends most of her time from Monday to Friday. She is a mother who is 55 years of age and has five children. Her canteen is the most important thing in her daily work. She earns $100.00-$200.00 WST ($40-80 USD) a week from selling banana salad and pancakes and she uses that money to support her school children and her family remittances.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her snacks business

loans.name: Maota

texts.en: Maota is 63 years of age and the mother of 7 children. She is the one that always gives support to her husband and two sons by operating their taro plantation six days a week. She hardly asks her family living overseas for financial support because she takes 3-4 bags of taro to the market twice a week and she earns more than $300.00-$400.00 ($120-160 USD) a month. To keep her children in school and to extend her 4 acre taro plantation is the reason she is applying for another loan from the SPBD Program.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Faamativa

texts.en:
Faamativa is married to a farmer from the village of Tafitoala, quite far from town. She has five children: four boys and one girl. Her husband has no job and that was the main reason she joined SPBD - to get a loan to support her two-acre taro plantation, just 30 meters from her house.

She sells 3-4 bags of taro twice a week and she earns $300.00- $400.00 WST ($120-160 USD) a week. She is also one of the best savers of the Tafitoala Centre; she usually makes a deposit of $50.00 WST ($20 USD) every week, to support her business, family, and for her children’s school fees.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Taufaanuu

texts.en: Taufaanuu joined SPBD Programme early this year. She said that most of her family has all moved to New Zealand, except her, her husband, and their five kids.  Without relying on remittances from overseas, she applied for a first loan and she used that money to buy chemicals, fertilizers, and other stuff for her taro plantation not far from her house. To enlarge the taro farming, she has now applied for another loan to support her plantation and to fix the floor of her house.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Thi Quy

texts.vi:
Ms Quý lives in the town of Chờ, Yên Phong, Bắc Ninh. She is a dynamic woman. She used to sell flowers and vegetables. Then she decided to open a street side restaurant selling "bánh cuốn" (steamed ravioli stuffed with pork & perfumed mushroom). Her husband is working in the restaurant with her. They're having a difficult time because their income is barely enough to cover their basic living expenses and putting their child in school. For this reason, they're applying for a loan to be invested in their restaurant thus raising their income in the long term. They are confident to be abL. to make weekly payment.

Translated by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Quý sống tại Thị trấn Chờ, Yên Phong, Bắc Ninh, là một người phụ nữ rất năng động. Trước đây, chị cũng làm nhiều nghề như buôn hoa quả , bán rau...Nhưng sau chị quyết định mở một tiệm bánh cuốn cho riêng mình.Cuộc sống khá khó khăn, chồng chị ở nhà phụ chị bán hàng.Nguồn thu nhập của anh, chị chỉ đủ nuôi con ăn học và sinh hoạt hằng ngày. Chính vì thế, anh chị muốn vay một khoản tiền nhỏ mở rộng cửa hàng và mua thêm nguyên liệu để tráng bánh. Anh chị thấy việc hoàn trả vốn theo tuần rất phù hợp với gia đình.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for "bánh cuốn"

loans.name: Petra

texts.en: Petra is a married woman of 27 years of age and is currently a member of Lalovaea centre. She is one of the older members who started Lalovaea centre. Her business is sewing, which she does by herself at her own house. She sews 3-4 puletasi (traditional Samoan woman garments) per day. She earns about $200.00-250.00 WST ($80-100 USD) a week. To buy another sewing machine is the reason she applied for another loan.

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies

loans.name: Taaitulagi Chung

texts.en: Taaitulagi is an old member of SPBD that supports her family through running her vegetable garden from the loan that she received from the SPBD Program. She is a young woman of 24 years of age and has five kids. She goes to the market once a week and she earns about $200.00-300.00 WST ($80-120 USD). Her first and second loan were use to buy stock for her vegetable garden, but to maintain and enlarge the garden is the reason she is applying for another loan. Also she plans to fix the floor of her house and to help out with her family remittances.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Vitolina

texts.en: Vitolina strongly supports the saying that “the more you plant and grow, the more you get.” She helps run a 6-acre taro plantation which is looked after by her husband and four laborers. Most of her family has moved overseas but she has no plans of joining them because she can get by with her taro plantation. She goes to the market twice a month where she’ll make $300.00-$400.00 ($120-160 USD) each trip. She also has a contract to sell taro in American Samoa once a month.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Gulnaz's Group

texts.en:
I am Gulnaz S.. I am married with five kids: three boys and two girls. All of my children are getting an education, as I feel it is necessary to become a good citizen and organize life in a good manner. Earlier I used to teach at a local school, but I do not teach anymore because I am the only one who is responsible for all the household chores. I live with my family in a small town, Kot Radha Kishan, in Paksitan. My husband is a daily wage laborer and constructs buildings, whereas I raise goats and sell them at reasonable profits. I want to buy few more goats for my business. 

I have few other members in my loan group. Abida P. requires a loan for her husband, who is a tailor and wants to start a proper shop of his. Mary S. needs a loan to pay for her ice-cream machine. Razia A. she wants to buy an additional cow for her business.  

I am the group leader of this group because I hope to use my leadership skills that I acquired while teaching at a school and to ensure that the group remains cohesive.

loans.use: Buy few more goats for the business

loans.name: Imeleta

texts.en: Imeleta is a 39-year-old mother of two. Her business is running a flea market, selling handicrafts in front of her house and at a stall at the Savalalo market. She makes $100.00-150.00 WST ($40-60 USD) a day from selling handicrafts and she uses her earnings to help support her family.

loans.use: To restock her flea market stall

loans.name: Arshad's Group

texts.en:
I am Arshad B. and I live with my family in Kot Radha Kishan, a small town in Pakistan. I have five children: two daughters and three sons. One of my kids is married, whereas the others are continuing with their studies. My husband works at Pakistan Railways for a meager income, and I sell milk from my house to supplement his income. Currently, I own five cows and now I want to buy an additional cow.

I have few others members in my loan group and we have together acquired a couple of loans earlier. All of my group members are hardworking entrepreneurs and play an important part to bring income to their houses. Sajida B. needs a loan for her husband’s grocery shop. Majeedan B. requires a loan to buy a cow, and lastly, Hanifan B. also wants to buy a cow with your loan.

loans.use: Buy an additional cow

loans.name: Thi Ngoc Thanh

texts.vi:
Ms Thanh is married and has one child. In the beginning, she and her husband had to work very hard to save money so they could open an internet cafe. Her husband works in sales (factory equipment) and he takes care of the computer's maintenance. Ms Thanh would like to obtain a loan to expand her internet cafe and pay for her child tuition fees. She would pay back the loan with the revenue from the internet cafe.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Thanh đã lập gia đình và có mọt người con. Lúc đầu, hai anh chị làm ăn vất vả dành dụm một ít tiền để mở được cửa hàng internet. Chồng chị bán thiết bị và bảo dưỡng máy tính. Chị muốn vay một khoản tiền nhỏ để mở rộng quy mô kinh doanh của mình và đóng tiền hoc cho con.Nguồn thu nhập của cửa hàng chí sẽ trích một phần để hoàn trả vốn theo tuần.

loans.use: Internet cafe

loans.name: Parween

texts.en: I am Parween B., resident of Lahore, a historical city known for its gardens.  I am a mother of three children, two girls and a boy.  My husband operates a steel scrap business and I stitch and embroider clothes on order. I need a loan of $250 for my husband to expand his business. We want to increase our income so that our children can continue with their education.

loans.use: Buy scrap objects in bulk

loans.name: Azra

texts.en: My name is Azra P., a resident of Lahore. I am mother of six children, aged between 10 to 18 years. I did a course of midwife ten years ago and opted it as a profession to earn my living. I need a loan of $500 to purchase medicines and furniture for my clinic where I practice. I intend to give a better future to my family, and I know it would materialize only when I am able to establish my business.

loans.use: Buy medicines for the clinic

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Nguyễn Thị Năm is 39 years old. She joined TYM in 1999. Her first loan was 30 USD which she invested in a clothing store and a food stand. All her subsequent loans were used to expand these 2 businesses. Her family financial situation had improved and she was able to save money. In 2004, with their savings and loans from family members, they have bought a property so they could move out and live in their own house. Today she has a restaurant serving the employees from the Yamaha factory nearby and her husband manages the clothing store in the town of Nỉ. Their family income is 375 USD a month. She's requesting a loan of 1200 USD to buy merchandise for their clothing store and products for her restaurant.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Năm, 39 tuổi, tham gia quỹ năm 1999. Lần đầu chị xin vay 30USD cùng với chồng đầu tư vào hàng may mặc và hàng ăn. Các vòng vốn sau chị đều vay mức cao để mở rộng cửa hàng. Kinh tế gia đình ngày càng phát triển và tích luỹ đựơc một số vốn. Năm 2004 với số tiền tích lũy được cộng với tiền vay của anh em trong gia đình, anh chị đã mua được một mảnh đất và ra ở riêng. Hiện chị bán hàng ăn cơm bình dân cho công nhân của công ty YAMAHA còn anh mở cửa hàng may quần áo tại phố Nỉ. Mức thu nhập bình quân: 375USD/tháng. Chị đang làm đơn xin vay 1200USD để mua thực phẩm và quần áo

loans.use: Buy products for her restaurant and merchandise for her clothing store.

loans.name: Mumtaz

texts.en: I am Mumtaz B., wife of Mr Faryad. My age is 35 years and I am a resident of Lahore. I and my husband want to start a business of selling bangles. I plan to sell bangles from my house to the women of my area, whereas my husband will sell bangles from his shop. We need $425 for this purpose. By doing this we would be able to meet our household expenses better, save something, and improve our living standard.

loans.use: Start a business selling bangles (bracelets)

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Nguyễn Thị Sỹ is 37 years old. She is a TYM fund member since 1996. Before joining TYM her family was living in poverty, it was not possible to borrow capital to invest in a business. So when TYM opened a branch in her village, she was the first person to join the fund. In her first year, she received a loan of 30 USD which was used to buy pigs. In subsequent loans, she was able to secure bigger loans. The loans were then divided in 2: half was used to buy breeding pigs & egg laying chickens, the other half to buy pigs & chickens for butchery. Beginning 2007, Ms Sỹ concentrates her effort on raising chickens for eggs. Right now she has 700 egg laying chickens. Selling the eggs brings in about 8 USD a day. This time she requests a loan of 1200 USD to buy chickens and feed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Sỹ, 37 tuổi, tham gia quỹ năm 1996. Trước khi vào quỹ gia đình chị rất nghèo, muốn vay vốn nhưng chẳng biết vay ở đâu. Khi Quỹ Tình Thương triển khai tại xã chị là người đầu tiên đăng ký tham gia. Năm thứ nhất chị được vay 30USD và sử dụng cho việc chăn nuôi lợn. Các vòng vốn tiếp theo chị đều vay mức cao một nửa dùng để chăn nuôi lợn, gà đẻ trứng, một nửa chị dùng để mua lợn, gà thịt về giết mổ phục vụ cho nhu cầu tiêu dùng của nhân dân trong vùng. Đầu năm 2007 với số lãi thu được chị Sỹ đã chuyển sang chăn nuôi gà đẻ trứng. Hiện gia đình có : 700 con gà đẻ trứng mỗi ngày cho thu nhập 8USD. Chị đang xin vay 1200USD mua gà giống và thức ăn cho đàn gà của mình

loans.use: Buy chickens and feed.

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en: I am Shamim Bibi and a mother of five children between 10 to 23 years. I live with my family in Lahore. My husband Nazir sells steel, tin and bronze scrap. I fix artificial gems and stones on shawls for someone for daily wages. I need a loan of $500 for my husband’s scrap business. It is difficult to meet our household expenses with our current limited income, and therefore we want to increase our income.

loans.use: Expand scrap business

loans.name: Rukhsana

texts.en: I am Rukhsana B. and a resident of Lahore. My husband, Ehsan Ali, runs a small restaurant. We have a son who is 18 years old. I make embroidered clothes, at my residence, for the past two years, to support my family. For my embroidery work, customers provide me the cloth, and the other materials used are my own. We need $350 to purchase a round table, chairs, cover and a television set for our restaurant. I am not facing any kind of problem yet , but I want to generate more income from the existing business of my husband.

loans.use: Buy furniture and tv for the resturant

loans.name: Shazia

texts.en: I am Shazia M. from Lahore. My husband, M. Ahmed, is a car washer and he also sells spare automobile parts. We have three children between 9 to15 years of age. I need a loan of $500 to purchase automobile spare parts in bulk for my husband’s business. Due to our low income in the past, we could not meet the household expenses, resulting in lot of quarrels amongst ourselves. I passed the time with lot of patience, and then I approached Asasah, a microfinance institution, and received a loan from them, and was able to make some improvement in our business. We hope to do even better with your loan.

loans.use: Expand spare parts business

loans.name: Abida

texts.en: My name is Abida and my husband’s name is G. M.. We are residents of Lahore. We have five children, ages between 8 to 16 years, and all of them are studying in schools. I live in a joint family with my father-in-law, mother-in-law and brother-in-law. My husband sells spare parts for big vehicles. I need a loan of $425 by which my husband will purchase spare parts such as rims, etc., for his business.

loans.use: Buy spare parts for the business

loans.name: Obaida

texts.en: I am Obaida B., wife of Mohammed Younus, resident of Lahore. We have two sons who are 8 and 10 years old. My husband sells fruit on his cart and I have been making embroidered clothes since last six years. I get cloth and material used in embroidery from customers and then charge them for my labor. The charges depend on the length and effort of my labor. I have a small family and the income of my husband is not sufficient to meet the household expenses. I need a loan of $425 to purchase cloth and material used in making embroidered clothes to increase my profits. By doing this, I hope to improve the living standard of my family.

loans.use: Buy cloth and other required materials

loans.name: Rehana

texts.en: My name is Rehana K., a resident of Lahore. My husband is a tailor and he creates readymade garments. I have three children, two girls and a boy. My elder daughter is studying in grade five and my son is in grade two. I need a loan of $250 to purchase a sewing machine and cloth for my husband’s garment business. I know that my children would be able to get better education if we are able to generate more income.

loans.use: Buy sewing machine and cloth for the business

loans.name: Mumtaz

texts.en: I am Mumtaz B.. My husband Irshad Ahmed is a fruit seller. We are residents of Lahore. I have three children, two sons and a daughter. I need a loan of $250 to invest in the fruit business of my husband. We need to increase our income to give a better future to our children.

loans.use: Expand fruit business

loans.name: Rukhsana

texts.en: My name is Rukhsana A. and I am a resident of Lahore. My husband manufactures plastic shopping bags. I have four children: one son and three daughters. I need a loan of $500 to invest in my husband’s business, by which he will purchase plastic granules, color and mixture. My elder son and daughter could not get education due to lack of financial resources and my son started doing menial jobs. I am determined to generate enough finances for the education of both of my younger children and for the business of my elder son.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Shazia

texts.en: My name is Shazia. My husband's name is A. and we have three children, a son and two daughters. My husband has a small retail shop, and I am involved in selling blankets, bedsheets and cloth, which I purchase from another city and sell in Lahore market. I need a loan of $250 to purchase blankets, bedsheets and the other cloth items for the business. All my children are studying, and our household expenses are very high. I am working so that I can give a better future to my children.

loans.use: Buy items for the business in bulk

loans.name: Robina

texts.en: My name is Robina, a resident of Lahore. I am the mother of five children, aged between 8 to 21 years. I did a course of midwife twelve years ago and started practicing as a midwife to earn my living. My husband Munir Ahmed sells fruit. We need a loan of $250, to purchase fruit for the business. I intend to fulfill my liabilities in a good way, such as through marriages of my daughters, so that is why I and my husband both work very hard.

loans.use: Buy fruit for the business

loans.name: Saima

texts.en: My name is Saima N. wife of N. But. I have three daughters aged between one to five years. I live with my family in Lahore, a big metropolis in Pakistan. My husband runs a small business of selling bedsheets. Earlier, he used to do a business of selling vegetables. He remained sick for one year and had to abandon his vegetable business. We need a loan of $425 to invest in our current business.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Yasmin

texts.en: I am Yasmin B. and the wife of Mohammad Azam. I have two sons of age 22 and 24 years. Both of my sons do a small business of selling rickshaw spare parts. Now they need a loan of $425 to purchase tires, rims and other spare parts of rickshaws in bulk for their business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for rickshaws

loans.name: Shafqat

texts.en: My name is Shafqat S.. I live with my family in Lahore. My husband manufactures sewing machines. I have six children, three sons and three daughters, ranging in age from 15 to 24. We need a loan of $500 to purchase spare parts used in the manufacture of sewing machines. I wish to help my husband in his business and give my children a better education.

loans.use: Buy sewing machine parts

loans.name: Asiah

texts.en: I am Asiah B. from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I am married have two boys. My sons run a small business selling costume jewelry and ready-made garments. They now need a loan of $250 to invest in their business and increase their income.

loans.use: Increase inventory in jewelry and garment business

loans.name: Nasim

texts.en: My name is Nasim T., and my husband’s name is T. Mehmood. We are residents of Lahore. I have four children, two sons and two daughters. My husband runs snooker hall, where people from nearby areas come to play snooker [a variant of billiards].  My husband is requesting a loan of $250 to invest in his snooker hall. He wants to expand his business to give our children a better future.

loans.use: Expand snooker hall

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea C., 39, is a hard-working mother of six children and works purchasing fruits from the growers and selling them to the people in her community, making on average about $1.30/day of profit. Her husband drives a motor-taxi earning on average about $2/day of profit, while three of her children are construction workers. The biggest expense of Mrs. Chea C. is on her other three children who are currently in school. Recently, she has humbly requested for a loan to purchase more fruits from the growers to meet  the growing customer demands.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits from the growers to the growing customer demands

loans.name: Sawya

texts.en:
Sawya is 36, married, and cares for 2 orphans in addition to her own 8 children. I was in a discussion with the credit officer who helps me translate (there are 52 different languages in Uganda) and told him that in the United States, people have an average of two to three children to a family. He asked, “Why do you not have more?” I discovered that to many people, children are wealth and seen as extra provision for parents because they are expected to look after their parents in old age.

Many people in Uganda have land that was given to them by their king. The thinking there is that as long as you have land that you can give to your children, you should have lots of children. The credit offer's father had 16 children and is considered a wealthy man. The problem of course becomes that the land is continually being divided into smaller and smaller plots. Currently, Uganda has one of the highest birthrates in the world and half of the population is under the age of 15, with no job prospects.

Sawya operates a restaurant where she serves typical Ugandan food of beans, meat, matooke, rice. In rural area, it is all but impossible to find any other type of food. She plans to use her loan to buy more foodstuffs for her restaurant. She hopes that she will be able to pay school fees so that her children will be able to finish school and even attend university.

loans.use: Sawya plans to use her loan to buy more cooking material for her restaurant

loans.name: Tahira

texts.en: My name is Tahira B.. My husband runs a ready-to-wear garment business. We reside in Lahore, Pakistan, known as the city of gardens. I have two children, a son, 8, and a daughter, 9. My husband needs a loan of $250 to purchase ready-made garments for the upcoming high season. We want to expand our business so that we can offer our children a better education.

loans.use: Increase inventory of ready-to-wear garments

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea Chantho, 43, works on her plot of land growing a  variety of vegetables and sells them to the people in her area, earning on average about $3/day in revenue. Her husband, meanwhile, is self-employed as a motor-taxi driver and typically makes $2/day. Mrs. Chea Chantho has six children, one of whom is employed at a nearby garment factory making $2/day and the rest of whom are enrolled in school. Mrs. Chea C. has had trouble with her water system to grow her crops, especially in the dry season. Recently, she has requested for a loan to purchase a water-pump and water pipe so that she is able to water her crops via a nearby pond in her community.

loans.use: To buy a water pump machine to facilitate her crop growings.

loans.name: Verina

texts.en:
Verina is 40 years old and widowed with 4 children. She also takes care of 2 orphans. She currently has a produce stand but would like to one day run a retail store of her own. People often start with selling wares/food at a produce stand as a way to support their families. However, these are temporary stand alone structures into which all goods must be packed up at the end of the day. It can be hot out there between the stores and the street.

Unless you are in the marketplace with all the other produce vendors, you will probably want to eventually have a retail store where you can get out of the heat, lock up at night and stock with a lot more items. Verina would like to have a store, but for now she uses her profits to just pay school fees. With her loan she will continue stocking her produce stand and hopefully expanding her business.

loans.use: Verina plans to use her loan to continue stocking her produce stand.

loans.name: Sang

texts.en: Mr. Sang S., is a widow and works on his rice paddy growing crops and can make only meager money per day. Every cost expense in his family is mostly conducted by his daughter who runs a stand selling grocery products with her husband working as a recycler. The three members work very hard day to day to generate their family’s income.  Mr. Sang S. has requested for a loan to expand his daughter’s grocery stand to meet her growing customer demands and the remainder of the loan is to reinvest in his son-in-law recyclable business.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products for his daughter to meet her clients' needs.

loans.name: Sang

texts.en: Mrs. Sang S. is a widow and works on her rice paddy growing crops and can make only meagre money per day. Every cost expense in her family is mostly taken care of by her daughter who runs a stand selling grocery products, with her husband working as a recycler. The three family members work very hard day to day to generate their family’s income.  Mrs. Sang S. has requested for a loan to expand her daughter’s grocery stand to meet her growing customer demands and the remainder of the loan is to reinvest in her son-in-law recyclable business.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products for her daughter to meet her clients' needs.

loans.name: Apophia

texts.en:
Apophia is a well-dressed 25 year old married mother of three. Every week she travels to Kampala, 5 hours away on the matatoo (taxi) to Masaka (a district in central Uganda), three hours away, to buy clothes for her store. Kampala has a very busy and hectic street marketplace where she can buy discounted new clothes. A lot of women sell used clothes which they buy in wired or gunnysack bales, stuffed with used clothes, but Apophia only buys new clothes.

This is a new business for her. She has only been in business for six months, but she is very bright and intuitive and her ability to select the products that her customers want and can afford has made her business successful. However, it is a lot of work to travel so far and deal with the anxiety of shopping in the garment district . She will use her loan to buy more clothes and to pay for her transport to Masaka. For now, she sells in the marketplace, but soon hopes to have a retail store to display her clothes more appropriately.

loans.use: Apophia plans to use her loan to buy more clothes for her store and to pay transport fees for buying clothes from other cities.

loans.name: Nusrat

texts.en: I am Nusrat P. from Multan, a medium-sized city famous in Pakistan for its pottery. I am married and have three children. My elder daughter attends kindergarten; the other two children are small are too young to attend school. My husband supplies various daily-use items to shopkeepers in the city. We need a loan of $250 to improve our business and increase our income.

loans.use: Improve current business

loans.name: Saleem

texts.en: I am married and have seven children: five boys and two girls. I live with my family in Multan, Pakistan. I have my own small brick house here. I want to borrow $425 for my husband.  He is an electrician and runs a shop where he sells electrical appliances and supplies. With your loan he will purchase a few gas motors, water pumps, pipes, etc. This loan will help us to bring economic security to our family.

loans.use: Buy supplies for electric goods store

loans.name: Phov

texts.en: Mrs. Phov S., 38, runs a stand at home selling a variety of grocery products to the people in her community and generally makes about $3/day in revenue. Her husband works driving a motor-taxi, making up to $5 per day. Mostly his passenger base is in front of a market. Mrs. Phov Savannarith has three children who are students. She has requested for a loan to purchase a new motorcycle for her husband because his current motor-bike is frequently broken and costs her family a lot of money to repair. (Her husband is pictured with a motor-bike he plans to buy to run a business).

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle for her husband to operate a business

loans.name: Jolly's Group

texts.en:
Jolly is the chairperson of the Nyakabare B Tutungukte Lending Group in the countryside outside of Ntungamo. The region around Ntungamo is knowns for its stunning beauty. The drive to the lending group is on a rutted road going through dense groves of matooke, coffee and lush green hills. The lending group meets in one of the homes of the owners. From this hilltop you can see neighboring Tanzania. Meeting at night, there is no electricity and the only light is from paraffin lanterns, lighting the homes of villagers across the valley. The sky is ablaze with stars.

Jolly and her husband have six children and own a wholesale business in which they sack beans, peas and millet in 50kg to 100kg sacks. In this area of Uganda, most people are subsistence farmers. Any extra food grown is sacked and sent to markets. In most retail stores you will see 4-6 of these sacks in front of the counter. Jolly and her husband have been in business for 10 years and have been members of their lending group for the past four years. They plan to use her loan to modernize their farm.

loans.use: Jolly plans to use her loan to buy modernize her farm.

loans.name: Kosar

texts.en: I live in Multan, a medium-sized city famous in Pakistan for its shrines. I have three children: one boy and two daughters. Thankfully my children attend school, except the youngest who is not of school age yet. I am requesting a loan for my husband, who is a scrap dealer. With this loan he intends to buy scrap items, including plastic bottles and old iron, in bulk. Please help us uplift our economic status.

loans.use: Buy scrap items in bulk

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy is 45 years old and married with six children. For the past 30 years, she has been farming with her husband. They farm and sell matooke (a plantain banana dish), sugar cane and beans. They are subsistence farmers, who sell the small amount left over after feeding their family. In this area, matooke and unripe bananas are the main staple foods. A matooke plant can yield up to two harvests per year. Growing one matooke plant can easily take up at least 100sq. ft. of land. In addition, the plant's leaves don't let in sunlight, making it hard to grow much around the plant, save for a few sweet potatoes. Coffee also grows well here and yields much more money per sq. ft.

However, people grow much more matooke than coffee. Why? The reason is that a field of matooke can yield mature fruit all year long, so when one plant isn’t producing, another will be. With coffee, you will only get two harvests per year for the entire field. Most people cannot wait for a harvest of coffee. With their Kiva loan, Joy and her husband plan to work on modernizing their farm.

loans.use: Joy plans to use her loan to modernize her farm.

loans.name: Rukhsana

texts.en: I am Rukhsana S. from Multan, a medium-sized city in Pakistan. I am married and have five children. All of us live in a small brick house. My husband’s income is very small. To supplement his income. I sew clothes to order for my neighborhood clients. I am requesting a loan of $425 to expand my business. Your loan will help me continue to put food on our table.

loans.use: Expand sewing business

loans.name: Tuy

texts.en: Mrs. Tuy R., 33, works at a nearby garment factory and earns about $4 per day in revenue. She lives with her husband, who is unemployed, and two little children in Phnom Penh city, Cambodia. Mrs. Tuy R. hopes to use this loan to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a motor-taxi business, which will enable them to generate more income for their household. (Her husband is pictured with a motorcycle he intends to buy for his business).

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a business.

loans.name: Loice

texts.en:
Loice is a 30-year-old married woman who looks after her own four children as well as three orphans. She runs a tailoring business and sells the clothes she tailors. Tailoring clothes in her village involves using a treadle sewing machine. In fact, in these villages, it is common to see people pedaling away on their treadle machines outside their tailor shops. Clothes made by a tailor are always cheaper than store-bought and is more compelling for buyers because they can take part in the design!

Tailoring is also a skilled trade, so if you have a knack for it and produce good work, you will always be in need, unlike a produce stand that can be here today and gone tomorrow. Here’s another interesting fact: In Uganda, young girls in rural areas often do not complete their formal education. Once a girl drops out of school, she becomes economically vulnerable and her hopes and dreams fade away. The abililty to learn a trade is therefore important so that she can support herself as boost her self-esteem. With her Kiva loan, Loice plans to buy more material and embroidery for her tailoring business.

loans.use: Loice will use her loan to buy more material and embroidery for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en: Mrs. Chhorn Y., 48, is a mother of four children and works with her husband as traditional musicians, earning collectively about $10 per day. One of her children is enrolled in school, while the rest of them are married and live away from her. Mrs. Chhorn Y. has humbly requested for a loan to purchase a motorcycle for her family’s transportation because she and her family has spent a lot of money on using a motor-taxi service day-to-day. She believes the loan will save her family a lot of money and also help increase her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her family’s transportation

loans.name: Gurban

texts.en:
The G. family lives in the Khachmaz region in the village of Gusarchay. He is married, has 2 children.
This man was born in 1957. Gurban has 6 years of experience in the farming business. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy seedlings and fertilizer. He plans to plant apple, cherry and other seedlings so he can improve his business and get more income.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Kishwer

texts.en: I have one son and live with my family in Multan, a medium-sized city in Pakistan. My son is too young to attend school. My husband operates a fruit business that he would like to expand. He is requesting a loan of $250 for this purpose. He intends to buy seasonal fruits in bulk with your loan. We hope we will able to give our child a sound economic future.

loans.use: Buy seasonal fruits in bulk

loans.name: Generous

texts.en:
Generous is 39, widowed, and looks after her three children as well as an orphan. She runs a hardware store in Ntugamo, selling mostly building materials. In the rural areas most homes are still built with twigs and mud, or adobe bricks and mud which do not require store-bought materials. But for every 10-20 earthen homes you will see a brick home with a concrete slab for a floor. So, bricks and cement are the main items for sale in hardware stores. Since there are no pre-mix concrete trucks, pouring even a small concrete floor can require hundreds of bags of cement that then need to be mixed with sand and gravel to make the concrete on site. Nails and metal items are few, due to their high cost.

Therefore, Generous' store meets an important construction need in her neighbourhood. She has been in business for 12 years and has been a member of her lending group for the past 4 years. With her Kiva loan, she plans to buy more bags of cement.

loans.use: Generous plans to buy more bags of cement and hardware for her store.

loans.name: Salma

texts.en: I am asking on behalf of my brother for a loan of $250. He is a rickshaw driver, and his rickshaw needs repairs. I am married and have six children. All of us, including my brother, live in Multan, a medium-sized city in Pakistan. This is a busy city, and many people like to travel by rickshaw.

loans.use: Repair rickshaw

loans.name: Jovia

texts.en:
Jovia is 57 years old and widowed. Having raised 6 children of her own, she now cares for her four orphaned grandchildren who have lost their parents - her children- to AIDS. Uganda is a nation with an entire generation lost to AIDS, so older people like Jovia are the only people left to care for their grandchildren. It is noticeable how few people there are here between the ages of 35-55. When AIDS hit hardest 20 years ago, it decimated the 15-25 age group, leaving a gap in the age demography for 35-55 year olds today .

Jovia runs a retail store where she sells dried staples such as maize flour, sugar, rice, etc. She has operated this store for the past 13 years and has been a member of her lending group for the past 4 years. She plans to use her Kiva loan to buy more such staples to boost sales.

loans.use: Jovia plans to use her Kiva loan to buy more dried goods for her store.

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en: My name is Shamim A.. I am married and have ten children. I live with my family in a two-room, brick-mud house in Multan, a medium-sized city in Pakistan. My husband operates power looms used to manufacture cloth. I embroider clothes and sell them for profit. I am requesting a loan of $175 to expand my business. With this money, I will buy cloth, thread, and sequins in bulk.

loans.use: Buy cloth, thread, and sequins

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is 37 years old, married, and looks after his own six children as well as three orphans. For the past 15 years, he has been packing dried beans and peas into sacks for wholesale. The 50 -100kg sacks are sold wholesale to retail stores who then weigh out the amount requested by customers. James is also a subsistence farmer. The farm land of the Ntugamo District, where he lives, is quite fertile and it is not uncommon for farmers to be able to grow extra crops for sale. James is a particularly good farmer who stands out because of the large volume of dried goods he can provide for sale.

loans.use: James plans to use his loan to improve his farm.

loans.name: Zokhrab

texts.en: Zokhrab was born in 1966. This young man is married andhas 3 children. He lives with his family in Khachmaz town. Two years ago he decided to start his own business for supporting his family. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to maintain his car and improve his business.

loans.use: To repair his car

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en: I am Shamim B. from Multan, a medium-sized city in Pakistan. I am married and have ten children. Almost all of my children are above the age of 16. I therefore have some free time in which I sew clothes for my neighborhood clients. My husband and one of my sons operate a rice business. These days rice is comparatively cheaper because it is the rice harvest season. My husband wants to purchase and stock a large quantity of rice while the price is low. Please lend him $325 for this purpose.

loans.use: Buy rice in bulk

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en: I live in Multan, a medium-sized city famous in Pakistan for its art work. I have four children: three boys and one girl. Thankfully all of my children attend a local school. My husband is an enthusiastic entrepreneur. He works very hard to provide for his family. By profession he is a rickshaw driver, and now his rickshaw needs maintenance. Please lend him $250 for this purpose.

loans.use: Repair rickshaw

loans.name: Hasanaga

texts.en: Two years ago Hasanaga started this business. He transports furniture with his truck for sale in furniture shops. Hasanaga is 48 years old, married, and has 2 children. He lives in Khachmaz town. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy spare parts for this lorry in order to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his truck

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en: My name is Parveen B. from Multan, a city famous in Pakistan for its shrines. I have seven children: four boys and three girls. All of us live in a rented brick house. Three of my children are above the age of 16, the rest all attend school. I sew clothes for women in my neighborhood. My business is growing at a reasonable rate. Now I wish to expand it and am requesting a loan of $325 for this purpose. With this loan, I intend to buy cloth, threads, and sequins.

loans.use: Buy cloth, thread, and sequins

loans.name: Shugufta

texts.en: I have five children: two boys and three girls. I live with my family in a small brick house in Multan, Pakistan. All of my children are enrolled in a local school here in Multan. I wind thread on plastic spools that my husband uses, at his power looms to manufacture cloth. We need to expand our current business for which we require a loan of $200.

loans.use: Expand cloth manufacturing business

loans.name: Shugufta

texts.en: I am Shugufta K. A. from Multan, Pakistan. I am a mother of six children: two boys and four girls. I provide tailoring services from my home to women in my neighborhood. There are not too many such tailors in our area. I therefore intend to improve my business through investing a loan of $250. I plan to buy threads, cloth and other few items with this loan.

loans.use: Buy few items for the business

loans.name: Rubina

texts.en: I live in a midsize metropolis, Multan, in Pakistan. I am married with four children. We live in a small rented brick house here in Multan. I have enrolled all of my children to school except the youngest, who will attend school sometime in the near future. My husband is the only breadwinner of the entire family. He is responsible for every household expense and pays for the children's school charges. He owns a grocery store. Now he plans to increase his income through expanding his shop. Please lend him $325. This loan will help him to have more customers flock to his shop.

loans.use: Expand grocery store

loans.name: Sardaran

texts.en:
I am a widow Sardaran B. from Multan, a midsize city in Pakistan. I am a mother of two girls both of whom are above 18. I work very hard to provide for my family. 

I buy various scrap items and sell them in different cities. I need a loan of $250 to buy scrap items such as iron objects, steel bits, and pieces in bulk for the business. This way I will be able to sell more on every visit to a different city. The man in the photo is my brother. Since I am a widow, I have engaged him to help me out with my business. I am needy and hope you will not turn down my loan request.

loans.use: Buy scrap items

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Sevindj

texts.en: Sevindj (her husband is pictured) was born in 1965. She is a mother of 2 children. The Mustafayev family lives in the Khachmaz region. This family has their own furniture shop. Sevindj's husband gives orders to the furniture makers to make new furniture for them, and then this family sells the furniture in their own shop. Now they need a loan of $950 to order new funiture to sell.

loans.use: To order new furniture to sell

loans.name: Sughran

texts.en: I am Sughran B. from Multan, a midsize city in Southern Punjab, a key province in Pakistan. I am married and a mother of six. My husband runs a fruit shop and one of our sons is in the embroidery business. My son now requires buying a special sewing machine and a computerized embroidery machine in order to improve his business, which will translate into better profits. Please lend him $425 for this purpose.

loans.use: Buy a special sewing machine and a computerized embroidery machine

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en: I am Nasreen B. from a city, Multan, in Pakistan. I am a mother of seven. My husband operates a furniture business. He has expertise at his work and a great aesthetic sense. He wishes to expand his business for which he requires a loan of $200.  He plans to produce high quality furniture and buy good timber. This way our income will be doubled.

loans.use: Buy wood for the business

loans.name: Khursheed

texts.en: I am Khursheed B., and I belong to a midsize city Multan, Paksitan. This city is very famous for its shrines and pottery. I have two sons; one of them studies in a local school.
