Se dedica a la venta de cecina, chorizo, chicharrón y sus derivados y desde hace 30 años , gracias a la buena sazón, higiene y buen servicio que presta, cuenta con clientes fieles no sólo de la zona, también de otras partes del departamento.

Con el préstamo de S/.1,500.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará los insumos necesarios para la elaboración de sus productos como los cerdos (chanchos), que es la materia prima esencial y los condimentos necesarios para la elaboración de las carnes ahumadas y los embutidos, también comercializa carne roja cruda.

La señora Grimanesa tiene 61 años, es madre de 7 hijos todos ellos independiente. El negocio que desarrolla la ha convertido en una mujer independiente, perseverante, decidida y segura, sueña con formar una empresa de negociantes asociados de venta de carnes rojas y derivados.

loans.use: Purchase necessary ingredients for the preparation of her smoked meats and sausages.

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es:
Maritza is a member of the Los Jazmines Communal Bank and lives in the province and district of Moyobamba in San Martin. She has a stand in the city’s central market where she sells fruits and vegetables from the coast. She decided to start this business because she wanted to be independent financially and with her time, and because she previously had a salaried job and she didn’t like being subjected to a boss and a schedule. Because she is a very apt and hard-working person, and because she likes to manage her own capital, she decided to start this activity and in that way, grow as a person and a woman.

The loan of S./ 1,000.00, which she will repay in 6 months, will buy her fruits such as apples, mangoes and peaches in boxes as well as vegetables like potatoes, onions, sweet potatoes in sacks, cauliflower, red peppers, spinach by the kilo and other fruits and vegetables. In that way, she will keep her sales stand well-stocked and her customers happy.

Maritza is 41 years old and has no children, but she is raising 4 nieces and nephews who can now support her in her business and at home. She also counts with the support of her husband. She is happy with what she does and with the results she has obtained to date. Her clientele has increased, which also helped improve her financial situation. Her goal is to have her business at home so that she may tend to her business and her household at the same time.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maritza es socia del banco comunal Los Jazmines, vive en el Jr. Grau s/n c-4 de la provincia y distrito de Moyobamba, departamento de San Martín. Tiene un puesto en el mercado central de la ciudad donde vende frutas y verduras de la costa. Decidió iniciarse en el negocio porque quería ser independiente en tiempo y dinero y porque antes tenía un trabajo con un sueldo y no le gustaba estar sujeto a un jefe y a un horario. Como ella es una persona muy trabajadora y hábil y como le gusta manejar su propio capital decidió iniciar esta actividad y de esa manera poder crecer como persona y mujer.

El préstamo de 1,000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará frutas como manzanas, mangos, duraznos en cajas, verduras como papas, cebollas, camotes en sacos, coliflor, ají pimentón, espinaca en kilos y demás frutas y verduras y de esa manera tener bien surtido su puesto de venta y también tener bien satisfechos a sus clientes.

Tiene 41 años, no tiene hijos, pero está criando a cuatro sobrinos quienes ahora ya la apoyan en el negocio y en la casa, también cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo. Está contenta con lo que hace y satisfecha con los resultados obtenidos hasta la fecha, su clientela aumentó y ello también ayudó a que mejore su situación económica. Su meta es contar con un negocio en su casa para poder estar pendiente a la vez de su casa y negocio.

loans.use: Purchase fruits (apples, mangoes, peaches, etc.) and  vegetables (potatoes, onions, sweet potatoes, cauliflower, red peppers and spinach)

loans.name: Elizabeth's Group

texts.es:
Lisbeth, Elizabeth and Rachel belong to the Communal Bank Florecer. They joined 1, 2, and 2 years ago, respectively. Lisbeth is 25 years old, Elizabeth is 31 years years old, and Rachel is 25 years years old. The three women are working in the group together, and have 2 children each. The 3 tell us that the Communal Bank taught them to be punctual, responsible and trained in how to invest their money, how to prevent disease and how to save money. Lisbeth, along with her husband has a restaurant located in a central area of the city of Ayacucho. The room is rented and in a home. She and her husband work as waiters and kitchen helper. They have been doing this work for a year, and are doing very well. Elizabeth sells cosmetics through catalogs like Ebel and Unique, and with the money that she was able save with Communal Bank, she bought a car for her husband who works as taxi in the city. Rachel runs a small grocery store, where she previously sold "salchipapas" which she had to stop offering because it just didn't sell. The loans requested are for 600 suns, 600 suns and 400 soles respectively, which will be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar, milk, soap, detergent, eggs, soft drinks, cosmetics, car tires, and a payment towards a freezer and a stove with 3 burners. Lisbeth, Elizabeth and Rachel dream of having a large restaurant and their own cars. They also dream of building their own house, where they can live happily so their children can study and become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Lisbeth, Elizabeth y Raquel pertenecen al Banco Comunal Florecer hace 1, 2, y 2 años respectivamente. Lisbeth tiene 25 años, Elizabeth tiene 31 años, mientras que Raquel tiene 25 años y las tres son convivientes y tienen 2 hijos cada una. Las 3 nos cuentan que en su Banco Comunal les enseñaron a ser puntuales, responsables y las capacitaron en cómo invertir su dinero, cómo prevenir enfermedades y el hábito del ahorro. Lisbeth junto a su esposo tiene un restaurante ubicado en una zona céntrica de la ciudad de Ayacucho. El local es alquilado y en un inicio ella y su esposo trabajaban como mozos y ayudante de cocina. En este tiempo ellos ahorraron y hace 1 año ellos iniciaron con el restaurante y les está yendo muy bien. Por otro lado Elizabeth vende cosméticos por catálogo como Ebel, Unique y con el dinero que llegó a ahorrar en su Banco Comunal compró un carro para que su esposo trabaje haciendo taxi en la ciudad. Mientras que Raquel tiene una pequeña tienda de abarrotes pero anteriormente ella vendía salchipapas pero dejó de hacerlo porque no tenía venta. Sus préstamos son de 600 soles, 600 soles y 400 soles respectivamente, que serán invertidos en la compra de arroz, azúcar, leche, jabón, detergente, huevos, gaseosas, cosméticos, llantas para su carro y en el caso de Lisbeth, pagará una cuota de su congeladora y una cocina de 3 hornillas. Los sueños de Lisbeth, Elizabeth y Raquel son tener un restaurante grande y propio, un carro, construir su casa, vivir feliz y que sus hijos estudien y sean profesionales.

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, milk, soaps, detergent, eggs, soft drinks, costmetics, car tires and payment towards a freezer and an stove with 3 burners. (Sus préstamos son de 600 soles, 600 soles y 400 soles respectivamente, que serán invertidos en la compra de arroz, azúcar, leche, jabón, detergente, huevos, gaseosas, cosméticos, llantas para su carro y en el caso de Lisbeth, pagará una cuota de su congeladora y una cocina de 3 hornillas.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in more clothing and garments for sale and to maintain his motorcycle

loans.name: Yovana's Group

texts.es:
Victoria is 25 years and is single, while Nelly and Yovana are both 29 years old and each has 1 child. They are partners of the Communal Bank Florecer and joined 3, 4, 3 years ago respectively. The Communal Bank wants all partners to be happy, united and to also learn to be punctual and responsible.

Yovana has a grocery store that she opened 2 years ago with a capital of 300 suns and sold only a few products, but now her business has grown and she has many customers.

Victoria, along with her mom, have a sales post in the grocery market Carmen Alto. Her mom travels to fairs to buy cereal, which she then grinds, and sells at their post.

Nelly sells candy at the door of Jose Condorcanqui Carmen Alto College, and also sells "salchipapas" at night at Avenue Libertadores.

Their loans are 600 soles each, which will be invested in the purchase of beans, barley, wheat, corn, peas, potatoes, oil, disposable dishes, cookies, candies, chocolates, rice, sugar, soap, milk, oil and panetones . The dreams of Yovana, Victoria and Nelly are buying a plot of land on which to build their own house someday. They dream of living happily with their husbands (and future husbands) and children. They want their children to grow and become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Victoria tiene 25 años y es soltera, mientras que Nelly y Yovana tienen 29 años y cada una tiene 1 hijo. Ellas son socias del Banco Comunal Florecer hace 3, 4, 3 años respectivamente. En el Banco Comunal todas las socias son alegres, unidas y además aprenden a ser puntuales y responsables. Yovana tiene una tienda de abarrotes que inició hace 2 años con un capital de 300 soles y solo vendía pocos productos, pero en la actualidad su negocio ha crecido y tiene muchos clientes. Por otro lado Victoria junto a su mamá tienen un puesto de venta de abarrotes en el mercado de Carmen Alto y también su mamá viaja a las ferias a traer cereales para luego elaborar molidos y luego venderlos en su puesto. Mientras que Nelly vende golosinas en la puerta del colegio José Condorcanqui de Carmen Alto, y además vende salchipapas por las noches en la Av. Libertadores. Sus préstamos son de 600 soles cada una, que serán invertidos en la compra de haba, cebada, trigo, maíz, arveja, papa, aceite, platos descartables, galletas, caramelos, chocolates, arroz, azúcar, jabón, leche, aceite y panetones. Los sueños de Yovana, Victoria y Nelly son comprar un terreno y luego construir su casa, vivir feliz con su esposo e hijo, casarse y tener una familia y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use:
The loans will be used for investing in the purchase of beans, barley, wheat, corn, peas, potatoes, oil, disposable dishes, cookies, candies, chocolates, rice, sugar, soap, milk, oil and panetones . 
(Sus préstamos son de 600 soles cada una, que serán invertidos en la compra de haba, cebada, trigo, maíz, arveja, papa, aceite, platos descartables, galletas, caramelos, chocolates, arroz, azúcar, jabón, leche, aceite y panetones.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in merchandise such as cosmetics, creams, and costume jewelry.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Improvements to  the school.

loans.name: Emiliana De

texts.es:
Emiliana is 38 years old, is married and has four children (the oldest is 16 and the youngest is 6). She has a very stable and united family. Emiliana, together with her husband, offer amplifier services, and her husband also works in a factory sewing slacks. They have enough experience in both their activities. But they have the longest experience working at sewing (they've done this for 11 years). Of course much depends on quality of product and service being offered to the public, who is very demanding. With this loan, Emiliana plans to buy speakers for her amplifier, which cost approximately $ US. 150 .- each, and she will purchase two of them. Emiliana has an excellent credit rating - this is the fourth loan she is requesting from our institution.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Emiliana es una señora de 38 años de edad está casada y tiene cuatro hijos de los cuales solo una es mujer la mayor, con aproximadamente 16 años y el pequeño tiene unos 6 años. Tiene un nucleo familiar muy estable y una familia muy unida. Emiliana junto con su esposo tienen una amplificacion y por otra parte su esposo trabaja también en una fabrica de pantalones como costurero. Tienen bastante experiencia en sus 2 actividades, la costura es donde son mas antiguos con aproximadamente 11 años. La competencia en el medio es relativa y moderada, depende mucho la calidad de producto y servicio que se ofrece al público para tener demanda. Con la presente solicitud Emiliana comprara parlantes para su amplificacion que aproximadamente le cuestan $us. 150.- cada uno y comprara dos de ellos. Emiliana es una persona que tiene un excelente comportamiento crediticio, esta es la cuarta operación que solicita en nuestra Institución.

loans.use: To purchase speakers for her amplifier. (Compra de parlantes para su amplificación)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying a refrigerator and making improvements to her work space (Comprar un enfriador y arreglar su lugar de trabajo)

loans.name: Elizabeth De

texts.es:
Elizabeth is a married 50-year old woman; she has two grown children who support themselves. Elizabeth's business involves the sale of orange juice, carrot juice, pastries, sandwiches, etc. All of these products are found at her own stand located near the university Mayor de San Simon. She also has a kiosk in front of the Viedma hospital. Her experience spans 128 months at this location, which is very popular by all of the students that attend both places. Although the competition is quite high, her experience and her attention to quality and hygiene are key factors. With the money from this current loan, she would buy carrots for Bs. 70 per bag, bananas for Bs. 50, as well as other fruit like strawberries, papaya, and other bottled soda. Elizabeth has a prior loan with us with very good history.

Translated from Spanish by Mindy Burns, Kiva volunteer.

Elizabeth es un señora casada de 50 años de edad, tiene dos hijos que son mayores de edad y los mismos se solventan solos. Elizabeth se dedica a la venta de jugos de naranja, zumos de zanahoria, empanadas, sandwichs, etc. Todos estos productos en su puesto propio que se encuentra ubicado cerca de la Universidad Mayor de San Simón, también cuenta con un kiosko frente al Hospital Viedma. Cuenta con una experiencia de 128 meses en este rubro por lo que es bastante conocida por todos los estudiantes que asisten en ambos lugares. Si bien la competencia es bastante elevada su antiguedad y su calidad de atención e higiene son factores clave. Con el dinero de la presente solicitud comprará zanahoria por un valor de Bs. 70.- el saquillo, platano por un valor de Bs. 50.-, también otras frutas como fresas papayas y así también otros refrescos en botella. Elizabeth tiene un crédito anterior con nosotros con un muy buen comportamiento.

loans.use: Additional kiosk/ fruit stand use

loans.name: Sofia

texts.es:
Sofia is married. Her husband, who is cosigning the loan, is a policeman. They have four children that depend on them.

Sofia owns a general store and has 4 years of experience in this endeavor. On the other hand, her husband has more than 20 years of experience working for the National Police.

The competition in the general store trade is very high, however, Sofia has the advantage of her experience that has allowed her to establish a steady clientele.

The current loan request is for the purchase of merchandise. The products that she buys are typical for a general store, such as consumer product for the use in the home. The prices fluctuate based on their seasonal availability.

Their credit history is good. They have already obtained two loans through this institution. Currently they are in the process of this third request with excellent references as to their reliability and timeliness.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Sofia es una señora casada, su esposo que es Policia quien firma como co-deudor, ademas tienen cuatro hijos que dependen de ellos.

Sofia tiene una tienda de barrio y cuenta con una experiencia de 4 años en este rubro.

Su esposo por otra parte tiene una experiencia de más de 20 años traajando para la Policia Nacional.

La competencia en este rubro es bastante elevada pero Sofia tiene la ventaja de contar con la experiencia que le ha valido para tener una clientela establecida.

La presente solicitud es para a adquisición de mercadería, los productos que compra son los típicos de una tienda de barrio que son productos de consumo masivo de la canasta familiar, los precios fluctuan según la escacez de los productos de la época.

Su comportamieno crediticio es bueno, ya han sacado dos créditos en nuestra institución, actualmente está en su tercera operación con excelentes referencias de puntualidad.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise.

loans.name: Melina

texts.es:
Melina lives in the region of San Martin in the district of Lamas. She is a member of the communal bank called Las Lamenas. She has a stand where she sells juices and cold drinks, strategically located close to main road which keeps her business steady. Three years ago, motivated by a friend her offered her an existing business, she decided to do it for two reasons; she already knew a little about the business, and also because her two daughters could help her. One of her daughters had experience in this type of business. Melina has been able to maintain her customers with her good service.

With the loan, which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy a new blender, as well as fruits she uses every day to prepare the juices such as oranges and papayas in bulk, also sugar and other ingredients to prepare her pastries and sweets. This will enable her to better meet the demand of her customers. Melina, at 70 years old, is an enthusiastic and strong woman who has raised 8 children. She continues to work hard to better her life.

La señora Melina vive en la región de San Martín, provincia y distrito de Lamas. Es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal Las Lameñas y tiene un puesto de venta de jugos y refrigerios en un lugar estratégico cerca al paradero de autos, ubicado en el Jr. San Martín Cdra 9, por lo que el negocio es bastante concurrido. Hace 3 años, motivada por una amiga quien le ofrece un negocio implementado, ella decide adquirirlo por dos motivos: conocía de las utilidades que dejaba el negocio y tenía el apoyo de 2 de sus hijas, una de ellas con experiencia en este tipo de negocio. Es por ello que hasta la fecha mantienen su clientela por la buena atención y el buen trato que reciben. Con el préstamo de S/. 2,500.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará una licuadora nueva, frutas que utiliza diariamente en la preparación de los jugos, como naranjas y papayas en sacos, guineos en racimos, azúcar en sacos e insumos para la preparación de refrigerios como pasteles, kekes y de esa manera satisfacer el apetito de sus clientes. Melina a sus 70 años aún es una mujer muy entusiasta y fuerte y con el aliento de sus 8 hijos, las ganas de vivir y trabajar todavía continúa luchando.

Translated by Kiva Volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: To purchase a new blender for her business making fresh juices.  She will also use it to purchase greater quantities of the fruits she uses each day, as well as sugar and other ingredients used in making the sweets she sells.

loans.name: Milegnith

texts.es:
Señora Milegnith belongs to the interim group "Jerusalén" (Jerusalem). She lives in the region and province of San Martín in the district of Tarapoto. Her house is located at 121 Pasaje Jerusalén. She has a business at 379 Mercado N. 2 Santa Rosa, which is called Almacén Santa Rosa. She sells dried, salted fish both retail and wholesale.

The opportunity to receive a loan from Manuela Ramos opened the doors for her to buy larger quantities of her products since she has a large demand. Her goal is to buy products directly from the provider to eliminate third parties, and to accomplish this, she needs good capital. With the necessary capital, she will be able to supply more clients and to fulfill her personal goals.

With this loan of 1,500 nuevos soles, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy 50 kilogram sacks of fish in large quantities of every variety.

Milegnith is 46-years-old, and she lives with her two children and her husband. She separated from the father of her children when they were still very young, and she had to work to be able to take good care of them. This is why she's thankful to Manuela Ramos because they offered opportunities to a woman like her to get ahead and to develop her abilities by having her own business.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Milegnith pertenece al Grupo Mientras Tanto “Jerusalén”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia de San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto, su domicilio está ubicado en el Pasaje Jerusalén Nº 121. Desarrolla un negocio en el Mercado Nº 2 Jr. Santa Rosa Nº 379 (Almacén Santa Rosa) y se dedica a la venta al por mayor y menor de pescado seco salado.

La oportunidad de un préstamo de Manuela Ramos le abrió las puertas para comprar en mayor cantidad sus productos ya que tiene buena demanda. Su meta es comprar productos directo al proveedor sin intermediarios y para lograr ello necesita un buen capital. Con el capital necesario le permitirá abastecer a más clientes y cumplir con sus metas personales.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,500.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará pescado en sacos de 50 kilos en mayor cantidad y de toda variedad.

La señora Milegnith tiene 46 años, vive con sus dos hijos y su esposo. Ella se separó del padre de sus hijos cuando éstos estaban pequeños y tuvo que trabajar para sacarlos adelante, es por ello que agradece a Manuela Ramos porque brinda oportunidades a mujeres como ella para salir adelante desarrollando sus capacidades mediante un negocio propio.

loans.use: Purchase of fish

loans.name: Militza Del Carmen

texts.es:
Mrs. Militza del Carmen is a member of the communal bank Los Jazmines (the jasmines). She is originally from Chachapoyas. She spends a lot of time in the city of Moyabamba and works selling products such as yucca, bananas, tomato, lemon, corn, and seasonal products. She also sells animals such as chickens, ducks, pigs, and turkeys in a stand she has in the central market of this city. In addition, she walks around the market and nearby streets offering her animals for sale. She decided to start this business because she likes this activity, being in contact with people. She also likes being in control of her own time, because in the past, she had been a cleaning lady and couldn't think of a better idea than to start her own business to be able to generate her own income, increase her self-esteem, grow as a person and as a woman, and contribute to the expenses required to support her children.

This loan for S/. 1,500.00, which she will pay back in 6 months, will buy animals such as chickens, turkeys, pigs, and in this way she will take advantage of the Christmas season. She will also buy products such as coffee, which is coming into season, and products she sells daily, such as sacks of yucca, corn, lemons, etc. With these products her business will be well stocked and her customers will be able to find the products they are looking for, very fresh.

Militza is 39 years old and has three children, one still a small child. She is happy because she can count with the support of her husband and she now has a person to help her with taking care of her young son, because this business requires a lot of hard work. Thanks to her hard work, the financial situation of her family has improved, and her self-esteem has increased as well. Her goal is to have a business selling grains.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Militza del Carmen es socia del banco comunal Los jazmines, es natural de Chachapoyas, vive mucho tiempo en la ciudad de Moyabamba y se dedica a la venta de productos de pan llevar como yuca, plátanos, tomate, limones, maíz, y productos que están en su temporada, también vende animales como gallinas, patos, cerdos, pavos en un puesto que tiene en el mercado central de esta ciudad, además recorre el mercado y alrededores con la venta de sus animales. Decidió iniciar un negocio porque le gusta esta actividad y quería estar en contacto con la gente y ser ella quien controle su tiempo porque anteriormente trabajaba como empleada doméstica y no tuvo mejor idea que emprender su propio negocio para así generar sus propios ingresos, alimentar su autoestima, crecer como persona y mujer y apoyar en los gastos que requiere sacar adelante a sus hijos.

El préstamo de S/. 1 500.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará animales como gallinas, pavos, cerdos y de esa manera aprovechar las fiestas navideñas, también comprará productos como café que ya se viene la cosecha y productos que vende a diario como yuca en sacos, maíz, limones, etc. Con esos productor podrá tener un negocio bien surtido y sus clientes encontrarán los productos que buscan y bien frescos.

Militza tiene 39 años y tres hijos, uno aún pequeño. Está contenta porque cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo y ahora ya tiene una persona quien le apoya en el cuidado de su pequeño hijo porque es muy sacrificado lo que hace, comparte su trabajo con las tareas domésticas. Gracias a su trabajo la situación económica de su familia mejoró, igualmente mejoró su autoestima. Su meta es tener su negocio de venta de granos.

loans.use:
Buying small animals (chickens, turkeys, pigs). Buying coffee and other products (yuca, corn, lemons, etc.)
(Compra de animales menores (gallenas, pavos, cerdos). Compra de café y otro productos (yuca, maíz, limones, etc))

loans.name: Nora Elia

texts.es:
Nora Elia is an enterprising woman who helps her husband selling cosmetics, shoes and clothes through a catalog to her her neighbors and friends. She works because what her husband earns as an electrician isn't enough to be able to pay the expenses of their two children. Her children are 11 and 8 years old and are studying in grade school. Nora Elia has worked in this business for two years and little by little has grown her customer base.

However, during the Christmas season, she has been given orders that she cannot fulfill so she's requesting a loan of $475 that she will pay back in a term of 6 months. With this money, Nora Elia will be able to buy the merchandise that her customers are requesting. In addition, she will be able to buy extra products to be able to have more of a variety to offer her customers. With your help, Nora Elia will be able to continue moving forward and growing her business at a strong rate.

Translated from Spanish by Kim Baker, Kiva volunteer.

Nora Elia es una mujer muy emprendedora que apoya a su esposo vendiendo cosméticos, zapatos y ropa por catálogo a sus vecinas y amigos puesto que lo que gana su esposo como electricista no es suficiente para poder pagar los gastos de sus dos hijos de 11 y 8 años que están estudiando la primaria. Nora Elia tiene dos años con este tipo de negocio y poco a poco ha ido creciendo su clientela.

Sin embargo en la temporada Navideña le han hecho un pedido que ella no puede surtir es por esto que está solicitando un crédito de US $475 para pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Nora Elia podrá comprar la mercancía que le están solicitando. Además de comprar productos extras para poder tener variedad para ofrecerle a sus clientes. Con tu ayuda Nora Elia podrá salir delante y crecer su negocio a pasos firmes.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise to supply her business orders.

loans.name: Nervith

texts.es:
Nervith is a member of the communal bank Siempre Unidas (together forever) of the district of Tarapoto, San Martin Province, San Martin district. She owns a business located in the Jr Ricardo Palma 1292. She started her business 36 years ago when she was very young and single, with only a sewing machine. She would sew for her friends in the beginning and later started making uniforms for institutions such as the Health Department and the National University of San Martin among others.

With the loan of S/.1,000.00, which she will pay back in 6 months, she will buy rolls of cloth to make towels, children's dresses to send to rural communities, clothing for underwear, buttons and thread wholesale, and assorted sewing accessories. Currently she has renovated her sewing machine and bought a mending machine. She will also buy cloth to make bed sheets and sell them at affordable prices.

Mrs. Nervith is 54 years old. She has two daughters who are professionals but are not working yet. This independent job has allowed her to let her daughters study. Also, she has studied High Couture in the city of Lima. With her good work and high quality finishes liked by her customers, she has increased her clientele and she feels very satisfied being able to help her husband and contribute to the household finances.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga and son, Kiva volunteers.

Nervith es socia del Banco Comunal Siempre Unidas del distrito de Tarapoto, provincia de San Martín, departamento de San Martín. Posee un negocio ubicado en el Jr Ricardo Palma 1292. Inició el negocio hace 36 años cuando era muy joven y soltera sólo con una máquina de coser, la costura era para sus amigas inicialmente y posteriormente comenzó a elaborar uniformes para instituciones como el Ministerio de Salud, la Universidad Nacional de San Martín entre otros.

Con el préstamo de S/.1000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará telas en fardos para confeccionar toallas, vestidos para niños para enviar a las localidades rurales, telas para ropa interior, botones en taper, hilos en docenas y accesorios de costura. Actualmente ha renovado su máquina y comprado una remalladora. También comprará tela para confeccionar sábanas y venderlas a precios cómodos.

La señora Nervith tiene 54 años, dos hijas que son profesionales, pero que todavía no trabajan. Este trabajo independiente le ha permitido hacer estudiar a sus hijas, además estudió en la ciudad de Lima Alta Costura. Con su buen trabajo y acabado de la costura (que gusta a sus clientes) le ha permitido aumentar su clientela y se siente muy satisfecha en apoyar a su esposo y aportar a la economía del hogar.

loans.use: Buying supplies to make clothes (Compra de insumos para la confección de ropa.)

loans.name: Orla

texts.es:
Mrs. Orla is a member of the communal bank La Amistad (friendship), she lives in the San Martin region, Moyobamba province and district. Her business is a stand at the market Erik in the city of Moyabamba. Her economic activity is selling fruits and vegetables, many of them planted and harvested in her own chacra (small farm) and others that come from the coast. She also offers a service of local transportation.

Thanks to the support of Manuela Ramos, and her husband and children, Mrs. Orla is a woman who has been able to increase her business and acquire a motorcar to transport her products from her small farm to the market, and offer local transportation services.

With the loan of S/.1,000, which will be paid back in 6 months, she will buy sacks of vegetables, such as potatoes, onions, cabbage, lettuce, tomatoes, peppers, and fruits like boxes of papayas, bunches of green bananas, as well as two wheels for her motorcar.

Mrs. Orla is 36 years old and lives with her husband and two children. She is a very energetic, persevering person, who is working so that in the near future she may have a general store set up in her own home.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga and son, Kiva volunteers.

La señora Orla es socia del Banco Comunal “La Amistad”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia y distrito de Moyobamba. Su negocio funciona en un puesto del Mercado Erik de la ciudad de Moyabamba, su actividad económica es la venta de verduras y frutas, muchos de ellos sembrados y cosechados en su propia chacra y otros que traen de la costa y también brinda servicio de movilidad local.

Es una mujer que gracias al apoyo de Manuela Ramos y de su esposo e hijos, ha logrado incrementar su negocio y adquirir un motocarro para trasladar sus productos de la chacra al mercado y hacer movilidad local.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará verduras en sacos como papas, cebollas, repollo, lechugas, tomates, ajíes, frutas como papayas en cajas, guineos en racimos y también dos llantas para su motocarro

La señora Orla tiene 36 años y vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos, es una persona con mucha energía, perseverante y está trabajando para que en un futuro cercano tener una bodega de abarrotes instalada en su propia casa.

loans.use: Buying fruits and vegetables (Compra de verduras y frutas)

loans.name: Rosa Isabel

texts.es:
Rosa Isabel belongs to the "La Amistad" communal bank and lives in the San Martin region, province and district of Moyabamba. Her home and business are located in the same house and she sell grocieries.

With a loan from Manuel Ramos she increased her start-up capital and with subsequent loans she received was able to increase her investment in the business in accordance with her customers' demands.

With another loan, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will buy rice, sugar (in sacks), milk, eggs and other products such as sweets, which are requested daily by her customers.

Rosa Isabel is 58, she is separated from her husband and lives with her older daughter, who is a great support. She is a joyful woman, creative and very enterprising. Her next project for the short term is to be able to have a poultry shop.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Rosa Isabel pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Amistad”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia y distrito D. Moyabamba, su domicilio y negocio están ubicados en su propia casa y se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes al por menor.

Con el apoyo del préstamo D. Manuela Ramos ha aumentado su capital inicial D. su negocio y así como el primero los demás préstamos que recibió le sirven para ir incrementando el capital del negocio D. acuerdo a la demanda D. sus clientes.

Con el préstamo, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará arroz, azúcar (en sacos), leche en cajas, huevos en javas y otros productos como golosinas, las cuales diariamente son solicitados por sus clientes.

La señora Rosa Isabel tiene 58 años, está separada D. su esposo, vive con su hija mayor quien es su gran apoyo. Es una mujer con mucha alegría, creatividad y muy emprendedora, su próximo proyecto en el corto plazo es poder tener una pollería.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries (rice, sugar, milk, eggs, etc.)

loans.name: Ruth Angelica

texts.es:
Ruth Angelica is a member of the La Primavera communal bank and lives in the province and district of Moyobamba. She and her husband have started an academy for teaching the Marinera and other Peruvian folk dances. She also sells and rents typical outfits and makes Marinera outfits for her students. She decide to start up this business because where she lives people were looking for these outfits and there was not any place that sold or rented them. She now has a good supply of outfits to rent. She is a very happy, enterprising and optimistic person, and this helps her to have good clients and many students for her academy.

A loan, which will be repaid in 6 months, will buy materials to make the outfits, such as fabric, sewing and embroidery thread in different colors, ornamental decorations and the like, so that she has in stock a good quantity of outfits for the different regional dances.

She is 34 and has three children. Her husband supports her both in her business and work about the house, so that she can take care of her housework and the academy at the same time and most of all, take care of the requests for outfits which take a lot of time and patience to make. She is content because of her achievements, and she has a steady clientele. Her goal is to have her own locale so that she can better promote her academy and also to have on hand many typical outfits from all of Peru.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Ruth Angelica es socia del banco comunal La Primavera, vive en la Av. Canana No 458 de la provincia y distrito de Moyobamba. Ella y su esposo han puesto una academia de Marinera y danzas folclóricas del Perú, también vende y alquila trajes típicos y confecciona los trajes de Marinera de sus alumnos. Decidió iniciar un negocio porque donde vive la gente buscaba los trajes y no había quien los vendiera o alquilara, ahora ya tiene una buena cantidad de trajes para alquilar. Ella es una persona muy alegre, emprendedora y optimista y eso le ayuda para tener buenos clientes y poder mantener la academia con bastantes alumnos.

El préstamo, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará materiales para confeccionar más trajes, como telas en metros, hilos para coser y bordar de diferentes colores, adornos como grecas, blondas y así tener en stock buena cantidad de trajes de diversas danzas de las regiones del país.

Tiene 34 años tres hijos, su esposo la apoya en su negocio y en las labores de la casa para que ella pueda atender las labores domésticas y la academia a la vez y sobre todo atender los pedidos de los trajes que toma bastante tiempo y paciencia en hacerlo. Está contenta por sus logros obtenidos y tiene su clientela segura. Su meta es tener un local propio para mejorar el marketing de su academia y tener bastantes trajes típicos de todo el Perú.

loans.use: Purchase materials for making typical regional outfits.

loans.name: Sarela Lorenza

texts.es:
Sarela Lorenza is a member of the La Amistad del Dorado communal bank, in the province and district of Moyabamba, department of San Martin. She sells groceries from a space located in her own house. What motivated her to start this business was the desire to continue educating her children, and in addition she enjoys being in contact with her friends and clients.

A loan, which will be repaid in 4 months, will buy various groceries such as different brands of soap, packages of toilet paper, canned fish, liters of oil, so that she can offer them to her clients.

She is 48 years old, has 2 children who are pursuing higher education and who support her, along with her husband, in attending the business. She has always distinguished herself as a hard-working woman, responsible for the work she assumes.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Sarela Lorenza es socia del Banco Comunal La Amistad del Dorado de la provincia y distrito de Moyabamba, departamento de San Martín. Se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en un ambiente ubicado en su propia casa. Lo que la motivo a dedicarse a este negocio eran las ganas que tenía de continuar dando estudios a sus dos hijos y además le gusta estar en contacto permanente con sus amigos y clientes.

El préstamo, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará diversos abarrotes como cajas de jabón por cada marca, papel higiénico en paquetes, conservas de pescado, aceite por litros, todo ello para ofertar a sus clientes.

Tiene 48 años, dos hijos que están cursando estudios superiores y quienes la apoyan junto a su esposo en la atención del negocio. Siempre se ha destacado por ser una mujer trabajadora y responsable con las labores asumidas

loans.use: Purchase of groceries (soap, toilet paper, canned foods, oil, etc.)

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
Teresa belongs to the "Las Margaritas" Grupo Mientras Tanto (a "Grupo Mientras Tanto" is an interim group of borrowers not large enough to form a communal bank), and lives in the province of San Martin, district of La Banda de Shilcayo. She sells medicine and first aid supplies.

She shares the responsibilities her home with her husband and has four children, but currently only cares for a grandson. Her husband also supports her in the business since he is a health technician at a hospital, and with the help of a microcredit she has been able to expand her business.

With a loan, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy medicines such as analgesics, antipyretics and material for giving injections, which is most in demand.

Teresa is 61 years old and is a woman who for most of her life has worked in rural zones where she learned to serve persons with many health needs; this motivated her to learn more about medicine, with her husband advising her. She is happy to be able to help others with her business, which has no set hours and is always at the service of people.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Teresa pertenece al Grupo Mientras Tanto “Las Margaritas”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia de San Martín, distrito de La Banda de Shilcayo, su domicilio y negocio están ubicados en el Jr. Césa Vallejo Nº 217 Asociación de Vivienda San Juan y se dedica a la venta de medicinas para primeros auxilios.

Las responsabilidades del hogar las comparte con su esposo, tiene cuatro hijos, pero actualmente sólo tiene a cargo a un nieto, el esposo también la apoya en el negocio ya que es Técnico Sanitario en un hospital y con la ayuda del microcrédito ha podido implementar más su negocio.

Con el préstamo, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará medicinas como analgésicos, antipiréticos en cajas y material para dar servicio de inyectables que son los que tienen mayor movimiento diario en el negocio.

La señora Teresa tiene 61 años y es una mujer que la mayor parte de su vida ha trabajado por zonas rurales donde aprendió a servir a personas con muchas necesidades de salud y esto la motiva a aprender más sobre el mundo de la medicina con el asesoramiento de su esposo. Se siente feliz de poder servir a los demás con un negocio que no tiene horario definido y que siempre está al servicio de las personas.

loans.use: Purchase of medicines.

location.town: La Banda de Shilcayo - San Martín

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es:
Ana María is 45 years old, studied through the third year of secondary school, and has 5 children, with 3 still dependent on her. She lives in the district of Salaverry in the Province of Trujillo in the Department of La Libertad. Ana works selling food at her stand to people in her neighborhood, and to all the passers-by. She also sells pasteles and desserts. Previously, she delivered food and boarded workers from different factories. For 15 years, she worked in this business. She tells us that before becoming a member of the "Las Auroras en Accion" (Daybreak in Action) Communal Bank, she sold a smaller quantity, since she did not have much capital. Now she feels very satisfied, because the loans she has received have allowed her to grow and improve her business.

At her "Las Auroras en Acción” Communal Bank, she obtained her first loan of 300 soles. With this, she bought the products she uses to prepare the foods she sells at wholesale, such as: oil, potatoes, noodles, rice, and soft drinks.

With this loan of 1,000 soles, with a term of four months, she will buy chairs, dishes, knives, forks and spoons to provide better service and convenience to her customers.

Ana dreams of having a large restaurant in the center of Salaverry.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

La señora Ana María tiene 45 años de edad, estudió hasta el tercer año de secundaria; tiene 5 hijos y 3 aún dependen de ella. Vive en el distrito de Salaverry en la Provincia de Trujillo del Departamento de La Libertad. La señora Ana se dedica a la venta de comida en su kiosco a personas de su barrio y todos los transeúntes, pero además vende pasteles y postres, anteriormente repartía comida y daba pensión a algunos trabajadores de diferentes fábricas, hace 15 años que se dedica a este negocio. Nos cuenta que antes de ser socia del Banco Comunal “Las Auroras en Acción” vendía en menor cantidad ya que no tenía mucho capital, ahora se siente muy contenta porque los créditos que ha recibido le han permitido crecer y mejorar su negocio. En su Banco Comunal “Las Auroras en Acción” obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.300 soles, con ellos compró al por mayor los productos que utiliza para la preparación de los alimentos que vende como: aceite, papa, fideo, arroz y gaseosas. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000 soles, que cancelará en cuatro meses, comprará sillas, platos, cucharas, tenedores y cuchillos para brindar mejor servicio y comodidad a sus clientes. La señora Ana sueña con tener un restaurante grande en el centro de Salaverry.

loans.use: Purchase of goods

loans.name: Elisa

texts.es:
Elisa is 33, married and has 2 children who are 13 and 5 years old. Elisa lives in the area of Santo Domingo, in the town of Muyurina, district of Jesus Nazareno. She is a member of the "Musuq Wasi" communal bank, which means "New House" in Quechua.

She and her husband work in agriculture and plant vegetables such as beets, spinach, cauliflower, coriander, and green onions, depending on market demand and time of year. In addition to growing vegetables, Elisa buys vegetables from producers and sells them wholesale at the Nery Garcia market; she does not have a stand and just distributes them to wholesalers. She also brings green onion seeds from Lima and from Huacho and sells them to the farms in her community and in the rest of the valley.

Elisa needs a loan which will be invested in the purchase of green onion seeds. She has belonged to the "Musuq Wasi" communal bank for 12 years and in this time she says she has learned to be responsible, punctual and most of all, to save.

Her savings are earmarked to buy a television, equipment or for a household emergency. Her dream is for her children become profesisonals and to be able to build a house out of sturdy materials.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

Elisa tiene 33 años, es casada y tiene 2 hijos de 13 y 5 años. Elisa vive en el anexo de Santo Domingo, centro poblado de Muyurina, en el Distrito de Jesús Nazareno. Elisa es socia del Banco Comunal “Musuq Wasi” que quiere decir “Nueva Casa” en quechua.

Ella y su esposo se dedican a la agricultura y siembran verduras como betarraga, espinaca, coliflor, lechuga, culantro, cebolla china dependiendo, de la demanda del mercado y de la época. Pero además de sembrar verduras, Elisa compra verduras de los productores y los vende al por mayor en el Mercado Nery García; no tiene un puesto, solo reparte a los mayoristas. También trae semillas de cebolla china de la ciudad de Lima, y de Huacho para luego venderlos en las chacras de su comunidad y en el resto del valle.

Elisa necesita un préstamo que serán invertidos en la compra de semillas de cebolla china. Elisa pertenece al Banco Comunal "Musuq Wasi" desde hace 12 ciclos y en este tiempo ella dice que ha aprendido a ser responsable, puntual y sobre todo a ahorrar.

Sus ahorros serán destinados en la compra de televisor, equipo o cualquier emergencia del hogar. El sueño de Elisa es que sus hijos sean profesionales y poder hacer una casa de material noble.

loans.use: Purchase seeds for planting green onions.

loans.name: Marciano

texts.es:
Marciano Z. is 47 years old and has been married for 23 years to Ermelinda who is 45 years old. They have two daughters, one of which is in school and the other is an adult and thanks to her parents has already finished her university education.

15 years ago he started with a small grocery store in his home where he sells all types of basic products such as milk, sugar, flour, rice, fruits, vegetables, etc. Before, his wife worked selling crafts, but now she helps him run his business, because it is the most important and most frequented store in the city.

Now he hopes to buy more merchandise such as various drinks and basic products such as flour, herbs, noodles and rice in large quantities because at this time of year his sales increase considerably.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Marciano Z. es un señor de 47 años de edad casado hace más de 23 años con Sra. Ermelinda de 45 años de edad. Tienen 2 hijas una en edad escolar y la otra ya es mayor de edad y gracias a sus padres ya ha culminado sus estudios universitarios.

Hace 15 años empezó con una pequeña despensa en su domicilio en donde vende todo tipo de productos de primera necesidad como leche, azúcar, harina, arroz, frutas, vegetales, etc. Anteriormente su esposa trabaja en las ventas de artesanías, pero actualmente lo ayuda con la atención del negocio, ya que es el centro de compra más importante y concurrida de la ciudad.

Ahora desea comprar más mercaderías como ser: bebidas en general y artículos de primera necesidad como: harina, yerba, fideos y arroz en grandes cantidades ya que en esta época del año aumentan considerablemente las ventas.

loans.use: purchase of sodas, juices, mineral water, flour, rice, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Gladis

texts.es:
Gladis lives in the San Martin region of the province and district of Lamas and is a founding partner of the Los Chancas Communal Bank. For 28 years now, she has been selling cosmetics and for the last 8 years she has been running a restaurant selling prepared meals and sodas. Both are situated in her home in Pasaje Los Jardines Nº 100.

She is separated from her husband and has 5 children who are now professionals. She began her business casually, when a friend observed her charisma and personality and offered her this job, which she accepted with her faith in doing things the right way. That was how she began winning over clients one by one, house by house and now they are very faithful to her, so much so that she receives orders daily. Likewise, clients and friends go to her restaurant given the excellent treatment and customer service she offers.

With the loan of S/. 1,000.00, which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy beauty products to increase her stock at home and take advantage of the bargains the companies she works with offer. She will also buy ingredients like meats of different varieties by the kilogram, vegetables, legumes and other products for the preparation of the dishes in her restaurant at her client’s request.

Gladis is a jovial and enthusiastic woman, and with the joy that characterizes her, she dreams of reaching old age in tranquility and surrounded by her children.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Gladis vive en la región de San Martín, provincia y distrito de Lamas, es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal Los Chancas, desde hace 28 años se dedica a la venta de cosméticos y desde hace 8 tiene un restaurante de venta de comidas y bebidas gasificadas, ambos ubicados en su domicilio en el Pasaje Los Jardines Nº 100 (en la parte alta de la ciudad de Lamas). Es separada de su esposo y con 5 hijos profesionales. Se inició en el negocio ocasionalmente, cuando un amigo observó su personalidad y carisma le ofreció este trabajo, el cual lo aceptó con la confianza de hacer bien la cosas, es así que fue ganando clientes uno a uno, casa por casa y ahora ya los tiene fidelizados, tan es así que los pedidos le llegan a diario, igualmente en su restaurante llegan clientes y amigos dado el buen trato y el buen servicio que se les brinda. Con el préstamo de S/.1,000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará artículos de belleza para aumentar el stock que posee en su casa y aprovechar las ofertas de las empresas con quienes trabaja, así mismo comprará los insumos como carnes en kilos en sus diferentes variedades, verdura, menestras y otros productos para la preparación de platos según lo requieran los clientes del restaurante. Gladis es una mujer muy jovial y entusiasta, con la alegría que le caracteriza sueña con tener una vejez tranquila rodeada de sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase beauty products and ingredients to prepare the dishes in her restaurant.

loans.name: Guillermina

texts.es:
Guillermina lives in the region of San Martín, in the province and district of Lamas. She is a member of the community bank Los Chancos, and owns a business of sales of materials for making dresses. She combines this business with the sales of canned and imported products. She stores her inventory in her home. She has been developing these two businesses for 10 and 15 years, respectively.

Thanks to her effort and the experience she has gained in sales and client service since she was a young girl, and thanks to the loans she receives from the community bank, she has been able to continue the family business in the sales of seamstress materials and shoes while adding her business of imported products. Many of her good clients are her friends and work colleagues, since she also works as a government employee.

Wih the loan of 3000 soles (Peruvian currency), which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy tins of cheese, cured meats, and fruit. She will buy these products in the city of Iquitos, by trading the queso fresco (a fresh cheese) produced in her area. This way she will be able to fill her pending orders.

Guillermina is separated from her husband. She has a young daughter she wants to see grow into a professional. She works tirelessly to attain her goals and to be able to have a better seamstress materials store very soon.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Guillermina vive en la región de San Martín, provincia y distrito de Lamas, es socia del Banco Comunal Los Chancas y tiene como negocio la venta de mercería para la confección de vestidos y lo combina con la venta de productos enlatados e importados, los mismos que lo tiene almacenado en su domicilio del Jr. Tobías Noriega Nº 168 , estos negocios los viene desarrollando hace 10 y 5 años respectivamente.

Gracias al esfuerzo y la experiencia que desde pequeña tiene en las ventas y atención al cliente y a los préstamos que viene recibiendo del Banco Comunal, ha podido continuar el negocio familiar de la venta de mercería y zapatos, y adicionar a esta la de productos importados, que es ofertado y adquirido entre sus amigos y compañeros de trabajo, ya que también se desempaña como empleada estatal.

Con el préstamo de S/ 3,000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará latas de quesos, embutidos de carne y frutas, estos productos los compra en la ciudad de Iquitos, los mismos que son intercambiados (trueque) por queso fresco que se produce en la zona y así cumplir con los pedidos pendientes que tiene.

Guillermina es separada de su esposo y con una hijita a quien quiere verla hecha toda una profesional. Trabaja incansablemente y de esa manera alcanzar sus metas y poder tener muy pronto una tienda de mercería mejor implementada.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise (cheeses, cured meats and sausages, meat, and fruit)

loans.name: Ines

texts.es:
Inés is a member of the community bank La Amistad del Dorado, located in the province and district of Moyobamba in the department (region) of San Martín. She works selling a variety of sweets in the principal schools of the city as well as in the central plaza.

Her siblings motivated her to develop this business. She considers the loan she received from the community bank a great help because it allowed her to build an inventory of a wider variety of products, including the products most in demand among her young clients.

With the loan of 500 soles (Peruvian currency) which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy a larger quantity of chocolate, cookies and waffles in packages, boxes of gum, popular sweets known as chisitos, fried potato sticks, candies in bags and packages of soft drinks.

Inés is very optimistic at the age of 41. She very much likes what she does, especially the daily contact with her young clients, together with her husband and her three children, who always support her. Inés wishes to further develop herself every day as a woman and a business person.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Inés es socia del Banco Comunal “La Amistad del Dorado”, ubicado en la provincia y distrito de Moyobamba, departamento de San Martín, se dedica a la venta de golosinas en sus diferentes variedades, los mismos que ofrece en las principales escuelas y colegios de la localidad así como en la plaza principal.

Fueron sus hermanos quienes la motivaron desarrollar este negocio y considera que el préstamo recibido del banco comunal es de gran ayuda porque le permite surtir y variar los productos que vende y que son requeridos mayormente por los niños.

Con el préstamo de S/. 500.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará mayor cantidad de chocolates, galletas y waffle en paquetes, chicles por cajas, chisitos, papitas fritas por tiras y caramelos en bolsas y bebidas gasificadas en paquetes. Inés con sus 41 años se muestra muy optimista, le gusta mucho lo que hace sobre todo el contacto diario que tiene con sus pequeños clientes, junto a su esposo y sus tres hijos, que siempre lo apoyan, desea desarrollarse cada día más como mujer y como negociante.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise (chocolates, cookies, waffles, etc.)

loans.name: Maria Hermelinda

texts.es:
Mrs. Maria Hermelinda is an associate of the communal bank “La Amistad del Dorado” which is located in the provincial city of Moyobamba in the state of San Martín. She dedicates herself to the sale of snacks at local schools, colleges and public institutions as well as the town’s main square. She began in this business helping her sister. With what she learned, she decided to break away from her sister and start her own business. With the first loan she received from the communal bank, she is able to provide a greater variety of goods that requested by children and adults alike. With this loan of 700 soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she plans to purchase an even greater assortment of chocolates, packaged cookies and waffles, gum in bulk, puffed cheese snacks (chisitos), potato chips, candy and fruit juice drinks. At age 44, Inés is a woman very concerned with seeing her children come out ahead. Her dream is to have her own home from where she can start selling groceries.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria Hermelinda es socia del Banco Comunal “La Amistad del Dorado”, ubicado en la provincia y distrito de Moyobamba, departamento de San Martín, se dedica a la venta de golosinas en sus diferentes variedades, los mismos que ofrece en las principales escuelas, colegios e instituciones públicas y privadas de la comunidad y también en su plaza principal. Fue su hermana quien la inició en este negocio y se desempeño como ayudante para luego motivarse en desarrollar su propio negocio. Con el primer préstamo que recibió del banco comunal hasta la actualidad lo mantiene surtido y variado con todo tipo de productos que vende y que son requeridos mayormente por pequeños y adultos. Con el préstamo de S/. 700.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará una mayor cantidad de chocolates, galletas y waffle en paquetes, chicles por cajas, chisitos, papitas fritas por tiras y caramelos en bolsas y frugos de frutas en cajas. Inés con sus 44 años es una mujer muy preocupada por sus hijos para sacarlos adelante. Sueña con tener una casa propia y en ella implementar un negocio de venta de abarrotes.

loans.use:
Purchase of merchandise (chocolates, cookies, waffle, etc.)

Compra de mercadería (chocolates, galletas, waffle, etc)

loans.name: Lucinda Group

texts.es:
The communal bank "Lucinda" started 1 year and 8 months ago. Currently, they have 8 cycles and 24 members. From being a part of the bank, the members have learned to be punctual, honest, and how to invest in a business. They also say that they have passed through difficult times in the bank, but also through happiness, and this has brought them closer together as friends. They also like it because they can get away, laugh, and learn.

The members have different businesses like selling vegetables, groceries, cereal, firewood, fruit, agricultural products, fish, books, candies, clothing, tubers, and making bread. Each member has a different history, like Margot, who started selling books in her home and now has a large bookstore. She will soon open a restaurant. On the other hand, Edith will use the loan to buy merchandise for her grocery business, which is located in the Las Américas market.

The members need different sums of money. Some amounts of the loans are 200, 400, 600, and 1000 soles. There will be a total of 13,100 soles in loans for the communal bank. The loans will be invested in buying medicine, vitamins, cabbage, carrots, celery, sweaters, pants, polo shirts, bread, peaches, plantains, flour to make bread, and fish. Their savings will be used to increase the capital of their businesses, constructing or improving their houses, a sickness that could arise, their kids' education, or enrollment in a university. The dreams of the members are to see their children become professionals and to have larger and more stable businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

El Banco Comunal Lucinda es un Banco Comunal que se inició hace 1 año y 8 meses; actualmente tiene 8 ciclos y 24 socias. Las socias cuentan que en su Banco Comunal aprendieron a ser puntuales, honestas, cómo invertir en el negocio. También dicen que el Banco Comunal pasó por muchas dificultades y también alegrías que las unió más como amigas, además que les gusta mucho las reuniones porque se distraen, ríen y además aprenden.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como L. venta D. verduras, abarrotes, cereales, leña, frutas, productos agropecuarios, pescado, libros, golosinas, ropa, tubérculos y elaboración D. panes. Cada socia tiene una historia diferente como es el caso D. Margot quien empezó vendiendo libros a domicilio y en L. actualidad tiene una librería granD. y próximamente va a abrir un restaurante. Por otro lado Edith utilizará el préstamo para comprar más mercadería para su negocio D. venta D. abarrotes, que está ubicado en el mercado Las Américas.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos. Algunos préstamos son D. 200 soles, 400 soles, 600 soles, 1000 soles, haciendo un total D. 13,100 soles D. préstamos en el Banco Comunal. Los préstamos lo invertirán en L. compra D. medicinas, inyectables, vitaminas, col, zanahoria, apio, cebolL., chompas, pantalones, polos, panetones, durazno, plátano, harina para L. preparación D. panteones y pescado.

Sus ahorros los utilizarán para aumentar el capital D. su negocio, construir o mejorar su casa, alguna enfermedad que se pueda presentar, los estudios D. sus hijos, matrícuL. en L. universidad. Los sueños D. las socias son que sus hijos sean buenos profesionales, tener negocios más grandes y estables.

loans.use: The members need different amounts of money for their loans.  Different amounts include 200, 400, 600, and 1000 soles.  The toal will be 13,100 soles for the communal bank.  The loans will be invested in the purchase of medicine, vitamins, cabbage, carrots, celery, onions, sweaters, pants, polo shirts, bread, peaches, plantains, flour to make bread, and fish.

loans.name: Rosa Sandra

texts.es:
Mrs. Rosa Sandra is a member of "Jasmine" Banco Comunal . She was born in Alto Amazonas province, Yurimaguas district. She has lived in Moyabamba City for 5 years and now sells lots of different items. Some of the items are: lotions, deodorants, sewing thread, scissors, etc. These are items are sold in the little booth that she has in the central market of the city. She also walks around the city and tries to find more people who would buy her items. She lives in Jr. El Dorado number 196 of the Moyabamba district, San Martin department.

The credit she requests, which will be re-paid within 6 months, wil be used to purchase Christmas supplies. She will also bring more merchandise to sell to her clients. She would like to have a wide variety of items because she would like her clients to find what they are looking for. Not only does she sell her goods in Moyabamba, on Sundays she travels to other town and tries to sell her goods at the fairs.

She is 27 years old and has two children, one boy and one girl. She is happy because she has her husband's support and they both work the business they run. Her goal is to find her own permanent spot and not have to go on such long walks like she does right now.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Rosa Sandra es socia del Banco Comunal “ Los jazmines”, es natural de la provincia de Alto Amazonas, distrito de Yurimaguas, hace 5 años que vive en la ciudad de Moyabamba y desde entonces se dedica a la venta de artículos de mercería como ungüentos, frotaciones de diferentes marcas, desodorantes, hilos de coser, tijeras, etc., estos artículos los vende en el puesto que tiene en el mercado central de esta ciudad, además recorre el mercado y alrededores para buscar vender mas día a día. Vive en el jr. El Dorado No 196 del distrito y provincia de Moyabamba, departamento de San Martín. El crédito de S/. 1 000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará artículos con motivos navideños, además con ello aprovechará la campaña navideña para traer más mercadería y ofrecer a sus clientes. Le gusta tener bien surtido su negocio porque quiere que sus clientes encuentren lo que buscan, además no sólo vende en Moyabamba, los domingos sale a otros distritos a vender en las ferias que se dan en los pueblos cercanos. Tiene 27 años y dos hijos, un varón y una mujer, está contenta porque cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo y ambos se dedican al negocio. Su meta es contar con un puesto propio y de esa manera descansar un poco de las caminatas que da todos los días.

loans.use: Purchase of Christmas decorations

loans.name: Dinh Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Dinh Thi H., 51 years old, living in Nghi Loc, Nghe An, is one example of being able to overcome poverty. Before joining the TYM fund, her whole family had only 2 cottages to live in. Since her husband’s death, Mrs. H. has been working and raising her 4 children on her own. Loaning is also very difficult for her family. In 2002, she borrowed 60 USD from the fund to do business on wells. Currently, she already owned a 3-suite house, a television and a motorcycle. With her income of 4 USD/day, she intends to borrow 625 USD to buy more building materials to make wells.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Đinh Thị Hường, 51 tuổi, sống tại Nghi Lộc, Nghệ An là một trong những tấm gương điển hình về xóa đói giảm nghèo. Trước khi tham gia vào Quỹ gia đình chị chỉ có hai gian nhà tranh, chồng chị đã mất, một mình chị Hường lao động để nuôi 4 con đang trong độ tuổi ăn học. Việc vay vốn đối với gia đình chị cũng hết sức khó khăn. Năm 2002, khi có Quỹ về chị đã vay vốn với mức vay 60USD dùng vào buôn bán, làm cống giếng. Đến nay chị đã xây được ba gian nhà và mua sắm được ti vi, xe máy. Với mức thu nhập mỗi ngày là 4USD chị dự tính xin vay 625USD để mua nguyên vật liệu làm cống giếng.

loans.use: Buy building materials to make well

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi H., 43 years old, is living with her husband and 3 children in Nghi Loc, Nghe An. Before joining the TYM fund, her whole family income depended on their several rice fields. 5 years ago, she talked to her family and took the courage to borrow money from the fund to buy the husking machines. This activity is very economically effective. Her current income is 100 USD/month. Her family has already overcome the poverty and becomes an exemplary business. She intends to borrow 325 USD to buy more unhusked rice.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hạnh, 43 tuổi, hiện đang sống cùng chồng và 3 con tại Nghi Lộc, Nghệ An. Khi chưa tham gia vào Quỹ thì cả gia đình chị chỉ trông chờ vào vài sào ruộng. Cách đây 5 năm chị đă bàn bạc với gia đình và mạnh dạn vay vốn của Quỹ về đầu tư mua máy xay xát. Hoạt động này mang lại hiệu quả kinh tế cao, mức thu nhập của chị Hạnh hiện nay là 100USD/tháng. Gia đình chị đã thực sự thoát nghèo và là tấm gương điển hình của quỹ về việc làm ăn kinh tế giỏi. Dự định chị xin vay thêm 325USD để mua thêm lúa gạo xay xát.

loans.use: Buy rice to husk

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Tran Thi H., 49 years old, joined the TYM fund since September of 2001. With her first loan of 60USD, she invested it in breeding animals and the yield was very satisfactory. Since the beginning of the third year, she uses her income from breeding animals and her loan to open a grocery store. After 6 years of joining the fund, Mrs. H. uses her loan very effectively. With an income of 150 USD/month, she intends to borrow 875USD to expand her store with more merchandise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Trần Thị H., 49 tuổi, tham gia vào quỹ từ tháng 9 năm 2001. Với mức vay đầu tiên là 60USD, chị đã đầu tư vào chăn nuôi và thu được những kết quả tốt. Bắt đầu vào năm thứ 3, thu nhập từ chăn nuôi và đồng vốn vay được chị đầu tư vào mở cửa hàng buôn bán các mặt hàng hóa bánh kẹo bia rượu, giày dép .v.v... Sau 6 năm tham gia những đồng vốn vay được chị H. sử dụng rất có hiệu quả. Với mức thu nhập 150USD/tháng, dự định trong thời gian tới chị sẽ xin vay 875USD để mở rộng các mặt hàng kinh doanh.

loans.use: Buy goods for her grocery store

loans.name: Belen Group

texts.es:
The Banco Comunal Belen is a young bank that was started one year ago. Currently, there are four cycles and 27 partners. Maritza, Hortensia, Juana, Eulogio and Felicitas are the founding partners of the Banco Comunal. The partners tell us that through the Banco Comunal, they learn how to be punctual, responsible, to save and they say that all the partners are friends and colleagues.

The partners are involved in different businesses such as the sale of food, fruit, shoes, clothes, cereals, and cosmetics, as well as small grocery stores, appliance repair services, and the making of agriculture tools. Each partner has a different history, such as is the case of Hortensia who worked as an employee in a store and, at the same time, traveled to markets bringing clothes to sell. At first, she brought little merchandise, but presently, she has more merchandise and stock and she sells second-hand clothes. Julia also sells second-hand clothes. At first, she had very little merchandise. Now, her business has grown and she has more customers. She also breeds guinea pigs. Julia has noted that one year ago she had six guinea pigs but now she has 58, which she sells to restaurants.

The partners need loans in different amounts. Some amounts are of 200 soles, 400 soles, 600 soles and 800 soles totaling a loan amount of 12,200 soles to the Banco Comunal. These loans will be invested in the purchase of baby clothes, pants, sweaters, cosmetics, tools, carbon stone, spare parts, transistors, integrated circuits, filters, fabric for ponchos for the Carnival celebrations, apples, bananas, papaya, shoes and products for the start of a small café and rental of premises.

They will use their savings to buy necessities for the home and education for their children. The partners’ dreams are that their businesses grow and are commercially great, to have their own premises and that their children are able to find better jobs.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

El Banco Comunal Belén es un banco joven que se inició hace 1 año. Actualmente tiene 4 ciclos y 27 socias. Maritza, Hortensia, Juana, Eulogio y Felicitas son las socias fundadoras del Banco Comunal. Las socias nos cuentan que en el Banco Comunal las socias aprendieron a ser puntuales, responsables, a ahorrar, y dicen que todas las socias son amigas y compañeras. Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como L. venta D. comida, frutas, calzado, ropa, cereales, cosméticos, abarrotes, servicios D. reparación D. electrodomésticos y fabricación D. herramientas agrícolas. Cada socia tiene una historia diferente como es el caso D. Hortensia que trabajaba en una tienda como empleada y a L. vez viajaba a las ferias llevando ropa para vender. En un inicio llevaba muy poca mercadería, pero en L. actualidad elL. tiene más mercadería y surtida, y además, venD. ropa D. segunda mano. Por otro lado Julia también venD. ropa D. segunda mano. En un inicio tenía muy poca mercadería, ahora su negocio ha crecido y tiene más clientes, además cría cuyes. Julia cuenta que hace 1 año elL. tenía 6 cuyes pero ahora tiene 58 cuyes, que venD. a los recreos y restaurantes. Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos, algunos montos son D. 200 soles, 400 soles, 600 soles, 800 soles, haciendo un total D. 12,200 soles D. préstamos en el Banco Comunal. Los préstamos lo invertirán en L. compra D. ropa D. bebé, pantalones, chompas, cosméticos, fierros, carbón D. piedra, repuestos, transistores, circuitos integrados, filtros, telas para L. confección D. ponchos para las fiestas D. carnaval, manzanas, plátano, papaya, zapatos, en productos para L. implementación D. un cafetín y en el alquiler D. un local. Los ahorros los utilizarán para comprar algún bien para su hogar y para L. educación D. sus hijos. Los sueños D. las socias es que sus negocios crezcan y sean grandes comerciantes, tener un local propio y que sus hijos sean mejores que ellas con una profesión.

loans.use: The partners need loans in different amounts. Some amounts are of 200 soles, 400 soles, 600 soles and 800 soles totaling a loan amount of 12,200 soles to the Banco Comunal. These loans will be invested in the purchase of baby clothes, pants, sweaters, cosmetics, tools, carbon stone, spare parts, transistors, integrated circuits, filters, fabric for ponchos for the Carnival celebrations, apples, bananas, papaya, shoes and products for the start of a small café and rental of premises.

loans.name: Vo Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Vo Thi L., 36 years old, is living with her husband and 3 children in Nghi Loc, Nghe An. She joined TYM fund in 2001. Besides working on the famiL.'s rice field (0.7 acre), her main activity is to raise pigs. In order to buy piglets and mash, she decided to join the fund. Her first loan was 60 USD, enough for her to breed 2 pigs. Now, she has 6-7 pigs already. After 5 loans, her repayment and business are very advantageous. With an income of 150 USD/month, she intends to borrow 950 USD to buy more piglets and mash to expand and improve her pig-breeding model.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Võ Thị Lý, 36 tuổi, sống cùng chồng và 3 con tại Nghi Lộc, Nghệ An, tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2001. Ngoài việc làm 7 sào ruộng, công việc chính của chị Lý là chăn nuôi lợn. Để có tiền mua lợn con và thức ăn, chị đã tham gia vào Quỹ Tình thương. Mức vay đầu tiên là 60USD đủ để chị nuôi 2 con lợn, đến nay đàn lợn đã tăng lên 6-7 con. Sau 5 vòng vốn việc hoàn trả và kinh doanh với chị đều diễn ra thuận lợi. Với mức thu nhập là 150USD/tháng, chị đang định xin vay thêm 950USD để mua thêm lợn con và thức ăn gia súc nhằm mở rộng, phát triển mô hình chăn nuôi.

loans.use: Buy pigs and mash

loans.name: Moa

texts.en: Mrs. Moa M., 63, is a mother of nine children. She is a housewife, while her husband is employed at a private company, earning up to $10 each day. Two of her children are grocers, three work at a garment factory making collectively over $300 per month, and the rest are married and live with their own families. Mrs. Moa M. hopes to use this loan to purchase more grocery products to expand her children's businesses and inventory. It is important to mention that with additional grocery items added, it enables her children to meet growing customer demands and generate more income for the household.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to expand her children’s business inventory

loans.name: Kung

texts.en: Mrs. Kung K. H., 24, is a housewife and has to take care her little kid who is too young to attend school. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, making only a meager sum to supplement his household. Mrs. Kung K. H. has concerns about not having enough money for her child’s tuition and other expenses of her family, depending solely on her husband’s motor-taxi business. Recently she has requested a loan to purchase a trailer that will attach to her husband’s motorcycle so that he will be able to transport many passengers and can generate more income for their household.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to go behind a motorbike, to transport passengers.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: Mrs. Srey L., 33, works very hard with her husband on their plot of land, growing variety of vegetables, and earns collectively around $14.50/day in revenue from selling her produce to the people in her community. She has three children. Two are enrolled in school and another one is unemployed. Mrs Srey L. hopes to use this loan to purchase more seeds to expand her crops, and the leftover of the money is to buy wood to repair her house.

loans.use: To purchase more seeds to expand her vegetable crops.

loans.name: Va

texts.en: Mrs. Va S. M., 37, works as a farmer growing rice crops and makes, on average, around $3/day in revenue. Her husband is self-employed as a construction foreman, making around $5 per day. Va S. M. has three children. One attends school and the rest are unemployed. Mrs. Va S. M. has recently requested a loan to purchase a motorcycle for her family’s transportation because the public transportation is too expensive for her family to afford. (Mrs. Va S. M. is pictured near a motorcycle she plans to buy).

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her family's transportation.

loans.name: Christine's Group

texts.en:
Christine N. has a bakery and also sells second hand clothes. She is 40 years old and a single mother who looks after her 6 children as well as her brother’s children. She has applied for a loan with BRAC Uganda in order to increase her inventory and baking supplies so that she can make more profits and improve her family life.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To increase stock

loans.name: Joan's Group

texts.en:
Joan N. is applying for a loan through BRAC Uganda because she wants to add to her business stock of fresh food such as yams and Irish potatoes. With the loan, Joan wants to purchase fresh food from nearby villages. Joan has three children.
