loans.use: To increase stock

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en:
Sarah K. has 4 children and is a tailor, making uniforms and crafts such as necklaces. Sarah also has a business selling water in the trading center. She wants this loan to pay for stock to increase her business.

loans.use: To increase supplies

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en:
Sarah L. is a farmer and a tailor. She is requesting a loan to purchase seed for her farm as well as cloth and thread for her tailor business. She looks after 4 children and wants to increase he profits to improve her standard of living.

Nanano S. sells pharmaceutical drugs and wishes to have a loan to increase her stock. She also intends to purchase a boda-boda motorcycle taxi to rent out to generate more income.

loans.use: To purchase sewing supplies

loans.name: Phoeun

texts.en: Mrs. P. Phoeun, 50, is a widow with two children, one son and one daughter, who both work. Her husband died under the Khmer rouge regime in year 1978.  Phoeun is living with her children in a village along Mekong River about thirty kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has been a silk weaver since 1992.  It's a skill she learned from her mother. Before starting her business of weaving, she was a farmer. Phoeun is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $300. She will use this loan to purchase silk material for continuing her silk production business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Sarin Group

texts.en:
These three families live in a village along the Mekong River about thirty kilometers north of Phnom Penh.  They are requesting their first group loan from Maxima to buy silk material for silk production.  
  
1- Mrs. S. Sarin (age 48 – left in photo with her husband) and her husband (age 48) have been married since 1994.  They have one daughter who studies in the local school. Her husband has been repairing wooden houses since 1990. Sarin has been a silk weaver since she was 20 years old. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. She is requesting her first loan from Maxima in the amount of $350. She will use this loan to purchase silk material for her weaving.

2- Mrs. S. Sarim (age 60- right in photo with her husband) and her husband (age 70) have been married since 1970.  They have six children—two sons and four daughters.  Like Asarin, Sarim has been weaving since she was young. Her husband grows rice. She is requesting her first loan from Maxima in the amount of $100. She will use this loan to purchase silk material for her weaving.
    
3- Miss. P. Sreyna (age 23- picture in the middle with her aunt) is single and lives with her aunt. Sreyna has been a silk weaver since she was 13 years old. It’s skill she leaned from her mother. She is requesting her first loan from Maxima in the amount of $200. She will use this loan to purchase silk material for her weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Kong, 44, and her husband, Mr. Soeng Kol, 50, have been married since 1982. They have one son who is a motor taxi driver. Kong and her family are living on an island of the Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has been a farmer and silk weaver (a skill she learned from her mother) since 1980.   On her farm, she grows tomatoes and corn. Her husband repairs wooden houses and buildings in the village.

Kong is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $1,000. She will use this loan to expand her farming business and repair her house.

loans.use: For expanding farming business and repairing her house

loans.name: Savin

texts.en:
Mrs. P. Savin, 30, and her husband, Mr. Meas Yoin, 33, have been married in 1998. They have three children – two sons and one daughter. One of her children is studying and the two youngest stay at home. Savin and her family are living on an island of Mekong River about twenty five kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has been a silk weaver since 2004. Before that she farmed. Her husband is horse-cart driver in the village.

Savin is requesting her third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of US $50. She will use this loan to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Jennifer's Group

texts.en:
Jennifer K. sells milk and wants a loan to purchase another fridge to increase her business and start another small business. She cares for 4 children of which two are orphans.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator for milk

loans.name: Aun

texts.en:
Mr. Y. Aun, 28, and his wife, have been married since 2004. They have one little daughter. Aun and his wife are living with his parents on an island of Mekong River about twenty five kilometers from Phnom Penh. Aun has been a silk weaver since 2000. It’s a skill he learned from his wife who is also a silk weaver. He is also engaged in fishing.

Aun is requesting his fourth loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $150. He will use this loan to purchase silk material for weaving.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Robina's Group

texts.en:
Robina N. is a tailor who also is in the business of photocopies. She wants a loan to finish her building. She has 3 children.

loans.name: Joe's Group

texts.en:
Joe N. bakes bread and cakes. She wants to purchase more trays and raise her level of profits so that she can send her 7 children to a boarding school.

loans.use: Purchase more baking equipment

loans.name: Uni

texts.en:
Uni A. is a 27-year-old entrepreneur who lives in Kisumu, Kenya. She is a widow with one child. Her business was doing quite well until about a year ago when her husband died and she became the sole income earner in her household. The rent and upkeep of her shop became too costly, so Uni decided to scale down and move to this tiny kiosk pictured here.

Her hard work, determination, and perseverance have led Uni to her success. She manages her stall during the day and sells second-hand clothes to her well-established clientele in the evenings. Her profits pay the household expenses as well as school fees for her child.

Uni plans to use the funds from her loan of US $600 to move to a bigger space She will invest part of the loan in buying cereals (grains) to supplement her current business, increase her stock of groceries, and save the remaining amount for emergencies.

loans.use: Increase her stock of groceries, pay rent for a bigger space, and augment her business with cereal (grain) sales.

loans.name: Bessy

texts.en:
Bessy A. is a 25-year-old entrepreneur and mother of two school-aged children. She and her husband live in Kisumu, Kenya. Her husband works as a security guard in Kisumu town.

Bessy began her current business of selling new clothes in the year 2005. She specializes in both children’s and women’s clothing such as skirts, dresses, and casual and formal tops. She periodically travels to Kampala, Uganda, where she is able to purchase a good variety at wholesale prices.

The prime location of her business on a busy street, and her two years of experience and her friendly interaction with customers has enabled her to establish a good clientele base. Her customers return to her shop for her wide selection or to make requests for certain styles.

Bessy plans to expand her business with her loan of US $700. She will invest part of the loan in a trial stock of second-hand clothes and also continue to purchase new ready-made clothes for re-sale.

loans.use: Continue purchasing new clothes and also try to buy stock of used clothes for re-sale

loans.name: Lize Silva

texts.pt:
Born in 1960, Lize Silva M. lives with her husband and 5 children in the neighborhood of Patrice Lumumba, in Maputo, Mozambique, where she sells beverages (soft drinks and beer) from home. She joined the credit program in February of 2007 and is now on her 3rd loan cycle. Lize will use her current loan to increase her stock of beverages.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Lize Silva M., portadora do BI nº100110039D , nascida a 28/04/1960 residente no bairro de Patrice Lumumba entrou no programa a 14/02/07 tomando o valor de 6000 mt agora esta no 3º ciclo vai tomar o valor de 12000 mt para pagar em 6 meses tem o seu negocio na sua casa vende serveja Refrigerantes com o valor do emprestimo vai alargar o negocio, tem 5 filhos e vive maritalmente.

loans.use: Stock increase

loans.name: Larissa Aminosse

texts.pt:
Born in 1977, Larissa Aminosse C. lives with her partner and 3 childen in the neighborhood of Ndlavela, in Maputo, Mozambique where she is in the business of selling whole grains and nuts from home. She joined the credit program in 2006, and is now on her 3rd loan cycle. Thanks to her loans to date, the business has been doing very well.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Larissa Aminosse C., portadora do BI nº 110650286T, residente no bairro de Ndlavela, veve maritalmente com 3 filhos negociante vende na sua propria casa ,vende produtos alimentares tais como , Amendoim ,feijão, caldos tudo a retalho, nascida a 18/10/1977, emtoru no programa a 14/12/06 tomando o valor de 3000 mt esta no 3º ciclo vai continuar a tomar 3000 para pagar em 4 meses o seu negocio esta a desenvolver muito bem.

loans.use: To improve the business

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.pt:
Maria Luísa M., born in 1957, lives with her partner and 4 children in the neighborhood of Liberdade, in Maputo, Mozambique where she sells food staples and cleaning supplies from home. She joined the credit program in June of 2006 and is now in her 5th loan cycle. Having paid all previous loans timely, Maria Luísa will be using the current $350 one to increase her business' stock to ensure it will continue to do well. She plans to invest a portion of the profits from her activities into improving her home.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Maria Luísa M., ´portadora do BI nº110179798T, com 4 filhos vive maritalmente nascida a 29/09/1957, residente no bairro de Liberdade tem o negocio em sua casa vende produtos de primeira necessidade tal com ovos ,Sabão folha de chá bolachas leite papel higiene,etc, com o valor pretende alargar o negocio com os lucros de negocio ela tem comprado bens para a sua casa entrou no programa a 30/06/06 tomando o valor de 5000 mt agora esta no 5º ciclo vai tomar o valor de 8000 mt a pagar em 5 meses.

loans.use: Stock increase

loans.name: Ketra

texts.en:
Mrs. K. Ketra, 45, and her husband, Un Many, have been married since 1980. They have four children—two sons and two daughters. Two of Ketra’s children are studying and one of her daughters is helping her in business of weaving cotton scarves. Ketra and her family are living along National Road Number Two, about twenty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has been in the business of weaving cotton scarves since 2000. Her husband is moto taxi driver.

Ketra is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of US $1,000. She will use this loan for expanding her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase material for weaving cotton scarves

loans.name: Hortência Alberto

texts.pt:
Hortênsia Alberto M., born in 1982, lives in Maputo, Mozambique with her partner and one-year-old child. She is in the business of selling quality clothing at the Xipamanine market. She just joined the credit program and is requesting a first loan of $275, which will allow her to increase her stock and therefore start to improve her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Hortência Alberto M., portadora do BI nº110431628A, residente no bairro de Hulene Tem o seu negocio no Xipamanine , vente roupas da calamidade, vive maritalmente nascida a 13/05/1982, tem 1 filho Esta a entrar no programa vai tomar o valor de 6000 mt para pagar em 6 meses

loans.use: Hortênsia will use her loan to buy more clothes to sell at her clothing stand

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Sokha, 43, and her husband, Mr. Prach Nhan, 49, have been married since 1980. They have five children -- two sons and three daughters. Sokha’s first son is married and living different house. The other three children are working. Two work in a garment factory, and the other weaves silk at home. Her youngest son remains in school. Sokha and her family are living on an island of Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. She and her husband are raising chickens and doing farming. 

Sokha is requesting her fifth loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $600. She will use this loan to repair her house and to purchase netting suitable for making a roof for her chicken pen.

loans.use: To raise chickens and repair her house

loans.name: Yoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Yoeun, 52, is widow with two daughters. Her husband died in 1988. One daughter works in a garment factory and other one is a tailor. Yoeun and her family are living on an island of Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.  Yoeun is in the business of selling cloth at the market in her village. She started this business in 1985.

Yoeun is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $700. She will combine this loan with money she has saved to buy wood to build her house. She is pictured with her daughter.

loans.use: To purchase wood to build a house

loans.name: Lida

texts.en:
Mrs. L. Lida, 32, is widow with three children—two sons and one daughter. Her two sons are studying in the local school and her daughter, the youngest, stays at home. Lida and her children are living  with her mother along National Road number five about twenty five kilometers from Phnom Penh. Lida is in the business of making Prohok (Cambodian cheese made from fish) and cucumber pickle, a food production business she started in 2002. Prohok isa  very famous food for Cambodians. They use Prohok to produce many kinds of other Cambodian foods.

Lida is requesting her fifth loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $500. She will use this loan to buy fish for making Prohok for reselling.

loans.use: To purchase fish for making and selling Prohok, a Cambodian cheese used in making many kinds of other Cambodian food

loans.name: Sinorn

texts.en:
Mrs. P. Sinorn, 49, and her husband Mr. Phi Sovan, 50, have been married since 1987. They have four children-- two sons and two daughters. Two of Sinorn’s children are working and the other two are studying. Sinorn and her family live along National Road number five about twenty-five kilometers from Phnom Penh. Sinorn has been growing rice since she was married. Her rice farm is about five kilometers from her house. Her husband is also farmer and a moto taxi driver.

Sinorn is requesting her third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $150. She will use this to purchase fertilizer and pesticide for growing rice.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticide for growing rice

loans.name: Violeta Vasco Mavie

texts.pt:
Violeta Vasco Mavie N., born in 1972, is a home owner who lives with her husband and two children in the neighborhood of Bunhiça, in Matola, Mozambique. She just joined the credit program with the goal of improving her home-based business of selling food staples such as flour, pasta, broths, etc. Violeta plans to use her first loan to increase her stock.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Violeta Vasco Mavie N., portadora do BI nº 100112491T, Casada , tem 2 filhos vive rem sua propria residencia esta a entrar no programa vai tomar o valor de 6000 mt para pagar em 4 meses tem negocio na sua residencia vende produtos de primeira necessidade tais como massas farinha caldoos, etc, é residente no bairro Bunhiça nasceu a 15/01/1972.

loans.use: Increase stock of food staples for her home-based market

loans.name: Margreth

texts.en:
This is 38-year-old Margreth M.. In 2001 she established a business seliing African print cloth. She now requires a loan of $275 to purchase additional stock in bulk. Margreth is married to husband Daudi, with whom she has three children. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of African cloth for re-sale

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
This is 28-year-old Stella S.. She is a seamstress by trade and in 2000 opened her own business sewing and mending dresses for clients in Ubungo, a suburb of Dar es Salaam. Most clients bring their own cloth to Stella and tell her the style of dress they would like sewn. However, Stella has realised that there is also a market for pre-made designs and is requesting a loan of $450 to purchase the materials necessary to sew a new range for sale. She has already repaid one loan from SELFINA and is determined to do so again. Stella is married to husband Emmanuel and has two children, Charles, aged 11, and Jack, aged 9.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase materials to sew a new range of clothes for sale

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline M. is a busy woman. She runs two businesses, one selling used clothing and the other raising chickens for sale. But let’s be honest, chickens can raise themselves without too many emotional scars, which leaves Caroline free to focus on the clothes business. It is this business for which she requires a loan of $275, with which she will purchase additional stock in bulk. Caroline is married to husband Dennis, and has three children, Peter, aged 12, Clifford, aged 2, and Dora, aged 1.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of fairly used clothing in bulk

loans.name: Phai

texts.en: Mrs. Phai N., 45, works making Khmer noodles and sells them at a busy market, earning around $3/day in revenue. Her husband runs a stand at home charging various kinds of batteries and generally makes around $4 per day. Mrs. Phai N. has four children. Two of them can work assisting her husband’s business, while the rest are married and live separately. Mrs. Phai N. hopes to use this loan to purchase some utensils and a mortar for grinding her noodles, and will use the remainder of the money to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase some utensils and a mortar for grinding her noodles

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Phai Nak start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
It’s difficult to know if customers frequent Esther M.’s bar to drink beer or to receive one of her big, beautiful smiles. Esther established the business in 2006 and it generates a monthly profit of about US$ 150. She requires a loan of US$ 550 to purchase additional stocks in bulk. Esther is married to husband Melkiori, with whom she has one child, daughter Gloria.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of beer and soft drinks in bulk

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
This is 26-year-old Beatrice L.. In 2006 she established a business selling stationery and other school supplies. She now requires a loan of $200 to purchase additional stock in bulk. Beatrice is married to husband Gerald and has three children aged between 10 months and 18 years. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her stationery shop

loans.name: Phum

texts.en: Mrs. Phum E., 58, is a widow and lives with her four children in a part of Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She stays at home cooking food for her children, while one of them works moving earth bought from the people in his arE. and resold for a good profit, earning  about $8/day in revenue. Another one of whom is employed at a factory making $2 each day and the rest of them are unemployed. Mrs. Phum E. hopes to use this loan to purchase a loading tractor for her son so that it will make his business of transportation much further faster and easier. (Her son is pictured with the loading tractor he plans to use for his business.)

loans.use: To purchase a loading tractor to assist in moving earth.

loans.name: Margreth

texts.en:
This is 38-year-old Margreth L., pictured with 8-year-old son, Prince, who lovingly assists her (when there's a camera around, at least) in her business raising and selling chickens. Margreth established the business earlier this year and now requires a loan of $275 to purchase additional chickens. She is married to husband Paul, with whom she has four children under 11.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional chickens to raise and sell

loans.name: Thuon

texts.en: Mrs. Thuon T., 42, is a mother of six children and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She and her husband are currently unemployed, so two of her children who work as laborers and two others as fishermen, working together to supplement their household income. Mrs. Thuon T. and her husband would like to run a business themselves, breeding ducks and buying rice crops from the growers and finally selling them whenever the price is going up. Recently, she has requested a loan to purchase ducks and rice crops to operate her new business, which she believes will increase her standard of living.

loans.use: To expand her livestock by adding more ducks.

loans.name: Yassar

texts.en: Yassar is a 30-year-old married man. He lives in the Bekaa with his wife and 2 children. Yassar repairs the vehicles. He fixes cars' wheels etc. This is the fourth time Yassar is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua. Yassar is an honest, reliable and hard working man. He requests $1,200 to buy tools and materials for his business.

loans.use: To buy tools and materials for vehicle repair shop

loans.name: Ramez

texts.en: Ramez is a 29-year-old married man. He lives in the Bekaa with his wife and child. Ramez is a car mechanic. This will the Ramez's third loan from A. Majmoua. He is requesting $1000 to buy equipment and materials to upgrade his business.

loans.use: To purchase equipment and materials to upgrade car mechanic business

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en: Khaled is a 31-year-old married man. He lives in the Bekaa with his wife and two children. Khaled is a car mechanic. He is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy tools and materials for his business. Khaled is known to be very dependable. This will be Khaled's fifth loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To buy tools and materials for his auto repair business

loans.name: Lam

texts.en: Mrs. Lam S., 54, works with her husband making baskets and sells them to wholesalers, earning collectively about $7/day in revenue. She has five children. Two are employed at private company; another one is a student and the rest are married and live separate from her. Mrs. Lam S. hopes to use this loan to purchase more bamboo and other tools to make additional baskets in order to meet her clients’ needs.

loans.use: To purchase more bamboo and other tools to make additional baskets to meet her clients' needs.

loans.name: Chring

texts.en: Mrs. Chring S., 43, works with her husband on a piece of land, breeding ducks, earning collectively about $7/day from selling duck eggs to the wholesalers. She has four children. Two are enrolled in school and the rest of them are unemployed. Mrs. Chring S. hopes use a loan to expand her livestock by adding more ducks to increase her standard of living.

loans.use: To expand her livestock by adding more ducks to increase her income generation.

loans.name: Al Rida Group

texts.en: Mariam, Nahla, Rahila and Mountaha are all married women that are part of one group called: 'A. Rida'. They live in the Bekaa and each needs a loan for her own business. Mariam needs to buy merchandise for her grocery shop. Mounataha needs to buy provisions for the traditionA. food she makes which is called the 'moune'. Rahila has to buy merchandise for her commerce, and Nahla wants to purchase new products for her accessories and perfumes business. This group has a long and solid history with A. Majmoua.

loans.use: To buy the needed provisions and merchandise for their businesses

loans.name: Zahra

texts.en: Zahra is 50 years old. She owns a tailoring workshop in the region of Saida, in south Lebanon. Zahra was involved with group loans from Al Majmoua, and then began applying  for individual loans. Zahra is requesting $1200 to refurbish her tailoring workshop. These improvements to her business will enable her to earn more income and to participate, with all the members of her family, to the house maintenance expenses.

loans.use: To refurbish her tailoring workshop

loans.name: Mal

texts.en: Mrs. Mal H., 39, is a widow and works as a broker buying palm sugar and rice crops from growers and reselling them to the people in her community, making about $3/day in revenue. She has six children. Two of them assist in selling palm sugar and the other four are students. Mrs. Mal H. would like to increase her income generation to pay her children’s tuition fees and her family’s expenses. She plans to use the loan to expand her inventory by purchasing more palm sugar and rice crops to meet her clients’ demands. (Mrs. Mal H. is pictured with her son who is in school.)

loans.use: To expand her inventory by purchasing more palm sugar and rice crops to meet her clients' needs.

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Mal Horn start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Zahi

texts.en: Zahi is a 32-year-old man who lives and works in the region of Saida, in south Lebanon. Zahi repairs and sells motorcycles. Zahi is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy motorcycle parts to develop his business. He is planning to insure a decent living for himself and his future family

loans.use: To buy motorcycle parts

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 21-year-old barber. Ali owns his barber shop in the region of Saida, in south Lebanon. Ali is uses some of his income to help his parents with their living expenses. He is requesting $1000 to improve the appearance and operation of his shop. Ali is a very determined young man who hopes to continuously upgrade his business.

loans.use: To improve the appearance and operation of his barber shop

loans.name: Akbar

texts.ru:
Akbar D. is 30 years old and a father of three children. His wife takes care of the kids and is not employed. He has been selling lemons at the Khudjan market for the last 10 years, both normally and wholesale. Until now the money he made in sales was enough to purchase more fruit. However, due to high inflation rates in Tadjikistan, he has been now forced to turn to Microinvest. Akbar is requesting to borrow 2000 somni to purchase more fruit for his business.

Translated form Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Джураев Акбар , возрост 30 лет , отец 3их детей ,жена домохозяйка.Уже 10 лет как торгует на рынке Худжанда,лимоном ,оптом и в розницу.До сих пор ему хватало для оборота , но сейчас с резкой инфляцией в Таджикистане он решил кредитоваться в Микроинвесте.Ему пока нужно 2000 сомони.

loans.use: purchase of lemons for trade

loans.name: Hurshed

texts.ru:
Hurshed H. is 22 years old and married. He works at a large bakery which produces a large variety of cakes and pastries, but in his spare time he also sells household items and guitar items at the market. He would like to expand his inventory for the coming winter season, and for that he is requesting to borrow 2000 somni from Microinvest.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer.

Хуршед Хабибов, возраст 22 года , женат .Сам работает в кулинарном цехе по производству кондитерских изделий , но помимо этого он в выходные дни торгует на рынке хозайственными товарами и электро принадлежностями .Хочет увеличить ассортимент , для этого ему понадобилось 2000 сомони и он решил обратится в Микроинвест.

loans.use: expansion of inventory

loans.name: Boltuev

texts.ru:
S. Boltuev is a father of two girls and a husband to his lucky stay-at-home wife. He works as a driver-for-hire for the local taxi shuttle service, but aside from that he has been raising cattle with his father since he was young. For the winter period he would like to purchase a calf for which he requires 2500 somoni and for that reason S. has turned to Microinvest.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Болтуев Шавкат отец двоих дочек и муж счастливой жены домохозяйки.Он работает наемным водителем на частном маршрутном такси.,но по мимо этого он с малых лет вместе со своим отцом занимается скотоводством.В зимний период он хочет купить еще одного бычка, для чего ему нужно 2500 сомони.Шавкат обратился в Микроинвест.

loans.use: raising cattle

payments.comment: Correction due to overpayment for business 28957

loans.name: Ramiz

texts.en: Ramiz lives in Khachmaz town. He was born in 1964. He is married, has 2 children. This man has sold dates and fruit for 2 years. He buys the dates from the villages for sale. Now he needs a loan of $950 to increase his goods and get more income.

loans.use: To buy dates and fruit

loans.name: Nizami

texts.en: Nizami H. is 49 years old, married, and has 4 children. He lives with his family in Khachmaz town. Nizami has his own cafe where he cooks kabobs. He buys the sheep from the villages and cooks kabobs in his cafe. He has 5 years of experience in this business. Now he needs a loan of  $900 to buy sheep for cooking kabobs and improving his business.

loans.use: To buy sheep

loans.name: Shakir

texts.en: Shakir was born in 1960. He is married and has 2 children. He lives in Khachmaz town. Shakir has sold scrap metal for 5 years. Now he needs a loan of $850 to buy metal for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy scrap metal to sell

loans.name: Namig

texts.en: Two years ago Namig started this business. This man buys the seedlings from the regions such as Barda, Yevlak, and Goychay for sale in Khachmaz. He was born in 1978. Namig lives in Khachmaz town and is single. Now he needs a loan of $850 to buy new sorts of seedlings for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy new sorts of seedlings to sell

loans.name: Firangiz

texts.en: Firangiz is a mother of 4 children. She was born in 1962. This woman lives in the Khachmaz region. She buys hazelnuts from the villages and prepares the kernel of the nuts at her home to sell. Firangiz has run this business for 5 years, to support her family. Now she needs a loan of $850 to buy hazelnuts to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy hazelnuts

loans.name: Esmira

texts.en: Esmira is a mother of 2 children. She is 46 years old, a widow, and lives in Khachmaz town. This woman has sold produce for 2 years. Now she needs a loan of $850 to buy produce for improving her business.

loans.use: To buy produce to sell

loans.name: Ilkhama

texts.en: Ilkhama (her husband is pictured) is a mother of 3 children. The M. family lives in the Khachmaz region. She is 42 years old. This family has been in the farming business for 5 years. Now they need a loan of $850 to buy fertilizer for improving their business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Khatira

texts.en: Khatira (her husband is pictured) was born in 1977. She has 2 children. The Hadjiyev"s family lives in the Khachmaz region. They have been in this business for 3 years. Now they need a loan of $850 to buy one cattle for improving their cattle breeding.

loans.use: To buy one cattle

loans.name: Hadjibaba

texts.en: Hadjibaba is a single man who lives in Khachmaz town. This man was born in 1985. Hadjibaba has been in this business for 3 years. He is a computer teacher. Now this man needs a loan of  $775 to buy the equipment (HDD, RAM, etc.) for the computer for improving his business and to give a lot of knowledge to his students.

loans.use: To buy the equipment (HDD, RAM, etc.) for the computer

loans.name: Elkhan

texts.en: Elkhan was born in 1975. He lives in Khachmaz town. This man is single. Four years ago he started this business. Now he needs a loan of $725 to buy one cattle for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy one cattle

loans.name: Nargiz

texts.en: Nargiz (her husband is pictured) was born in 1968. She is a mother of 5 children This family lives in the Khachmaz region. Nargiz's husband has been in this business for 10 years. He transports the building materials to the different places. Now they need a loan of $725 to buy spare parts for the lorry for improving their business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for the lorry (truck)

loans.name: Tushikamane A Group

texts.en:
Mwashamba S., age 23, is married with 1 child (2 years old) and also takes care of her mother. Mwashamba owns a water and ice cream business which she started almost 2 years ago. Working from 8am-10pm daily, she earns about $264 a month from this business.

Mwashamba is the leader of Subgroup A of Group Tushikamane (Swahili for “Be Together”), which totals 40 members. She will be sharing this loan with subgroup members Asha M., Zaria M., Tatu S. and Retisia W., who have businesses dealing in selling food.

Mwashamba hopes for a loan to purchase more ice cream ingredients.

In the picture, Mwashamba is standing on the left.

loans.use: To buy more ice cream ingredients

loans.name: Wailes Mibulani A Group

texts.en:
Fatuma A. is married with 2 children (4 and 7 years old). Fatuma owns a clothes and shoes business which she started almost 3 years ago. Working from 10 am - 4 pm daily, she earns about $53 in profit a month from this business.

Fatuma is the leader of Subgroup A of Group Wailes-Mibulani , which totals 30 members. She will be sharing this loan with subgroup members Sunday A. and Naima O., who have businesses dealing in food and clothes sales.

Fatuma now hopes for a loan to purchase more clothes and shoes.

loans.use: to buy clothes and shoes

loans.name: Kahe A Group

texts.en:
Mwajuma R. lives with her mother . Mwajuma owns a fish business which she started almost 11 years ago. Working from 5am to 10 pm daily, she earns about $53 in profit a month from this business.

Mwajuma is the leader of Subgroup A of Group Kahe which totals 30 members. She will be sharing this loan with subgroup member Tabu M., who has businesses dealing in soda sales.

Mwajuma now hopes for a new loan to purchase more fish.

loans.use: to buy Fish

loans.name: Bertilda

texts.es:
Mrs. Bertilda is 44 years old and finished elementary school. She has 6 children, 4 of which still depend on her. She lives in the small town of Palermo in the district of Chao in the province of Viru in the county of La Libertad. She dedicates herself to the raising of animals such as: turkeys, ducks, and chickens that she sells to people in her community as well as taking them to Trujillo to sell in the large market. She also a cow and two calves that are producing milk that she sells everyday to a large dairy product company in the country. In addition she plants corn and sells it to wholesalers in Viru and Trujillo. She is a member of the group “Las Luchadoras” (The Fighters), and they provided her first loan of 300 soles ($150) that helped her complete the sum to buy her first cow. With this loan of 700 soles ($250), which she will pay back in four months, she’ll buy fertilizer for the corn she has planted. Mrs. Bertilda dreams of buying more dairy cows in order to start a dairy farm.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Bertilda tiene 44 años de edad, estudio primaria completa. Tiene 6 hijos y 4 aún dependen de ella. Vive en el Poblado Menor Palermo del Distrito de Chao de la Provincia de Virú del Departamento de La Libertad. Se dedica a la crianza de animales como: pavos, patos y gallinas, los cuales luego vende a personas que van a comprar en su comunidad y también los lleva a vender a Trujillo, en el mercado mayorista, además tiene una vaca y dos terneras que está dando leche, la cual vende todos los días a una empresa grande de producción de lácteos en el país; también siembra maíz, el que vende a comerciantes mayoristas de Virú y Trujillo. Es socia del Grupo Mientras Tanto “Las Luchadoras”, en este grupo obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.300.00 soles con los cuales completó el dinero necesario para comprar su vaca. Con este préstamo de S/.700 soles, que cancelará en cuatro meses, comprará abono para el maíz que ha sembrado. La señora Bertilda sueña con comprar más vacas lecheras y poner una lechería.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for the land.

loans.name: Maria Carmela's Group

texts.es:
Maria Ysabel, Maria Carmela, and Dina Mercedes are members of the communal bank “Llamkasun” which is a quechua word meaning “Let’s Work,” for 1, 3, and 1 year respectively. Maria Ysabel has a grocery store that she’s been running for two years that belonged to her mother. On the other hand Dina Mercedes, with her husband, has been selling construction materials for 3 years. They used to use her brother’s car for deliveries, but a year ago they bought their own car and now have two cars to transport the construction materials. Meanwhile, Maria Carmela has a grocery store located in the district of Chiara. She used to have a kiosk in a market in the city of Ayacucho but decided to move to Chiara to dedicate herself to agriculture and livestock in addition to selling groceries. Maria Ysabel, Maria Carmela, and Dina Mercedes need loans of 800 soles, 1000 soles, and 1200 soles (total $1025 US) that will be used to buy rice, sugar, wine, champagne, milk, holiday breads, chocolate, oil, soft drinks of all sizes, split rocks, sand, bricks, and to pay their laborers. The savings will be used to build their homes, for the education of their children, and for emergencies. Their dreams are to own a mini-market, a better education for their children so they can become professionals, buy more cars, have good health, and have a harmonious home life.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva volunteer.

Maria Ysabel, Maria Carmela y Dina Mercedes son socias del Banco Comunal “Llamkasun” palabra quechua que significa “trabajemos”, hace 1, 3, 1 años respectivamente. Maria Ysabel tiene una tienda D. abarrotes, que anteriormente fue D. su mamá y hace 2 años ella lo administra. Por otro lado Dina Mercedes, junto a su esposo, venD. materiales D. construcción desD. hace 3 años. Anteriormente ellos trabajaban con el carro D. su hermano, pero hace 1 año se compraron su carro y actualmente tienen 2 carros, y así poder trasladar los materiales D. construcción. Mientras que Maria Carmela tiene un tienda D. abarrotes, que está ubicado en el distrito D. Chiara. Antes ella tenía un kiosco en un mercado D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho y decidió ir a Chiara para dedicarse además a la agricultura y ganadería. Maria Ysabel, Maria Carmela y Dina Mercedes necesitan préstamos D. 800 soles, 1000 soles y 1200 soles que serán invertidos en la compra D. arroz, azúcar, vinos, champán, leche, panetones, chocolate, aceite, gaseosa D. todo tamaño, piedra chancada, arena D. asentar, ladrillo y para el pago D. sus peones. Los ahorros los utilizarán para la construcción D. su casa, para la educación D. sus hijos y para las emergencias. Sus sueños son tener un minimarket, una mejor educación para sus hijos y puedan ser profesionales, comprar más carros, tener buena salud y vivir en armonía en el hogar.

loans.use: Maria Ysabel, Maria Carmela, and Dina Mercedes need loans of 800 soles, 1000 soles, and 1200 soles (total $1025 US) that will be used to buy rice, sugar, wine, champagne, milk, holiday breads, chocolate, oil, soft drinks of all sizes, split rocks, sand, bricks, and to pay their laborers.

loans.name: Jessica Jackelin

texts.es:
Jessica is 30 years old and has two children who attend school and depend on her. They live in Asentamiento Humano in the district of Salaverry in the Trujillo provence. She has set up a small shop in her house where she sells grocery items, vegetables, sodas and beers. She buys all of her products in a wholesale market in Trujillo where she gets lower prices and therefore higher profits on her sales. Jessica is a member of the communal bank Las Auroras en Accion, from whom she received her first loan to buy phone cards and kitchen utensils. With the new loan, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy more grocery items and vegetables, as well as beer in cases. Her dream is to have a car so she can avoid the high costs of transporting her merchandise.

La señora Jessica tiene 30 años de edad, estudió hasta el cuarto año de secundaria. Tiene 2 hijos en edad escolar que aun dependen de ella. Vive en el Asentamiento Humano “Aurora Díaz” del Distrito de Salaverry en la Provincia de Trujillo del Departamento de La Libertad. Ha ambientado la sala de su casa para poner una pequeña tienda en la que vende abarrotes, verduras, cerveza y gaseosas. Todos los productos que vende los compra en un mercado mayorista de la ciudad de Trujillo porque consigue los productos a menor precio lo que le permite tener mayor margen de utilidad. La señora Jessica es socia del Banco Comunal “Las Auroras en Acción”, en este Banco Comunal obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.300 soles, con los que compró tarjetas telefónicas y utensilios de cocina, que la mayoría de madres de familia de su sector le hicieron pedidos. Con este préstamo de S/.1,000.00 soles, que cancelará en 4 meses, comprará algo de abarrotes y verduras, además 50 cajas de cerveza. La señora Jessica sueña con tener un carro para poder movilizarse sobre todo a realizar sus compras en Trujillo y evitar incurrir en gastos de transporte.

loans.use: TO STOCK HER SMALL STORE WITH VARIOUS ITEMS, INCLUDING GROCERIES AND VEGETABLES

loans.name: Victoria's Group

texts.es:
Alejandra is 42 years old and has 5 children. Victoria is 39 years old with 4 children, and Elena is 38 and has 2 children. They are all members of the communal bank "Llamkasun", a word which means "Let's work" in their local language of Quechua.

Alejandra has been selling vegetables from a stall at the Nery Garcia Market for 15 years. In addition to the vegetables, she also grows grain, potatoes and other crops on the small bit of land she has in HuamanguilL.. Victoria sells clothing, grocery items and fruits, as well as cereals, cheese and small animals. And Elena sells clothing in the local fairs, and buys cereal, potatoes and small animals at the fair to later sell in the market.

They are requesting a loan to invest in their respective businesses, to buy potatoes, carrots and other vegetables, fish, clothing, etc, and they are all very grateful to the communal bank because they have learned a lot about running their businesses. They are now saving to increase their business capital and make repairs on their homes.

Alejandra tiene 42 años y 5 hijos, Victoria tiene 39 años y 4 hijos, mientras que Elena tiene 38 años y 2 hijos. Alejandra, Victoria y Elena pertenecen al Banco Comunal “Llamkasun” palabra quechua que significa “trabajemos”, hace 1, 6, 6 años respectivamente. Alejandra venD. verduras en un puesto del Mercado Nery Garcia hace 15 años, además D. L. venta D. verduras elL. también siembra trigo, papa, entre otros productos, en sus chacras D. HuamanguilL.. Por otro lado Victoria es feriante y venD. ropa, abarrotes, frutas y D. las ferias trae cereales, leña, queso, animales menores, para luego venderlo en las tiendas y repartiendo en casas. Asimismo Elena venD. ropa en las ferias y también realiza trueque, actividad ancestral que consiste en hacer un cambio D. productos diferentes, y D. las ferias trae cereales, papa, arveja, animales, para luego venderlo en el mercado. Ellas necesitan préstamos D. 1000 soles, 1200 soles y 1000 soles, que serán invertidos en L. compra D. papa, arveja, oca, haba, zanahoria, apio, cebolL., pescado, pollo, frutas, camotes, panamito, pantalones, mandiles, chompas y animales. Alejandra, Victoria y Elena están muy agradecidas con su Banco Comunal porque aprendieron L. responsabilidad y L. puntualidad, además pudieron ahorrar y con sus ahorros compraron su carro, e implementaron más sus negocios. Ahora están ahorrando para L. construcción D. su casa, para aumentar el capital D. su negocio y las diferentes necesidades D. su hogar. Sus sueños son educar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales, tener un negocio más granD., tener una casa D. material noble, mejorar su casa y que sean felices en su hogar.

loans.use: ALEJANDRA, VICTORIA AND ELENA WILL USE THE LOAN TO INVEST IN THEIR RESPECTIVE BUSINESSES SELLING FRUIT, GROCERY ITEMS AND CLOTHING.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia is 42 years old and only studied until the 4th grade because they could not afford it. She lives in the sector called Rio Seco in El Porvenir, Trujillo provence. She has 3 children, but only 2 still depend on her. Julia works making parquet floors, running the business and contracting out with other people who specialize in installing the floors. She also has a business selling beauty products. She joined the communal bank Bendicion de Dios after an invitation from her sister in law, and obtained her first loan to buy enough beauty products to sell on credit. With the new loan, which she will repay in 4 months, she will travel to Lima to purchase parquet and glue for her flooring business.

La señora Julia tiene 42 años de edad, estudió solo hasta el cuarto grado de primaria debido a que no tuvo mayor apoyo. Vive en el sector Río Seco distrito de El Porvenir en la Provincia de Trujillo, Departamento de La Libertad. Tiene 3 hijos pero solo 2 dependen de ella. Se dedica a hacer pisos de parquet, ella administra el negocio y da trabajo a otras personas especialistas en colocar y pulir el parquet, además se dedica a vender productos de belleza por catálogo. Ingresó al Banco Comunal “Bendición de Dios” por invitación de su cuñada, en este banco comunal obtiene su primer crédito de S/.300.00 compró productos de belleza para tener en stock y para poder vender al crédito. Con este préstamo de S/. 1,800.00 soles, que cancelará en 4 meses, viajará a la ciudad de Lima para comprar parquet y brea para colocar los pisos. El sueño de la señora Julia es tener un local propio en el centro de la ciudad para vender ahí sus productos.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE MATERIALS FOR HER FLOORING BUSINESS

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria is 56 years old and studied a career, but did not follow through with it for personal reasons. Currently, she lives in the district of Laredo in the Trujillo province in La Libertad. She has two children but only one depends on her. She sells clothing, beauty products and fashion jewelry to friends and acquaintances in her district and in other parts of the city of Trujillo.

Maria is a partner of the “Laredo” Communal Bank, from which she obtained her first loan of S/. 300.00. With this money, she purchased beauty products and jewelry to have in stock and be able to sell it using credit.

With this loan of S/. 1,300.00 soles, which she will repay in 6 months, she will purchase summer clothing which will be in high demand now that the season is nearing. Her greatest wish is to have a large boutique in the center of the city of Trujillo.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora María tiene 56 años de edad, estudió superior pero no ejerció su carrera por motivos personales. Actualmente vive en el distrito de Laredo de la Provincia de Trujillo, Departamento de La Libertad. Tiene 2 hijos pero solo 1 depende de ella. Se dedica a vender ropa, productos de belleza y joyas de fantasía a amigas y conocidas tanto de su distrito como de la ciudad de Trujillo. La señora María es socia del Banco Comunal “Laredo”, en este Banco Comunal obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.300.00, con este dinero compró productos de belleza y joyas para tener en stock y poder vender al crédito. Con este préstamo de S/.1,300.00 soles, que cancelará en seis meses, comprará ropa de verano la cual tendrá demanda porque ya se acerca la temporada. Su mayor anhelo es tener una gran boutique en el centro de la ciudad de Trujillo.

loans.use: Purchase clothing for the upcoming summer season.

loans.name: Alejandra Angela

texts.es:
Mrs. Alejandra´s main business is threefold : a bakery, wholesale and retail bread distibutor. She has a stall in the local market and a small general store in her home selling food and refreshments. This entrepeneur started her businesses with her own savings.

Her permanent stall in Leon´s market sells bread wholesale and retail. She is a single mom with a child currently studying in high school that she wants to provide for.

Ceprodel has been at her side financially with 19 loans in the last three and a half years. All the loans have been duly returned. We are glad to have been an instrument to help Mrs.Alejandra and her family better their living conditions through her bread sales.

Translated from Spanish by Henry Corral, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients

loans.name: Martina Felicita

texts.es:
Martina Felicita is 55 years old. She studied through secondary school. She has 6 children; only one remains dependent on her. She lives in the district of El Porvenir in Trujillo province in the department (region) of La Libertad in Peru. She started her business selling prepared foods in the wholesale market of the city of Trujillo. She worked 35 years in that business but the constant change of temperature between cooking and washing gave her a very delicate illness and forced her to change direction.

Currently she has a stand in the shopping center El Virrey in which she sells cosmetics, colognes, shampoos, and creams of different brands. She buys her products from a catalog, and every time she has the chance she travels to the city of Lima to buy men's clothing wholesale along with some cosmetic products.

Martina is a member of the community bank Victor Raul. When she received her first loan of 300 soles /Peruvian currency) she was still working selling food; she bought soft rinks, beer, rice and milk with the loan. With his new loan of 2200 soles, which she will repay in full in 4 months, she will travel to Lima to buy summer clothing and dress clothing. She plans to sell the clothing during the end-of-year holidays. Martina dreams of opening a toy store in another rented stand in the same shopping center.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran.

La señora Martina Felicita tiene 55 años de edad, estudió secundaria completa. Tiene 6 hijos pero solo 1 depende de ella. Vive en el Distrito de El Porvenir de la Provincia de Trujillo del Departamento de La Libertad. Inició su negocio vendiendo comida en un mercado mayorista de la ciudad de Trujillo, trabajó 35 años en este negocio pero el cambio de temperatura constante al cocinar y lavar a la vez hizo que adquiriera una enfermedad muy delicada por lo que tuvo que cambiar de giro.

Actualmente tiene un stand en el centro comercial “El Virrey” en el que vende cosméticos, colonias, shampoo y cremas de diferentes marcas, estos productos los compra por catálogo; además cada vez que tienen oportunidad viaja a la ciudad de Lima a comprar ropa de hombre al por mayor y también algo de cosméticos.

La señora Martina es socia del Banco Comunal “Víctor Raúl”, cuando recibió su primer préstamo de S/.300.00 todavía se dedicaba a la venta de comida por lo que compró gaseosa, cerveza, arroz y aceite. Con este préstamo de S/. 2,200.00 soles, que cancelará en cuatro meses, viajará a Lima para traer ropa de verano y ropa de fiesta que piensa vender en estas fiestas de fin de año. La señora Martina sueña con poner una juguería en otro stand que alquila en el mismo centro comercial.

loans.use: Buy clothing

loans.name: Zaituni's Group

texts.en:
Zaituni N. has a shop and is seeking a loan in order to purchase a refrigerator and shelving. She also wants to use the loan to increase her inventory. She looks after 3 orphans and also took in a child she picked from a garbage dump.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To purchase store fixtures

loans.name: Julio

texts.es:
Julio is 40 years old, works in transportation and already has two vehicles (taxis), of which he drives one. He rents the other one out to a third person.

Julio is separated from his wife, but he is responsible for and lives with his son, who is studying in school.

He has been working as a taxi driver since 88 months ago, so he can say that he has quite a bit of experience.

With his competence in this work, Julio's experience allows him to rely on stable customers who contact him by cell phone. This is also an advantage, so he knows which are the best places to pick up passengers, when traffic is congested, and other details.

This request will serve to acquire home appliances for his home. Currently, Julio only has debts at Fundación Agrocapital, and one additional financing source. His history and responsibility level at both are excellent.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Julio tiene 40 años de edad, se dedica al transporte ya que cuenta con dos vehículos (taxis) de los cuales uno lo maneja él y el otro lo renta a una tercera persona. Julio se encuentra separado de su esposa, pero el se hace cargo y vive con su hijo, el mismo que se encuentra estudiando en el colegio. La actividad de chofer de taxi la desempeña desde hace 88 meses atrás, por lo que se puede decir que cuenta con una amplia experiencia en el rubro. Si bien existe bastante competencia en este rubro, la experiencia de Julio le permite contar con clientes fijos que lo ubican mediante celular y también es una ventaja para él el tener conocimiento de cuales son los mejores lugares para recoger pasajeros, las horas conflictivas de tránsito y otros. La presente solicitud será destinada a la adquisición de electrodomesticos para su hogar. Actualmente Julio sólo tiene deudas en Agrocapital y otra financiera más, su cumplimiento y responsabilidad en ambas es excelente.

loans.use: Home appliances

loans.name: Lucia Perez

texts.es:
Before señora Pérez established her clothing sales business, she worked as a housewife and then as a maid. Because of the economic situation that she had with her four school-aged children and the little salary that her husband earned, their family didn't have enough to sustain itself.

Señora Pérez decided to work on her own as a street vendor selling clothing in markets. With fight and perseverance, she obtained an established place in a stretch of a market, which consists of a wooden stall that is completely open. This is why she feels obligated to rent a place to keep her merchandise every day. She started her business with savings from her previous jobs and loans from microfinance institutions.

She now has 11 years of experience in this business and gets up very early in the morning to travel since she lives in the outskirts of the city. This is so she can increase the income of her family as well as her sales. Ceprodel has offered her six credits to date, which have been paid off on time. This is why this client is considered an excellent one in light of the good way she has used her credits.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La Sra. Pérez antes de establecer su negocio de venta de ropa , se desempeñaba como ama de casa, luego de empleada domestica y por la situación económica que vivía con sus cuatros hijos en edad escolar y el poco salario de su esposo no era lo suficiente para la sostenibilidad de su familia.

La señora Pérez decide trabajar por cuenta propia de forma ambulante en los mercados dedicándose a la venta de ropa , con la lucha y perseverancia de obtener un lugar establecido logra adquirir un tramo en el mercado, lo cual esta constituida por una caseta de madera totalmente abierta, por lo que se ve obligada a rentar un lugar para guardar su mercadería diariamente.

El negocio lo inicia con ahorros de sus trabajos anteriores y prestamos realizados a los micros financieras. Actualmente tiene once años de estar establecida y viajando desde muy temprano ya que habita en las afueras de la ciudad, para poder ayudar a incrementar los ingresos de su familia al igual que incrementar su negocio. Ceprodel, le ha otorgado hasta la fecha seis créditos el cual han sido cancelados en tiempo y forma por este motivo se considera un excelente cliente en vista que realiza buen uso de sus créditos.

loans.use: Work capital and purchase of products

loans.name: Mila Esther

texts.es:
Mila is 26 years old. She studied only through primary school. She wasn't able to continue her studies because her parents had very little money and so she had to give the opportunity to learn to read and write to her younger sisters and brothers. She has 2 children; both remain dependent on her. She lives in the housing development Palermo in the district of Chao in the Virú province of the department (region) of La Libertad in Peru.

Mila decided to start her own business as a way of helping with the household expenses, since her husband does not have a full time job. She prepares and sells grilled chicken weekends in her house. She sells beer and soft drinks, as well. She does this work during the weekends because weekend days are the pay days of the workers in the local agribusinesses. She also works growing and selling ducks, pigs and sheep. With her earnings she is beginning to set up a small general store.

Mila is the President of the group Las Luchadores. With this group she received her first loan of 200 soles (Peruvian currency) with which she bought an oven to prepare the chicken; previously she had been renting her oven. With this new loan of 600 soles, which she will repay in 4 months, Mila will buy feed for the animals with plans to sell them duing the end-of-year holidays. Mila dreams of having her own house someday.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Mila tiene 26 años de edad, estudió solo primaria, no pudo continuar sus estudios porque sus padres no tenían dinero y tuvo que dar oportunidad a que sus hermanos más pequeños por lo menos aprendan a leer y escribir. Tiene 2 hijos y ambos dependen de ella. Vive en el Poblado Menor Palermo del Distrito de Chao de la Provincia de Virú del Departamento de La Libertad.

Decide empezar su negocio para ayudar con los gastos de su hogar ya que su esposo no tiene un trabajo fijo. Se dedica a preparar y vender pollo a la brasa los fines de semana en su domicilio, ahí aprovecha también para vender cerveza y gaseosa. Esta actividad la realiza solo los fines de semana porque son los días de pago a los obreros de las empresas agroindustriales; también se dedica a la cría y venta de patos, pavos, cerdos y ovejas. Con las ganancias que tiene está empezando ha implementar un apequeña bodega. La señora Mila es Presidenta del Grupo Mientras Tanto “Las Luchadoras”, en este grupo obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.200.00 soles, con los cuales compró un horno para preparar el pollo a la brasa ya que antes tenía que alquilarlo. Con este préstamo de S/.600 soles, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará alimento para sus animales los que venderá en las fiestas de fin de año. La señora Mila sueña con tener su casa propia.

loans.use: Purchase of animal feed

loans.name: Nancy Azucena

texts.es:
Nancy is 43 years old. She studied through secondary school. She has 4 children; 3 remain dependent on her. She lives in the housing development Aurora Díaz in the district of Salaverry in Trujillo province in the department (region) of L. Libertad in Peru. Nancy has a small beauty salon in her house where she offers haircuts, coloring, styling, make-up application, etc. At the same time she crafts nets used in traditional fishing and sells them to local fisherman.

With her first loan of 300 soles (Peruvian currency), received from the community bank "Las Auroras en Acción" she bought a mirror to hang in her beauty salon, hair color and creams. With this new loan of 1200 soles, which she will repay in full in 4 months, she will buy nets, thread, rope and lead for the manufacture of fishing nets of different sizes. Nancy is the guiD. mother of wawa wasi in her area (a program offering attention to poor children). She dreams of having a larger boat in order to to give it to her husband so that he could land more fish and sell more in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

L. señora Nancy tiene 43 años D. edad, estudió secundaria completa. Tiene 4 hijos, 3 aún dependen D. elL.. Vive en el Asentamiento Humano Aurora Díaz del Distrito D. Salaverry D. L. Provincia D. Trujillo del Departamento D. L. Libertad. L. señora Nancy tiene un pequeño salón D. belleza en su casa en el cual brinda servicio D. corte D. cabello, teñido, peinados, maquillaje, etc. Paralelamente confecciona redes que son usadas en L. pesca artesanal y venD. a los pescadores D. su zona. Con su primer crédito D. S/.300.00 soles, que obtuvo en el Banco Comunal “Las Auroras en Acción” compró un espejo para colocarlo en su peluquería asimismo tintes y cremas para el cabello. Con este préstamo D. S/.1,200.00 soles, que cancelará en cuatro meses, comprará redes, hilos, cabo, plomo para L. fabricación D. las redes D. diferentes tamaños. L. señora Nancy es madre guía del wawa wasi D. su sector (programa D. atención a niños pobres), sueña con tener un bote mas granD. para dárselo a su esposo para que tenga mayor pesca y pueda vender más en el mercado.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials for fishing nets

loans.name: Angela Ramona

texts.es:
Mrs. Ángela M. is a woman who works selling food. For a large part of her life, Mrs. M. has worked hard to be able to bless her children with being able to go to school. In addition, being a single mother, she has a responsibility to care for these little ones, offering them security and safety. She decided to sell cheese as a street vendor, working only in the mornings, so she could dedicate the rest of the day to her children and one grandchild that are in her care. One of her daughters is a single mother who works in the capital (city).

Later on she decided to sell food as a street vendor (instead of just cheese), to obtain better wages. At the same time, she started to take measures to obtain a section in the market, La Estacion. She successfully obtained this stand and renovated it with the loans that she had been granted, and continue to be granted, by Ceprodel.

Mrs. M. has worked with Ceprodel for three years and they have provided her with 13 loans, all of which she has paid back on time.

Translated from Spanish by Kim Baker, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Ángela M. es una dama que se dedica al negocio de la venta de comida, la mayor parte de su vida la Sra. M. se ha esforzado para poder bendecir a sus hijos con los estudios ya que además de ser madre soltera, debe de cuidar a estos pequeños brindándoles seguridad. Decide vender queso de forma ambulante realizando esta actividad solo por la mañana para dedicarles el resto del día a sus hijos y un nieto que tiene a su cargo ya que una hija de ella es madre soltera el cual trabaja en la capital.

Mas adelante decide cambiar de actividad y realiza la venta de comida, buscando obtener mayor ganancia siempre de forma ambulante, a la vez inicia a gestionar un tramo en el mercado La Estación el cual logra obtener y acondicionar con los prestamos que le ha otorgado y le sigue otorgando Ceprodel .

La señora M. tiene tres años de trabajar con ceprodel y se le han otorgado trece créditos de los cuales ha sido cancelado en tiempo y forma.

loans.use: Working captial for her business.

loans.name: Carol's Group

texts.en:
Carol N. makes clothes and crafts. She wants to purchase materials in order to make more crafts as well as to buy crafts from others. She plans to supply the big shops in Kampala. She looks after 2 children.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To become a wholesale crafts supplier

loans.name: Olinda Fredesminda

texts.es:
Olinda is 43 years old. She studied only through primary school. She has 5 children; 2 remain dependent on her. She lives in the housing development Palermo in the district of Chao, province of Virú and department (region) of La Libertad in Peru. Olinda used to live in a rural area; she decided to move to the housing development so that her children would be closer to school.

She started her business selling salchipollo (fast food chicken) and noodles during the afternoons. Later she was able to acquire a sales stall in the Buena Vista martket, where she was selling vegetables but the market was not well managed and closed. It was then that she decided to sell out of her house and began to set up a convenience store, the business that she has currently.

Olinda is a member of the group Las Luchadoras. With this group she received her first loan of 300 soles (Peruvian currency) with which she bought noodles, tuna, milk and juice.

With this loan of 500 soles, which she will repay in 4 month, Olinda will buy soft drinks and beer She dreams of having savings in her old age, and of seeing her children grown and successful.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Olinda tiene 43 años de edad, estudió solo primaria. Tiene 5 hijos y 2 aún dependen de ella. Vive en el Poblado Menor Palermo del Distrito de Chao de la Provincia de Virú del Departamento de La Libertad. Anteriormente la señora Olinda vivía en la chacra y decide trasladarse al Poblado Menor Palermo para que sus hijos estén más cerca de la escuela.

Inicia su negocio vendiendo salchipollo y tallarines por las tardes, luego consigue un puesto en el mercado de Buena Vista en el cual vendía verduras pero no hubo buena administración del mercado y terminó cerrando, es en ese momento decide vender en su casa y empieza a implementar una bodega, negocio que tiene actualmente. La señora Olinda es socia del Grupo Mientras Tanto “Las Luchadoras”, en este grupo obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.300.00 soles con los cuales compró: fideos, atún, leche y jugos. Con este préstamo de S/.500.00 soles, que cancelará en cuatro meses, comprará gaseosa y cerveza. La señora Olinda sueña con tener ahorros para su vejez y con ver realizados a sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase of  soft drinks and beer

loans.name: Martha Celestina

texts.es:
Señora S. is a very hard-working woman. She is a single mother who has always supported her kids by selling soft drinks and bread, which she sells both in her home and as a street vendor. With the little savings from her sales, she decided to set up at a bus station located in La Estación market. This place has a lot of passenger circulation, which is favorable for her sales and helps her generate larger profits.

Señora S. has benefited from working with Ceprodel with 23 credits. She has an excellent credit record, which has helped her begin construction of a stand where she makes her sales. It's necessary to point out that señora S. is both mother and father to her children, and her selfless and great spirit of bettering herself has allowed her to move past the difficult economic situation that she had faced.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La Sra. S. es una mujer muy luchadora, madre soltera que ha mantenido a sus hijos trabajando siempre en la venta de refresco, pan y gaseosa La venta la realiza en su casa y de forma ambulante. Con el poco ahorro de sus ventas decide ubicarse en una estación de buses ubicada en el mercado La Estación este lugar le favorece la circulación de pasajero para la venta de su producto y así generar mayor ganancia.

La señora S. ha sido beneficiada por Ceprodel con veintitrés créditos teniendo un excelente record crediticio que le ha ayudado a comenzar a construir su caseta para sus ventas. Es necesario señalar que la señora S. es padre y madre a la vez de sus hijos y con su abnegación y gran espíritu de superación ha podido salir delante de la dura situación económica en que se ha encontrado.

loans.use: Work capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase fabrics and other materials to create dresses and decorations.

loans.name: Jennifer's Group

texts.en:
Jennifer K. produces about 4 egg trays a day and wishes to take a loan in order to add to her flock, build more poultry houses, and purchase more chicks. She has 5 family members and looks after one orphan.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To increase egg production

loans.name: Juvenal

texts.es:
Juvenal is 48-years-old. His family consists of 6 people: Juvenal, his wife, and their four children, who are 15, 12, 11, and 9. He works at the Empresa Venado, where he is a welder. He also does tailoring work in his home on weekends and holidays. In both activities, he has broad experience of 8 years, and he is a hard-working and entreprising person. The competition in both activities is average since the labor market offers people that offer these types of services to private institutions. On the other hand, Juvenal's finished product is what sets him apart. With this request, he will acquire a motorcycle to be able to move around more quickly. This will cost between $700-800. His previous credit record is very good.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Juvenal tiene 48 años de edad, su familia se encuentra compuesta por seis personas él, su esposa y sus cuatro hijos que son de 15, 12, 11 y 9 años respectivamente. Juvenal es empleado dependiente de la Empresa Venado, ocupa el cargo de soldador, por otra parte y de forma particular realiza trabajos de sastrería en su domicilio los fines de semana y días feriados. En ambas actividades tiene una amplia experiencia de 8 años, es una persona trabajadora y emprendedora.
